headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Spain’s Colonial Said to Agree to Takeover
abstract: The Investment Corporation of Dubai has agreed with leading shareholders of a Spanish property firm, Colonial, on the broad terms of a 3 billion euro ($4.56 billion) takeover, Dow Jones reported.

headline: E-Mail at Work: Some Basics
abstract: Even when warned about the lack of privacy in using e-mail from the office, employees still e-mail with abandon.

headline: Writer-Less Colbert: ‘Where Are My Words?’
abstract: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg summarize Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert’s returns to television:

headline: WestLB and Flowers Mull Bid for Germany’s IKB
abstract: The German bank WestLB and Christopher Flowers, an American investor with a taste for distressed financial assets, are considering bidding for IKB Deutsche Industriebank, The Financial Times Deutschland reported.

headline: Air France to Buy Stake in Merged Delta-Northwest, Report Says
abstract: The Air France-KLM Group, Europe’s biggest airline, plans to invest in a combined Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines carrier, according to news reports.

headline: Microsoft Makes $44.6 Billion Bid for Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft said Friday that it would offer $44.6 billion for Yahoo, the ailing search giant. The surprise offer of $31 a share represents a 62 percent premium to Thursday’s closing share price. Yahoo shareholders could elect to receive either cash or stock.

headline: Bear’s Troubles Bite China (Again)
abstract: China still has a lot to learn about investing.

headline: Could Samsung Learn from Experience?
abstract: If the head of one of the biggest electronics companies has trouble getting technology to work, it might not be that simple for us mere mortals.

headline: Even in War, Not All Is War
abstract: It is a warm morning in February 2004, before the uprisings, before the mosque bombings, before Abu Ghraib and beheading videos and sectarian cleansing. A man named Kadum Abdullah, his bent figure draped in a green robe, is poling me and my colleague Razzaq on a wooden skiff through the marshlands of southern Iraq.

headline: Citi Shakes Up Its Mortgage Business
abstract: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: No Recession at Red Hat
abstract: Red Hat reported strong earnings, and its new chief executive said that as technology budgets tighten, the open-source software it provides becomes a more attractive alternative.

headline: How Does RiskMetrics Measure Up?
abstract: The RiskMetrics initial public offering is scheduled for this week. According to The Wall Street Journal, it could be a “bellwether” for this year’s I.P.O. market.

headline: Lobbyists Gird for Battle Over Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
abstract: It could be payback time.

headline: Buffett Beats Gates to Become World’s Richest Person
abstract: Warren E. Buffett has beat his longtime bridge buddy Bill Gates to take the title as the richest person in the world with $62 billion to his name, according to Forbes’ annual ranking of the world’s wealthiest people.

headline: Ex-Wall St. Chiefs Asked to Testify on Pay
abstract: A trip to Capitol Hill may not be exactly what Charles O. Prince III and E. Stanley O’Neal were hoping to do with their new-found free time.

headline: No I.P.O. Soon for Yelp, Chief Says
abstract: Yelp, whose Web site lets users review restaurants and other local services, isn’t likely to hold an initial public offering anytime soon, its chief executive, Jeremy Stoppelman, told The Deal’s VC Ratings blog.

headline: Maker of SuperPoke Takes $50 Million
abstract: A social network software maker, Slide, said on Friday it had closed a $50 million institutional financing round, marking the rising valuations of start-ups riding fast-growing Facebook‘s wave of popularity.

headline: Trump Entertainment Loss Grows
abstract: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company founded by Donald J. Trump, posted on Wednesday its biggest loss since emerging from bankruptcy in 2005.

headline: Prince, O’Neal, Mozilo to Testify Before Congress on Pay
abstract: Two former Wall Street chieftains and the head of the nation’s largest home lender will testify next week before a congressional committee examining the link between executive pay and the mortgage crisis.

headline: An Unusual Spark for the CNet Fight
abstract: The most recognizable player taking on CNet Networks is easily the activist hedge fund Jana Partners. But according to PEHub’s Dan Primack, the original agitator in the brewing proxy fight was, of all things, a venture capital firm.

headline: Warren Buffett Opens His Wallet
abstract: Warren E. Buffett is apparently in no mood to quit.

headline: British Bungle Bank Bailout
abstract: Is this a case of throwing good money after bad?

headline: Goldman Predicts More Write-Downs for Brokers
abstract: Goldman Sachs said it expects additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup estimated to record the highest amount of about $12 billion.

headline: Game Over for ADS
abstract: Friday morning, Alliance Data Systems filed a notice of dismissal of its action in Delaware’s Court of Chancery. In other words, ADS is dropping its lawsuit against the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm that agreed to buy it in May for $6.4 billion but has since backed out of the deal.

headline: UBS to Close U.S. Mortgage-Trading Unit
abstract: UBS, Europe’s biggest bank, will close a unit in the United States that makes bets on fixed-income investments as it scales back risk-taking after writing down the value of subprime mortgage investments by $14.7 billion last year, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Jean-Marie Balestre
abstract: I only met Jean-Marie Balestre once, and my impression of him was confused as he seemed like a cool enough, easy-going enough guy, while history wrote a different picture of the former leader of the FISA and the FIA, who has just died at 86.

headline: 3Com Shareholders Approve Failed Bain Deal
abstract: Shareholders of 3Com approved a merger agreement with Bain Capital Friday — one day after the private equity firm called off the deal following opposition from U.S. lawmakers.

headline: HotOrNot Sells for a Cool $20 Million
abstract: An iconic dating site, HotOrNot, has sold itself to a little-known media company called Avid Life Media for a reported $20 million.

headline: News Corp. Raises Stake in Premiere
abstract: News Corporation has raised its stake in Premiere, Germany’s largest pay-television operator, raising speculation that it could push for a full takeover of the company.

headline: Dubai International Says It Takes Back Citi Comments
abstract: How does one say “never mind” in Arabic?

headline: CNBC Video: Faber on Take-Two and EA
abstract: The unsolicited — and possibly hostile — deals keep on coming. The latest example hit Sunday when Electronic Arts, the video game giant, made a $2 billion offer for a rival, Take-Two Interactive Software. Take-Two, the maker of the wildly popular Grand Theft Auto series, quickly rebuffed the bid.

headline: E*Trade President to Resign
abstract: E*Trade Financial, an online brokerage struggling with heavy mortgage losses, on Wednesday said R. Jarrett Lilien plans to resign as president and chief operating officer, less than three weeks after Donald Layton filled the vacant chief executive post.

headline: AirTran Hopes for a Delta-Northwest Merger
abstract: As industry observers continue to speculate on the airline merger game, one carrier has made its own wish list.

headline: A Vocabulary Lesson Gleaned From a Trading Crisis
abstract: What is “epiphany risk?” Davos is full of bankers but this term is of recent enough vintage – and its humor black enough – that Howard Davies could get some good laughs when he gave the definition.

headline: Hour by Hour Accounts of Work — Share Yours
abstract: Feel like writing about your workday?

headline: Brazil’s Telemar Talks Up a Deal for Brasil Telecom
abstract: Telemar Participacoes , the owner of Brazil’s largest fixed-line phone carrier, said it’s in talks to take over Brasil Telecom Participacoes to gain control of almost two-thirds of the country’s land lines, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: U.S. and Canada Accuse Biovail of Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday charged Biovail, a Canadian drug maker that has been embroiled in a heated battle with several hedge funds, with accounting fraud.

headline: Excel Pays $2.4 Billion to Board Quintana
abstract: Excel Maritime Carriers said Tuesday it would acquire competitor Quintana Maritime  in a deal it valued at nearly $2.45 billion that will create one of the world’s largest dry bulk companies by fleet and capacity.

headline: 80th Oscars Officially Lowest-Rated Ever
abstract: Ratings for Sunday night’s Oscar presentations were the lowest ever, according to preliminary Nielsen figures, and down nearly 20 percent from last year’s broadcast of the event.

headline: Slowdown to Test Market for Credit Default Swaps
abstract: Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term, The New York Times says.

headline: Will Microsoft’s Executive Shuffle Scare Yahoo?
abstract: Microsoft’s new reorganization splits responsibility for its online offerings between four executives, most of whom also are responsible for parts of the Windows operating system. That resembles the complex organization at Yahoo, which bred the infighting and paralysis, that many Yahoo employees blame for its ills.

headline: Legg Mason Picks Chief From Inside
abstract: The money manager Legg Mason said Monday that it had promoted Mark R. Fetting, a senior vice president, to chief executive, succeeding Raymond A. Mason, who is retiring.

headline: Citadel Said to Eye Centro Stake
abstract: Centro Properties Group, Australia’s second high-profile victim of a global credit crunch, is attracting interest from the Citadel Investment Group, according to press reports.

headline: The White House and the Wall Street Factor
abstract: Are the early results in the presidential races showing an anti-Wall Street tinge?

headline: The 27-Hour Day
abstract: On-demand movies disappear after 24 hours. It would make a lot more sense to extend that viewing window to 27 hours.

headline: Analyzing the M&A Boom
abstract: The M&A boom that defined the most recent business cycle may well prove the largest ever, especially for that rich M&A subset of leveraged buyouts. With about $4.5 trillion of companies bought and sold in 2007 alone, its sheer size is astonishing and unparalleled.

headline: Should Microsoft Put Plaxo in Its Address Book?
abstract: Microsoft made a big splash with its $240 million deal to buy a sliver of Facebook. Now, some industry observers think the software giant should consider another social-networking deal. This time, the focus is on Plaxo, an early entrant into the social-networking field that was overtaken by rivals and is looking to fetch as much as $100 million in a potential sale of the company.

headline: Kathie Lee Signs On To ‘Today’
abstract: Kathie Lee Gifford, the longtime co-host of “Live with Regis and Kathie Lee,” is returning to morning television as the host of the fourth hour of NBC’s “Today” program, the network confirmed Monday morning.

headline: Buyout Shops Bow Out of Bid for Pub Operator, Report Says
abstract: Apax and Cinven, the private equity groups, have abandoned plans to participate in a takeover bid for Britain’s Mitchells & Butlers, The Telegraph reported, underlining the difficulties facing financial buyers as they consider offers for the troubled pub operator.

headline: European Hedge Fund Openings Declined Last Year
abstract: Investors cooled toward new hedge funds last year, with cash put into European openings falling for the first time since the 2001 bear market.

headline: V.C.s Shower Suniva With Cash
abstract: A solar cell maker, Suniva, has raised $50 million in its second round of funding to be used for a new manufacturing facility near Atlanta. The financing was led by New Enterprise Associates and Advanced Equities.

headline: CBS Earnings and Revenue Fall
abstract: The Associated Press reports: “Media company CBS Corp. reported a 14.6 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings Tuesday as revenue slipped, but adjusted earnings still beat analysts’ expectations.”

headline: Creator of ’24’ Calls It Quits
abstract: Joel Surnow, the creator of “24,” is clocking out.

headline: Zombies and Scrabble Knock-Offs to Invade MySpace
abstract: MySpace is about to open up its platform and give developers a set of tools with which to build applications that can run, and make money, on its site.

headline: And Obama Will Be at The Sands All Next Week
abstract: Hillary Clinton did her best impression of Wolf Blitzer at the conclusion of Thursday’s Democratic primary debate as she plugged an upcoming broadcast on the Hallmark Channel.

headline: You Lived the Bubble, Now See the Video
abstract: Between the layoffs and the lackluster bonuses, Wall Streeters need all the levity they can get these days.

headline: Chinese Retailer Said to Bring HSBC and UBS on Board for I.P.O.
abstract: A Chinese department store operator, Maoye International Holdings, has hired two more investment banks to underwrite its postponed Hong Kong initial public offering, according to Dow Jones.

headline: Qatar Buys Up Credit Suisse Shares
abstract: Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse in the open market and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year, according to its prime minister.

headline: Blackstone Said to Talk to Close Brothers About a Buyout
abstract: The Blackstone Group held talks last week with Close Brothers Group, a 130-year-old British investment bank, that may lead to a takeover offer,according to press reports.

headline: Let the Games Begin – The Market Will Speak on Proposed Game Merger
abstract: Translation of Electronic Arts offer for Take TwoInteractive: let’s test the market and find out whether Take Two investors, many of them doubtless frustrated by the ups and downs of Take Two’s struggles the last few years, might be tempted to take one in the hand.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Clear Channel Approval Is Near, Report Says
abstract: The $23 billion buyout of radio and outdoor advertising giant Clear Channel Communications could get antitrust approval from the Department of Justice as early as Wednesday, according to The Deal.com.

headline: V.C.’s Pump $20 Million into Virtual Iron
abstract: Virtual Iron, a start-up aiming to commercialize the open-source Xen virtualization software, has raised $20 million.

headline: Legg Mason Puts Up $1.1 Billion to Bail Out Funds
abstract: Legg Mason said Friday that it would put up $1.1 billion in cash and guarantees to bail out two of its money market funds that were coming under pressure from their asset-backed commercial paper investments, in the latest of such bailouts triggered by the credit crisis.

headline: ABC Profits Soars 30 Percent
abstract: Revenue for The Walt Disney Company “rose 9 percent, to $10.45 billion, led by gains in advertising revenue at ABC and ESPN,” Brooks Barnes reports in today’s Times. In its fiscal first quarter:

headline: S.&P. Warns on Banks’ Exposure to Bond Insurers
abstract: Commercial and investment banks could see their credit ratings cut if the bond insurers that hedge some of their assets were themselves downgraded, Standard & Poor’s said on Tuesday, as billionaire investor Wilbur Ross mulled whether to invest $1 billion or more in the sector.

headline: HSBC Pours $7.5 Million into India’s Newgen Software
abstract: HSBC Private Equity Asia, a subsidiary of HSBC‘s Asian Ventures Fund, said on Monday it had pumped $7.5 million into New Delhi, India-based Newgen Software Technologies, a company that focuses on document imaging and work flow management systems.

headline: Former Brocade Official Sentenced in Backdating Case
abstract: The former human resources chief of Brocade Communications Systems, Stephanie Jensen, was sentenced on Wednesday to four months in prison and ordered to pay a $1.25 million fine for her role in a stock options backdating scheme.

headline: Small Law Firm’s Big Role in Bundling Mortgages
abstract: In recent years, as subprime lending proliferated, a small law firm played a big role on Wall Street.

headline: Citigroup to Cut 2,000 More Jobs
abstract: Citigroup plans to lay off another 2,000 investment bankers and traders before the end of the month, according to The New York Times.

headline: Getty Images to Sell Itself for $2.4 Billion
abstract: Getty Images, the world’s biggest pictures and video distributor, agreed Monday to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $2.4 billion including debt.

headline: Did Bill Gates Really Say That?
abstract: Who first said, “That’s not a bug, it’s a feature?” Did Thomas J. Watson Jr., of I.B.M. really say, “I think there is a world market for about five computers?” Fred Shapiro, the editor of the “Yale Book of Quotations,” is trying to find out. Can you help?

headline: Strike News: ‘Criminal Minds’ First Back On Set
abstract: The CBS drama “Criminal Minds” will become the first television drama to resume production today, only eight days after the writers’ strike ended, the network confirmed today.

headline: Writers Informally Meet With Studios
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Investcorp Technology Raises $500 Million for Third Fund
abstract: Investcorp Technology Partners, the technology buyout arm of the Bahrain-based investment firm, announced Monday that it had raised $500 million for its third fund, outstripping the $400 million it originally sought to raise.

headline: Credit Suisse to Expand Private Bank, Report Says
abstract: The Credit Suisse Group bucked a financial sector trend on Thursday, announcing a worldwide expansion plan for its flagship private banking arm, Reuters reported.

headline: Rallying the House of Morgan
abstract: High in a Park Avenue skyscraper, within a maze of soft rugs and wood-paneled walls, James Dimon sits just footsteps from the mahogany roll-top desk of J. Pierpont Morgan, the feared lord of the House of Morgan and the most powerful financier of his time.

headline: A Loophole That Lets Activists Tread Softly
abstract: Just how exactly did two hedge funds manage to acquire a 21 percent stake in CNet Networks without triggering any regulatory disclosure requirements?

headline: Making Fraud Easier
abstract: The Supreme Court today made it easier for companies to defraud investors, and impossible for those investors to go after companies that help out in the fraud.

headline: Leaving Lenders Behind
abstract: Can’t get funding from a bank? Forget the bank.

headline: Unsolicited Bid for Yahoo Follows a Trend in the Acquisition Market
abstract: Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion offer to buy the Internet company Yahoo is not an aberration but part of a broader trend in which suitors make bold unsolicited bids during a time of weak stock prices and tight credit markets.

headline: United Technologies Makes Bid for Diebold
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation made public on Sunday an unsolicited $3 billion bid for Diebold, one of the largest makers of automated teller machines and voting machines.

headline: A Good Google Idea
abstract: What if you could search Google results by date, not relevance. If Google ever did it, you’ll wonder how you ever lived without it.

headline: EchoStar-AT&T Deal ‘Still Likely,’ Analyst Says
abstract: There are plenty of reasons to be doubtful about recent speculation that AT&T might buy EchoStar, which runs the Dish satellite-television network. For one thing, some believe that, for tax reasons, this month’s spinoff of EchoStar’s technology and infrastructure assets puts a two-year kibosh on any EchoStar takeout. Others look to recent sales of EchoStar stock by the company’s executives as a bearish signal.

headline: Who’s Next for the Deal Dead Pool?
abstract: Reddy Ice on Wednesday announced that it was in price renegotiations with respect to its pending $1.1 billion purchase by GSO Capital Partners. The announcement comes as the February 3, 2008, termination date for the transaction fast approaches. GSO must decide prior to that date whether to commit to the transaction if it can obtain financing, or terminate on that date and pay a $21 million termination fee. In the latter event, GSO may claim a material adverse change to Reddy Ice under the terms of the merger agreement in order to escape even paying the $21 million reverse termination fee.

headline: Guild Leader: Battle Is Over, but Fight Continues
abstract: The scenario sounds like the end of a classic television or film script: a battle ends, a victory is declared, and the exhausted combatant warns: “we’ve only just begun to fight.”

headline: Growing Demand for Video on Demand
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Video on demand, as popularized by HBO and the major cable operators, doesn’t have the cachet of online video but is increasingly gaining viewers, said Matthew Strauss, the senior vice president for new media at Comcast Cable, at a panel discussion at the National Association of Television Program Executives conference on Tuesday.

headline: Britain to Use Bond Sale to Aid Northern Rock Sale
abstract: The British Treasury said on Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the company’s assets into bonds for sale to investors.

headline: The Making of a Davos Man
abstract: It’s not easy to generate buzz here if your name isn’t Bono or Clinton or Gates. For a billionaire pipe-maker from Ukraine named Victor Pinchuk, it would seem harder still. Yet over the last four years, Mr. Pinchuk has transformed himself and his country into a bona-fide Davos brand.

headline: Buffett Sees ‘Poetic Justice’ in Banks’ Woes
abstract: Reuters reports on some interesting comments Wednesday from Warren Buffett, the legendary value investor, about the troubles facing many of the biggest financial firms:

headline: Sale of Retailer Hits Legal Snag
abstract: The co-founder of Active Endeavors, an upscale clothing retailer, and two other investors who are owed $936,200 apparently have blocked, at least temporarily, the sale of the company.

headline: The Late Show with Barack Obama
abstract: Barack Obama read “campaign promises” in the familiar Top 10 segment of “The Late Show with David Letterman” on Thursday night.

headline: A Debate on Bits: Technology as a Weapon Against Piracy
abstract: This week on bits a debate between Rick Cotton, the general counsel of NBC Universal, and Tim Wu, a professor at Columbia Law School. The subject is how technology should or shouldn’t be used to restrict the use of copyrighted works in the digital age.

headline: Davos and the iPhone Effect
abstract: In Silicon Valley, it may be all-iPhone-all-the-time, but here among the world’s business elites in Davos, it’s still very much a RIM Blackberry world. Indeed, if you pull an iPhone out of your pocket, it still creates a mild sensation here, because unlike in the United States, most Europeans have yet to touch Apple‘s six-month-old handheld phenomenon.

headline: Pernod Ricard Wins Auction for Maker of Absolut Vodka
abstract: Pernod Ricard, the French liquor company, announced Monday that it had agreed to acquire the parent of Absolut vodka for 5.63 billion euros ($8.87 billion).

headline: Icahn Enters Alliance Data Ring
abstract: The Alliance Data Systems buyout imbroglio took another turn Monday as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn let the two sides know that he is now on the scene.

headline: ‘Idol’ and ‘House’ Dominate Tuesday’s Ratings
abstract: Fox overwhelmingly dominated the ratings Tuesday night thanks to the one-two punch of the popular shows “American Idol” and “House.” At 8 p.m., “Idol” delivered an average of 28.1 million viewers, and “House” reeled in 22.5 million at 9 p.m.

headline: SRM Opposes Countrywide Deal
abstract: SRM Global, the British hedge fund that unsuccessfully sought to block a takeover of troubled British lender Northern Rock, is now taking the fight to Countrywide Financial, signaling its intention to fight the $4 billion takeover by Bank of America.

headline: K-Sea GP Files for $100 Million I.P.O.
abstract: K-Sea GP Holdings, a holding company affiliated with K-Sea Transportation Partners, filed on Wednesday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Network News Trimming Staff, Especially Producers
abstract: Most of the recent news about media industry layoffs has come from newspapers, where buyouts and layoffs are increasingly common. But television news operations have trimmed their employee rolls as well.

headline: CNet’s Case Against Jana
abstract: It is boom time for corporate litigation in Delaware. On Monday, the hedge fund Jana Partners sued CNet Networks in Delaware Chancery Court to force CNet to accept Jana’s nominations for seven candidates at the next election of CNet’s board of directors. Jana states that it is nominating these new directors based on CNet’s failure to create “shareholder value”, a code-word often used by insurgents in proxy contests as a precursor to forcing a sale of a company.

headline: Baltimore Suing Wells Fargo Over Foreclosure Crisis
abstract: Baltimore’s mayor and City Council are suing Wells Fargo Bank, contending that its lending practices discriminated against black borrowers and led to a wave of foreclosures that has reduced city tax revenues and increased its costs.

headline: Bank of America May Scrap Prime Brokerage Sale, Report Says
abstract: JPMorgan Chase‘s deal to buy Bear Stearns may have thrown a wrench into Bank of America‘s plans to sell its prime brokerage business.

headline: Q&A: Breaking the Hedge-Fund Silence
abstract: Last week, Phillip Goldstein, the hedge fund manager, announced a not-so-modest proposal: He told The Financial Times that he plans to sue the Securities and Exchange Commission over a rule about hedge-fund advertising that is often blamed for muzzling hedge fund executives.

headline: Fox Experiments With Monday Nights
abstract: Fox is moving two of its midseason dramas, “New Amsterdam” and “Canterbury’s Law,” to higher profile time slots. But because the writers’ strike has led to a shortage of new episodes, the shows will be shown in sequence — one will start after the other ends — instead of at different times on the same night between February and May.

headline: Commerzbank Replaces 2 U.S. Executives
abstract: The co-chief of Commerzbank‘s United States business and its New York-based head of credit have exited the bank in the wake of loss-making investments in subprime mortgages.

headline: Bank of America to Sell $6 Billion in New Shares
abstract: Bank of America announced on Wednesday that it planned to raise $6 billion by selling preferred shares, one day after reporting a 95 percent decline in quarterly profit.

headline: Facebook Is No Kingmaker
abstract: On 60 Minutes, Leslie Stahl said that presidential candidates “have to be on Facebook.” In fact, Facebook, and other social networks, have had a relatively little impact on the race so far. They are not suited to mass political persuasion any more than they are for other forms of mass advertising.

headline: A Writer Comes to Davos
abstract: Contrary to the stereotype, the folks at Davos are impressed by people other than hedge fund managers or captains of industry. They just might not always show it.

headline: Are ‘Cavemen’ (the Ads) a Bad Omen for ‘Cavemen’ (the Show)?
abstract: The “Cavemen” commercials are back. What does that mean for the “Cavemen” television series?

headline: F.B.I. Opens Subprime Inquiry
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation officials said the agency has opened criminal inquiries into 14 companies as part of a wide-ranging investigation of the troubled mortgage industry.

headline: Yang to Yahoos: Don’t Lose Focus
abstract: The prospect of working for Steven Ballmer and the leviathan that is Microsoft can’t help but be a bit distracting to the many employees of Yahoo. That could be why Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive of Yahoo, decided to circulate a memo to his workers Wednesday in which he thanked them for “staying focused on executing our priorities” and asked them to sit tight while Yahoo considers how to respond to Microsoft’s $44.6 billion takeover offer.

headline: Gazprom Moves Into Coal
abstract: Gazprom, the world’s largest natural gas producer, acquired control of a leading Russian coal company in an asset merger announced Tuesday that extends its sprawling business empire into electricity.

headline: Campbell Brown’s Soft Launch At CNN
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Borders Puts Pershing Partner on Board
abstract: Borders Group said it has given a board seat to a partner from Pershing Square Capital Management, an activist hedge-fund firm that is one of the bookseller’s largest shareholders. The partner, Richard McGuire, is one of five people responsible for managing about $6 billion for Pershing, Borders said in a statement.

headline: Smart Eating at Work – Part 2
abstract: More tips for smart eating at work.

headline: A Network for ‘Actuality’ Shows
abstract: Court TV has always served up gritty stuff, like courtroom dramas and crime and justice shows. The cable channel’s new name, truTV, is designed to reflect that, according to Marc Juris, the network’s executive vice president and general manager.

headline: The Worst Spam Ever
abstract: If you’re not feeling helpless and livid already over mobile phone spam, if you’re not already storming your carrier and Congress, it can only be because you haven’t been m-spammed yet. But your time will come.

headline: Tribune Clears Set at Original Warner Bros. Studio
abstract: The original Warner Bros. studio in Hollywood, now home to KTLA-TV Channel 5 and other Tribune entertainment companies, was sold for $125 million Wednesday to a Los Angeles real estate investment firm.

headline: Motorola May Spin Off Cellphone Unit
abstract: Motorola, it seems, is finally picking up Carl C. Icahn’s messages.

headline: Blackstone’s Golden One: Schwarzman Is Paid $350 Million
abstract: Here’s another number to ponder: $350 million

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Keeping Up With Blogs
abstract: A new site offers a directory of popular blogs in a range of categories.

headline: CW Cuts Jobs As the Strike and Low Ratings Take Their Toll
abstract: The CW has become the first network to “dramatically alter” its executive structure in the wake of the writers’ strike.

headline: Bear’s Stock Becomes a Battlefield
abstract: Only days after the fire sale of Bear Stearns stunned Wall Street, a battle seems to be brewing in the markets over the fate of the troubled investment bank and the controversial deal that JPMorgan and federal authorities devised to save it.

headline: Regulator Approves Liberty’s DirecTV Deal
abstract: The media mogul John C. Malone could soon be back in the business of delivering TV signals to consumers-this time via satellite.

headline: BofA’s Tough Countrywide Choice
abstract: As it watches its $2 billion investment in Countrywide Financial erode, the Bank of America faces a tough choice, says Fortune: It can buy Countrywide outright, pour even more money into the once high-flying mortgage lender, or simply bide its time and hope for the best.

headline: Bits Debate: Responding to Readers on Filtering
abstract: Tim Wu, of Columbia Law School, and Rick Cotton, of NBC Universal, respond to each other and to questions from readers, in the latest installment of our week-long debate on copyright, piracy, and digital filtering.

headline: Super Tuesday: Networks Try Restraint
abstract: Alessandra Stanley on the Super Tuesday TV Watch:

headline: Tax Scandal in Germany Fans Complaints of Inequity
abstract: For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.

headline: ‘Oprah’s Big Give’ Gets Big Numbers
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Rebel Monkey Nabs $1 Million in First Round
abstract: Rebel Monkey, a year-old startup that develops casual multi-player games, briefly emerged from stealth mode Wednesday to snatch $1 million in first-round financing from Redpoint Ventures.

headline: GSO Capital Said to Hire From Rival Firm
abstract: GSO Capital Partners, the $10 billion hedge fund that recently agreed to sell itself to the Blackstone Group, has recruited the head of asset-backed securities at Brevan Howard, a British rival, Financial News reported. Najib Canaan, who has worked at Brevan Howard since last May, is also a former colleague of GSO’s co-founders, the publication said.

headline: Clean Energy Investments Top $100 Billion
abstract: Despite the global credit crunch in 2007, new investment in clean energy industries like wind and solar power rose sharply to break through the $100 billion barrier for the first time, a research group, New Energy Finance, said Wednesday.

headline: Citi to Inject $1 Billion Into Hedge Funds
abstract: Citigroup, the banking giant, moved Monday to shore up six of its hedge funds pressured by a tightening in the municipal bond market, the newest problem to entangle the struggling company.

headline: Regulator Chills Alliance Data Deal
abstract: The turbulence on Wall Street threatened to claim another victim on Monday as the Alliance Data Systems Corporation, the big credit card processor, warned that its proposed $6.4 billion buyout might unravel.

headline: Allianz to Support $19 Billion Dresdner SIV
abstract: Allianz moved to shore up the $19 billion structured investment vehicle K2, which is managed by its Dresdner Bank unit, and said it was rolling back its business in complex finance products that have been hit by global credit turmoil.

headline: Aversion to Risk Deepens Credit Woes
abstract: The credit markets came under renewed stress Thursday as investors sought absolute safety and even moved away from debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage lending enterprises.

headline: Anatomy of a Short-Selling Rumor
abstract: The near-collapse of HBOS sent shivers through the financial world, as many wondered whether the same sort of rumor-mongering that dogged the British lender could have been at play in the demise of Bear Stearns.

headline: Premiering Tonight: The ‘Root of All Evil’
abstract: Lewis Black, the comedian for whom the word acerbic could have been coined, is finally becoming the host of his own show. “Lewis Back’s Root of All Evil” premieres Wednesday at 10:30 on Comedy Central.

headline: ‘Hottest Female Associate’ Contest Leaves Skadden Unamused
abstract: Who’s the hottest young female lawyer at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom? Last week that question sent the New York firm into a bit of a tizzy.

headline: Tripwire Considers an I.P.O
abstract: With 2007 revenue approaching $50 million and a third year of profits in the books, Tripwire is better positioned to go public, according to the company’s chief executive, Jim Johnson.

headline: Debating the Rise of Sovereign Funds
Microsoft’s Inner Thoughts on Online Advertising
abstract: You can be sure that Microsoft will use the antitrust arguments it made against Google’s recent deal for Doubleclick again to claim that it simply had no choice but to shell out $44.6 billion for Yahoo.

headline: Europe Sees More Canceled Offerings Than U.S.
abstract: The number of postponed and canceled flotations in Europe last year was almost five times higher than in the United States, despite the origins of last summer’s credit crisis and equity market volatility lying in the United States mortgage market.

headline: Live From North Korea, It’s the New York Philharmonic
abstract: “The New York Philharmonic’s concert in North Korea on Feb. 26 will be broadcast that evening on WNET, Channel 13, and distributed two days later on PBS,” Daniel J. Wakin reports.

headline: V.W. Denies Chairman Wants to Oust Porsche Chief
abstract: Volkswagen denied on Sunday that the chairman of its supervisory board, Ferdinand Piech, wanted to oust Wendelin Wiedeking as chief executive of the sports car maker Porsche, V.W.’s biggest shareholder.

headline: Why Would NYSE Want Amex?
abstract: A report that NYSE Euronext, the operator of the mighty New York Stock Exchange, might want to buy the much smaller  American Stock Exchange is prompting many to ask a basic question: Why?

headline: Getting Around Davos: Our Annotated Map
abstract: View Larger Map

headline: Reyes to Prison
abstract: Another chief executive was sentenced today to join the ranks of bosses in jail.

headline: Sprint Ousts Three Executives
abstract: In its latest move to restructure and shore up its stock, Sprint Nextel announced on Thursday the immediate departures of three top executives, including the chief financial officer, Paul Saleh.

headline: G.M.’s Fuel-Cell Car Makes a Statement
abstract: General Motors is using C.E.S. to promote prototype vehicles that lack conventional elements — like gasoline or a driver.

headline: Krispy Kreme Reshuffling Prompts Sale Speculation
abstract: The announcement that Krispy Kreme Doughnuts‘ chief executive, Daryl G. Brewster, has resigned amid a sputtering turnaround had at least one market pundit betting that a sale of the chain may ultimately be in the offing.

headline: ‘Animal Planet’ Bares Its Feral Side
abstract: Last month the film “Grizzly Man” debuted on Animal Planet, the cable channel owned by Discovery Communications. The 2005 documentary explored the life of a man who spent years with bears in the Alaskan wilderness before being mauled to death.

headline: Gore Raises $5 Billion for Investment Fund
abstract: The sustainable investment firm run by Al Gore is about to be closed to new investors, having raised close to its $5 billion target.

headline: Tips for Weathering the Storm
abstract: The buyout crowd here in Munich got a welcome speech from Jon Moulton, managing partner of Alchemy Partners, a London-based private equity advisory firm. And what was his counsel in these challenging times?

headline: Ranking Banks for a Different Kind of Green
abstract: Has the green movement finally begun to take hold of the bottom-line-driven banking industry?

headline: Chinese Developers to Brave I.P.O. Market, Report Says
abstract: Four more Chinese property firms plan Hong Kong initial public offerings this year to raise a combined $2.6 billion, Reuters said, as Beijing’s clampdown on bank lending forces developers to brave stock market volatility.

headline: Among V.C.’s, Talk of a Green Bubble Arises
abstract: Egged on by $100-a-barrel oil and consumers going green, venture capitalists plan to pour ever more cash into environmentally friendly technology this year, prompting talk of a bubble reminiscent of the dot-com era.

headline: Brazil’s Once-Hot I.P.O. Market Grinds to a Halt
abstract: Brazil’s market for initial public offerings has cooled from its white-hot pace last year with companies deciding that conditions in the broader equity market are too rough to launch new issues, according to a report.

headline: ‘Raymond’ and ‘Family Guy’ Are Rare Bright Spots in Syndication Firmament
abstract: LAS VEGAS – The last few years have been particularly rough for syndicated television shows. Local stations that are affiliated with the major networks purchase the rights to these shows and sell advertisements against them, but those ads can be a tough sell in the absence of hit shows.

headline: The End of eBay’s Egalitarianism
abstract: While small sellers on eBay are complaining about changes to the fees and feedback changes, larger sellers are benefiting from discounts that for the first time in the site’s history, treat high-volume merchants better than mom-and-pop sellers.

headline: Love for Deals Bound Diller and Malone, Court Is Told
abstract: The first hint of drama in the dispute between John C. Malone’s Liberty Media and Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActiveCorp came on Wednesday, the third day of a trial that turns on whether Mr. Diller’s plan to split IAC into five companies can survive a challenge by Mr. Malone.

headline: Who Swept the Ratings Last Night? You Get One Guess.
abstract: About 25.5 million people watched Amanda Overmyer, the rocker nurse with the two-tone hair, get eliminated from “American Idol” on Wednesday from 9 to 10 p.m., a figure that easily pulled Fox into a first-place position for the night.

headline: Citi Writes Down $18 Billion; Merrill Gets Infusion
abstract: Two of the nation’s biggest financial firms announced Tuesday that they had lined up outside investments to shore up their ravaged balance sheets.

headline: Microsoft and Yahoo Said to Be Holding Talks
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are holding informal merger discussions, marking a shift from the “radio silence” that previously existed between the two companies, according to several news reports.

headline: Upek Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
abstract: Upek, which makes fingerprint security products for notebook computers, has canceled its proposed initial public offering because of difficult market conditions, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Tuesday.

headline: Two Views of Digital Music Subscriptions
abstract: RealNetworks is taking over Yahoo’s music subscription service. It hopes that as one of the last paid services standing it will better be able to promote the concept. Yahoo is moving toward ad-supported online music, but the details are still not clear.

headline: GSO Nears Deadline to Close Reddy Buyout
abstract: At a time when all buyouts have been subject to doubts, the $680 million buyout of Reddy Ice Holdings by GSO Capital Partners is running up against the end of its extended marketing period.

headline: CNBC Video: THL on the Clear Channel Lawsuits
abstract: Topic A on Wall Street Thursday, by far, was Clear Channel Communications. Specifically, people were talking up the passel of lawsuits that radio broadcaster and its buyers filed against six banks that had agreed to finance the deal.

headline: BofA, Countrywide Said to Be in Merger Talks
abstract: Bank of America is in talks to acquire Countrywide Financial, the troubled mortgage lender in which it has a $2 billion stake, people briefed on the situation told DealBook.

headline: Kill A TV Bore: Watch ‘The Wire’
abstract: Some of the reviews of the fifth and final season of HBO’s inner-city Baltimore drama “The Wire” practically pleaded with viewers to watch.

headline: Directors Will Begin Talks With Studios
abstract: “The Directors Guild of America and Hollywood’s production companies said Friday that they planned to start formal contract negotiations on Saturday, promising a major break in the entertainment industry’s labor troubles,” Michael Cieply reports.

headline: Deconstructing Time Warner’s Fix-It Guy
abstract: At a conference in November, Richard Parsons, the outgoing chief executive of Time Warner, was asked what he would do if he were in the shoes of his successor, Jeffrey Bewkes. “If I were Jeff,” Mr. Parsons replied jokingly, “I would shoot myself.”

headline: SocGen Launches Rights Issue At Deep Discount
abstract: Société Générale, the French bank reeling from a rogue trading scandal, started a rights issue at a steep discount on Monday, intending to raise 5.5 billion euros ($7.97 billion) to bolster its balance sheet.

headline: WeGame Lands $3 Million from V.C.s, Report Says
abstract: San Francisco based WeGame, described as a “YouTube for gamers” seems to be off to a solid start since opening last month.

headline: Icahn’s Family Ties Bind Him to Sinking Motricity
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has gained fame over the years at least as much from his blunt talk as from his investment prowess. But the former came to the fore as the billionaire investor sat down for a chat with PEHub’s Dan Primack, who wanted to know about Mr. Icahn’s two investments in Motricity, a wireless content startup.

headline: The Space-Shuttle Quandary
abstract: If you are going to see what could be a once-in-a-lifetime experience, do you photograph it–and watch it through the limits of a view finder– or just enjoy it by taking in the entire sweep of the event with the naked eye?

headline: Shareholder Activists Take to the Web
abstract: Activist investors are stepping up their use of the Web to push for change at companies, Compliance Week wrote in a recent article.

headline: Plan to Rescue Bond Insurers Is Outlined
abstract: The recapitalization of bond insurers hit by the subprime crisis may occur soon, but if it fails, insurers can be forced to separate riskier activities from their municipal bonds business, New York State officials said Thursday.

headline: New Parodies, Anyone?
abstract: Comedy Central has successfully satirized evening newscasts on “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” and news talk shows on “The Colbert Report” with Stephen Colbert. Last month it introduced a court show satire by Lewis Black called “Root of All Evil.” Up next: spoofs of reality shows and news magazines.

headline: Bear Hugs From Abroad
abstract: In the midst of this weekend’s Yahoo hullabaloo, two other bear-hug letters — in addition to the one from Microsoft that we previously wrote about — were delivered to United States-based companies.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: At Sundance, a Second Life Sweatshop Is Art
abstract: Want a window into so-called telemetric manufacturing methods of the future? Performance artists at the Sundance Film Festival created a virtual sweatshop in Second Life that makes real jeans. Is it art for money or money for art?

headline: NBC’s Content Theme At C.E.S.
abstract: “Wedged between the towering glass televisions of the Samsung and Toshiba booths” at the Consumer Electronics Show “was an unusual presence: a plain old media company, NBC Universal,” Brad Stone writes in Thursday’s Times.

headline: Rough Economic Conditions May Fuel Visa I.P.O.
abstract: MasterCard once again reported blowout earnings last week, bolstering predictions of a smooth ride for the much-anticipated $10 billion initial public offering for its rival Visa.

headline: CW Loses Its Chokehold on WWE’s ‘Smackdown’
abstract: The CW will stop telecasting the showcase wrestling program “WWE Smackdown” at the end of this broadcast season, the network announced late Thursday.

headline: Buyout Firms Said to Eye $6 Billion Bid for Virgin Media
abstract: A consortium of private equity firms, including the  Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, are considering a takeover bid for Richard Branson’s Virgin Media, according to The Observer.

headline: Societe Generale Uncovers $7.1 Billion Trading Fraud
abstract: Update: The Financial Times said that the trader is Jérome Kerviel, a 31-year-old Frenchman who joined Société Générale in 2000.

headline: Box.net Takes $6 Million in Fresh Funding
abstract: Box.net, whose goal is to become the file system for the Web, has scooped up $6 million in B round funding led by U.S. Venture Partners, the company said Thursday.

headline: RiskMetrics Eyes $306 Million I.P.O.
abstract: RiskMetrics Group, the parent of the proxy advisory service Institutional Shareholder Services, has set a price range for its initial public offering, which could raise up to $306 million.

headline: Ziff Davis Media Seeks Bankruptcy
abstract: Ziff Davis Media, publisher of technology and video game magazines, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, citing a decrease in revenue from print advertising and subscriptions as contributing to its decline.

headline: Thinking Green, on a Private Island
abstract: Richard Branson was lounging under the starry midnight sky on Necker Island, his palm-dappled speck of an island, recently when he asked high-powered visitors, among them Larry Page of Google, Jimmy Wales of Wikipedia and Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, whther they thought global warming threatened the planet.

headline: The Upfronts: Now USA Likes October as Much as July
abstract: USA, the cable network, normally introduces its original series during the summer, when the broadcast networks are showing repeats. But in a departure from this practice, USA said Wednesday that it would begin a new 10-episode series of “The Starter Wife,” which chronicles the post-divorce life of a character played by Debra Messing, in October.

headline: ‘Smackdown’ Moving To MyNetworkTV
abstract: Cherry, Domino, Edge, Hornswoggle, Jimmy Wang Yang and their friends will soon have a new home.

headline: Sovereign Takes $1.6 Billion Loss in 4th Quarter
abstract: Sovereign Bancorp warned Monday that the nationwide downturn in the credit and capital markets exacted a $1.6 billion toll on the company in the 2007 fourth quarter.

headline: Deal Gossip on Jossip
abstract: Jossip Initiative, the company that owns the mediacentric Web site jossip.com and other ventures, is on the block and Conde Nast may be a potential buyer, The New York Post reported.

headline: Clips: TiVo Wins; More ‘Truth,’ Less Star Jones
abstract: — Thursday was a great day for TiVo: it announced a deal with CBS to share research data, PaidContent reports, and it won a major court victory “in its ongoing patent fight with satellite operator EchoStar Communications, now known as Dish Network Corp,” Broadcasting & Cable reports.

headline: SAG Awards: One Last Tribute To ‘The Sopranos’
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: Theory Gains That Trader Had a Helper
abstract: The police investigating the trading scandal at Société Générale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed, The New York Times reported.

headline: Citi Touches 52-Week Low as Bad News Continues
abstract: How low can Citigroup go?

headline: Coming F1 attractions at the IHT
abstract: I just wanted to check in to mention a few things to watch out for over the next week, as we’re so close to the beginning of the new season and it might be a time when readers wonder what will be happening in Formula One coverage at the IHT.

headline: Trying to Get the Swiss to Talk
abstract: Like Paul Revere, Konrad Hummler sounded the alarm last week as he made his way by train and by plane to his bank’s branches across Switzerland. This country’s storied role as secret banker to the world’s wealthy is under threat like never before, Mr. Hummler warned.

headline: Oh, Mama: Tobias Saga Goes Supernatural
abstract: The bizarre drama surrounding the death of Seth Tobias just got another offbeat character. Allow us to introduce Madam Simbi M’Arue, a woman identified by The New York Daily News as a “voodoo priestess.” She apparently also goes by the name “Mama.”

headline: Judge Allows Additional Arguments in Suit Against Enron Bankers
abstract: A federal judge in Houston on Friday left open a sliver of hope for Enron investors suing big banks over their alleged roles in defrauding investors in the energy company’s collapse.

headline: Days After CBS, NBC Orders A Canadian Drama
abstract: Days after CBS said it would broadcast a Canadian television drama, NBC announced a parallel acquisition on Friday, revealing that CTV’s “The Listener” will come to the United States sometime later this year.

headline: Reflections About Work, Hour by Hour
abstract: An entertaining new book offers day-in-the-life accounts of women working in various jobs.

headline: I Want My… Candidates to Chat With Veterans
abstract: MTV staged a series of conversations in Pennsylvania between each of the two remaining Democratic presidential nominees and a group of young veterans of the Iraq war, and plans to televise the dialogues across all the network’s cable channels tonight at 6 p.m.

headline: Was Private Equity Set to Pounce on Yahoo?
abstract: A rumor has emerged that a buyout shop was circling Yahoo shortly before Microsoft muscled in with its $44.6 billion takeover offer.

headline: Tata to Buy Jaguar, Land Rover for $2.3 Billion
abstract: India’s Tata Motors says it will acquire British automakers Jaguar and Land Rover from the Ford Motor Company for $2.3 billion, sealing a long-expected deal for the luxury car lines.

headline: Ahead of Dexter’s Broadcast Debut, Critics Slam CBS for ‘Celebrating Murder’
abstract: “Dexter” went under the knife ahead of its broadcast debut Sunday night on CBS. The curse words were replaced and the most visible moments of gore were truncated. But some critics believe the drama does not belong on broadcast television, with or without the edits, for a fundamental reason: the storyline encourages viewers to root for a mass murderer.

headline: Yahoo Looks at New Way to Survive
abstract: As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo may try to put a little more time on the clock.

headline: First Avenue to Raise $750 Million for Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: Alternative investments firm First Avenue Partners said on Monday it planned to raise up to $750 million for a portfolio that will invest with start-up hedge funds, as well as funds that have seen heavy outflows.

headline: Britain Orders BSkyB to Cut ITV Stake
abstract: The British government ordered BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, to cut its stake in ITV from 17.9 percent to less than 7.5 percent.

headline: An Upstart in Films With Many Fast Moves
abstract: With a mix of commercial comedies and dramas, indies and genre films, Overture Films, an upstart studio backed by John C. Malone, is fast entering a movie marketplace that is bursting at the seams with new players, releasing an ever-growing number of films vying for limited audiences.

headline: J. Crew’s Stylish Run on the Big Board
abstract: Last week, DealBook highlighted Orbitz’s slumping stock as the kind of thing that gives ammunition to critics of buyout-backed initial public offerings.

headline: Craving the High That Risky Trading Can Bring
abstract: It is easy to dismiss Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at Société Générale, as a fluke.

headline: Britain’s Friends Provident Announces Asset Disposals
abstract: British insurer Friends Provident on Thursday said it would dispose of its controlling stake in F&C Asset Management, the U.K.-listed fund manager, and pull out of its other wealth management businesses as part of a restructuring that would see the life assurer cut costs and rebase its dividend.

headline: Massachusetts Pension Fund Fires Goldman Sachs
abstract: The Massachusetts state pension fund has fired a money manager for the fifth time in five months, terminating a $1.2 billion contract with Goldman Sachs because of alleged substandard performance and discomfort with personnel changes at the bank.

headline: More Times Bloggers on C.E.S.
abstract: Some posts about the Consumer Electronics Show from other blogs at NYTimes.com.

headline: Justice Department May Have Beef With JBS Deals
abstract: A pair of deals by a Brazilian meat company, JBS, to acquire beef production assets in the United States is likely to direct political heat toward the Justice Department, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Europe Stabilizes
abstract: Davos, Switzerland

headline: Market Street SPAC Files for $350 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Another blank-check company is coming down the pike with an initial public offering.

headline: Deutsche Post Appoints Temporary Chief Amid Tax Scandal
abstract: The supervisory board of Deutsche Post on Monday picked Frank Appel to lead the mail and global logistics company after his predecessor resigned last week amid a growing tax evasion investigation that has gripped Germany.

headline: MySpace Co-Founder Buys Revver
abstract: Brad Greenspan, co-founder of MySpace.com and founder of LiveUniverse, an online entertainment network, announced that his company had acquired an ailing video-sharing site Revver.

headline: Index Closes First Late-Stage Venture Fund
abstract: In a move highlighting the growth of the European venture capital market, Index Ventures has closed its first fund targeting later-stage investments, a 400 million euro ($585 million) vehicle from which the firm may invest as much as 50 million euros in target companies.

headline: What Would David Do?
abstract: A S.L.R. camera can make a person look like a tourist. Is that any reason not to take a sophisticated camera on a once-in-a-lifetime trip?

headline: Sovereign Wealth Funds May Surpass Global Foreign Reserves
abstract: Sovereign wealth fund assets may soon surpass total official foreign reserves held by central banks and become the main vehicle for capital investment, a Morgan Stanley economist said on Tuesday.

headline: Diebold’s Fuzzy Numbers
abstract: As one of the largest makers of voting machines and A.T.M.’s in the United States, Diebold is presumably good with figures. But when it comes to the firm’s own accounts, it has hit more than a few glitches.

headline: Malone Speaks of Diller as Court Battle Starts
abstract: The cable media mogul John C. Malone told a judge on Monday that he held no ill will toward his longtime business partner, Barry Diller, who controls IAC/InterActiveCorp, even though the two are now battling over who controls what at IAC.

headline: Refco’s Ex-Chief Pleads Guilty to Fraud and Conspiracy
abstract: The former chief executive of Refco, one of the world’s biggest commodities brokerage firms, pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy and fraud charges that carry a possible prison term of more than 300 years.

headline: Microsoft Buys Virtualization Start-Up
abstract: The latest in a spate of deals for virtualization start-ups is Microsoft‘s acquisition of Kidaro, an Israeli developer of desktop virtualization software for enterprises.

headline: CSX Rebuffs TCI’s Demands for Special Meetings
abstract: There’s no love lost between CSX, the railroad operator, and The Children’s Investment Fund, the hedge fund battling for seats at the company.

headline: Microsoft Announces $3 Million Fund for Health Care Applications
abstract: Got a good idea for a health care application? If so, you could get as much as $500,000 in funding from Microsoft.

headline: China’s Sovereign Wealth Fund Said to Eye Stake in Fortescue
abstract: In China’s latest move to secure iron ore supplies, the country’s $200 billion sovereign wealth fund, the China Investment Corporation, and a coal mining company, the China Shenhua Group are reportedly in talks to take a sizable stake in Fortescue Metals, a major Australian iron ore producer.

headline: No Bonuses for Top Merrill Executives
abstract: Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that top executives, including Merrill President Gregory Fleming, will not receive bonuses for 2007 after the world’s largest brokerage posted $12.1 billion in net losses during the second half of the year.

headline: Colony Said to Bid For Tropicana Casino
abstract: Colony Capital, the private equity owner of the Resorts casino in Atlantic City, N.J., and a Resorts executive, Nick Ribis, have offered to buy the troubled Tropicana Casino and Resort for $850 million in cash, according to The New Jersey Star-Ledger.

headline: Predicting the Hot Tech I.P.Os of 2008
abstract: Just because the U.S. economy might be looking at a recession, doesn’t mean a few good tech initial public offerings can’t light up the market, says Fortune.

headline: F1 Pole Poll Vote
abstract: After today’s controversy in Malaysia, the first of the short F1 season, take a moment to vote in the poll I created over at formula1.about.com.

headline: Investors Push RAB Capital Up After Earnings Report
abstract: Shares in a British hedge fund manager, RAB Capital climbed over 7 percent Friday as broadly steady earnings indicated it’s weathering weak markets relatively well, though the firm cautioned it’s also facing a tough start to 2008.

headline: Peltz Seeks Control of Wendy’s Board
abstract: Nelson Peltz, the billionaire investor, is turning up the heat on Wendy’s International, which he wants to add to his fast-food holdings.

headline: $300 Million to Burn, With a Catch
abstract: Special purpose acquisition companies, which have come into vogue with the likes of Ronald O. Perelman, Bruce Wasserstein and Nelson Peltz, seem to be among the only equity offerings that aren’t suffering in the public markets at present.

headline: Facebook Scores New European Investment
abstract: Facebook has attracted yet another strategic investor, raising millions of euros to fuel its European expansion, from three German brothers who made their fortune building Internet companies.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Shelley Ross May Leave ‘Early Show’
abstract: Shelley Ross, the executive producer of CBS’s morning news program, ‘The Early Show,’ has so alienated staff members on and off camera that she may be ousted from her position within the next few weeks.

headline: ‘This Week’ Moves To Newseum In April
abstract: The Newseum, a Pennsylvania Avenue museum dedicated to journalism, will open its doors on April 11, the Freedom Forum announced on Thursday.

headline: Fees for High-Yield Loans Said to Rise
abstract: High-yield lenders may have had to write down the value of some of their loans, causing some pain. But Bloomberg News said Thursday they appear to be making some of their money back.

headline: Ratings: NBC Has a Strong Inside Game but ABC and CBS Shoot From the Perimeter
abstract: NBC eked out a rare victory in Thursday’s ratings, attracting the most viewers for the night by the slimmest of margins thanks largely to the strength of “Deal or No Deal.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the 8 p.m. game show drew 10.2 million viewers, finishing runner up to ABC’s “Lost” (11.3 million) for the night’s largest audience.

headline: Live From Macworld Expo
abstract: Steve Jobs speaks at the Macworld Expo in San Francisco. Here are the updates.

headline: Microsoft Reassigns Several Top Executives
abstract: As it continues to push for its $44.6 billion unsolicited bid for Yahoo, Microsoft announced a sweeping shake-up of its executive ranks Thursday, placing new executives over operations facing fierce new competition from Google, Apple and cellphone makers.

headline: High Finance Backfires on Alabama County
abstract: In 2002, a JPMorgan Chase banker named Charles E. LeCroy arrived in Birmingham, Alabama with a novel pitch to ease taxpayers’ burden. Some Wall Street wizardry, he said, could lighten their load.

headline: Leno and Kimmel Commiserate
abstract: E! Online calls it the cross of the couches: the NBC comedian Jay Leno and the ABC funnyman Jimmy Kimmel visited each other’s shows on Thursday and commiserated about the ongoing writers’ strike.

headline: Anti-Davos Gatherings Go Smaller, but Global
abstract: The World Social Forum has billed itself as the anti-Davos since 2001, when a collection of leftist activists of all stripes met in Porto Allegre, Brazil to proclaim “Another World Is Possible.” So, it turns out, is another kind of World Social Forum.

headline: Feeling Sick? Stay Home
abstract: Five reasons you shouldn’t come to work if you are sick.

headline: Bonderman’s Bright Side
abstract: Here’s one way to sum up the feeling at this week’s Super Return conference: A leading figure in the private equity business predicted a 40 percent drop in deals in 2008 — and went on to suggest it could be a lot worse.

headline: Buyout Bosses in Europe Form Committee
abstract: A who’s who list of London’s top private equity bosses has come together in a new committee aimed at developing a “common hymn sheet” for the controversial industry, The Times of London reported.

headline: MoneyGram’s Price for Independence
abstract: MoneyGram International may not have taken Euronet Worldwide‘s unsolicited takeover offer in December. But it is paying a dear price.

headline: A Farewell Note From a Departing Yahoo
abstract: Bradley Horowitz, a Yahoo vice president who left this week for Google, pens a loving note to his troubled ex-employer.

headline: Rural Electrification I.P.O., a Test for Investors in India
abstract: An initial public offering of 156 million shares of India’s state-run lender, the Rural Electrification Corporation, was fully subscribed within the first hour of the opening.

headline: We Report, You Decode: The Strike Ends
abstract: In a new regular feature, “We Report, You Decode,” TV Decoder will pull out some of the best (and worst) posts from our comment section. Today, what readers make of the end of the Hollywood writers’ strike.

headline: MBIA Sells Stock to Aid Rating and Raises $1 Billion
abstract: The bond insurer MBIA raised $1 billion on Thursday by selling shares at $12.15 each in an effort to protect its AAA insurance rating.

headline: Bear Deal Helps Lift Jittery Markets
abstract: Wall Street appears to be developing a case of whiplash.

headline: Can AOL Divide and Prosper?
abstract: It was showtime Wednesday for Jeffrey Bewkes, who held his first quarterly conference call with analysts since taking the chief executive’s post at Time Warner.

headline: Transparency in Derivatives?
abstract: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: Syms and the Future of Sarbanes-Oxley
abstract: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act has many detractors. They claim that the Act is an over-burdensome piece of regulation, one that has imposed costly and unneeded obligations on issuers. It has driven U.S. companies to exit the public markets and “go private,” and it has deterred non-U.S. companies from raising capital and listing in the United States.

headline: New Trial Ordered for Former Qwest Chief
abstract: An appeals court has tossed out all the guilty verdicts against Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted last year of 19 counts of insider trading.

headline: Icahn’s Legal Move Turns Up the Heat on Motorola
abstract: When billionaire Carl C. Icahn lost a battle last year to win seats on Motorola‘s board, he vowed that if the company failed to deliver better results, he’d be back. Now he is – and he has brought his lawyers with him.

headline: With ‘Deal,’ NBC Narrowly Beats CBS
abstract: NBC won the slimmest of victories in the ratings on Wednesday over CBS, largely due to an advantage in game show programming. At 8 p.m., “Deal or No Deal” on NBC attracted nearly twice the number of viewers as “Power of 10″ on CBS, 13.3 million versus 6.1 million, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Notes from a hot and humid Friday in Sepang
abstract: As I mentioned in a comment below, no sooner did I say it was not so hot in Sepang than the temperature rose over 30 degrees Celsius and the humidity rose to 71 percent at the end of practice. As I write these words, the humidity has hit 78 percent. That makes it feel hotter than Australia….

headline: Visa Eyes October Deadline for I.P.O.
abstract: Visa, the world’s largest credit-card network, said on Monday there is a 95 percent chance it will complete its initial public offering by Oct. 10, Reuters reported citing a quarterly filing.

headline: Positive Signs For Spanish-Language ‘Mas Vale Tarde’
