abstract: In December TV Decoder noted that Telemundo introduced a new late-night talk show, “Mas Vale Tarde con Alex Cambert.” In Sunday’s New York Times, Marc Weingarten notes that it is a “radical experiment” for Spanish-language television, and finds some encouraging signs for the show:

headline: The More Things Change…
abstract: The National Law Journal ran a story this week asserting that lawyers “specializing in mergers and acquisitions, particularly involving private equity firms, are scrutinizing more critically the bailout terms of contracts.”

headline: BNP May Set Terms of SocGen Bid in May, Report Says
abstract: BNP Paribas could set out terms for any offer for embattled rival Société Générale in May, La Tribune newspaper reported on Wednesday without saying where it got the information.

headline: Google’s Microsoft Fixation
abstract: Google has raised antitrust questions about Microsoft’s proposed acquisition of Yahoo. Google has long feared Microsoft, but that deal could well be a boon because it would further slow down its already poky rivals.

headline: Unexpected Retirement at the Top of Vanguard
abstract: The Vanguard Group, a fund manager known for its low-cost portfolios, surprised the industry on Friday when it announced that its chief executive, John J. Brennan, would step down.

headline: Covad Pays $7 Milion to Settle Suit by Former General Counsel
abstract: Covad Communications and its ex-general counsel have finally laid to rest a sordid, six-year saga of allegations of self-dealing directors, sexual harassment and retaliatory firing.

headline: With Fast Search Deal, Microsoft Aims at Google
abstract: Microsoft‘s $1.2 billion bid on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company, was seen mainly as an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products, but was also being done, analysts said, with an eye toward fending off Google.

headline: Fox’s Big ‘Moment': The Truth Hurts
abstract: “In the annals of reality television, ‘The Moment of Truth’ may be a milestone,” Alessandra Stanley writes in Friday’s New York Times. “Fox has come up with a cash-prize competition that is neither a game of chance nor a test of knowledge. It’s a pseudo-psychological trial by ordeal in which the contestants trade candor for dollars.”

headline: Q&A: Answers From Iraqis
abstract: Video

headline: Chinese Insurer $3.4 Billion Stake in Fortis Unit
abstract: The Ping An Insurance Company, a leading life insurer in China, has agreed to pay 2.15 billion euros ($3.4 billion) for 50 percent of Fortis’s asset management business, the companies said.

headline: Signs of Discontent Over Strike Tactics
abstract: “When Hollywood’s studios walked away from the bargaining table last month, striking screenwriters came out swinging,” Michael Cieply writes in Friday’s New York Times. But the “militant tactics may be creating fissures within the guild.”

headline: Toshiba Plays Clinton to Sony’s Obama
abstract: The press conference for Toshiba, creator of the HD DVD format, felt more like a funeral following the news last week that gives the rival Blu-ray format momentum.

headline: Schwarzman Said to Offer Olive Branch to Banks
abstract: Stephen Schwarzman has been forced to eat a rare slice of humble pie on Wall Street. Schwarzman, chief executive of the Blackstone Group, went hat in hand to JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers in an effort to mend fences after the banks pulled the plug on his $1.8 billion deal to acquire PHH, The New York Post reported.

headline: Ratings: Falling ‘Idol,’ Rising ‘Moon’
abstract: One day after the premiere audience for Fox’s “American Idol” fell 4 million viewers shy of the series’ 2007 debut, the talent competition slipped even further in the ratings on Wednesday.

headline: Goldman Names Four to Lead Securities Unit
abstract: Until recently, two people presided over Goldman Sachs‘s giant securities business; now, the unit will be run by four — or more, depending on how you parse the recent promotions at the investment bank.

headline: Loan Reviewer Aiding Inquiry Into Big Banks
abstract: A company that analyzed the quality of thousands of home loans for investment banks has agreed to provide evidence to New York state prosecutors that the banks had detailed information about the risks posed by ill-fated subprime mortgages.

headline: iPhone Entrepreneurs Line Up for Funding
abstract: It was only last week that Appleannounced that Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, run by venture capitalist John Doerr, would pony up $100 million to invest in start-ups seeking to create applications for iPhone, but already hopeful entrepreneurs are knocking on Kleiner’s door.

headline: Ex-Brocade C.E.O. Sentenced to 21-Month Prison Term
abstract: The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems was sentenced Wednesday to 21 months in prison for orchestrating a scheme to tamper with the company’s records of stock option grants.

headline: Inverness to Pick Up Matria Healthcare for $900 Million
abstract: Inverness Medical Innovations continued a shopping spree with the acquisition of Matria Healthcare, a troubled provider of disease management services.

headline: Bristol-Myers Said to be Shopping Baby Food Business
abstract: The drugmaker Bristol-Myers Squibb is sounding out potential buyers for a possible sale of its Mead Johnson baby formula food business, which is valued at between $7 billion and $9 billion, according to The Financial Times.

headline: What Do Clear Channel’s Buyers Want?
abstract: As rumors swirled in recent weeks that the banks backing the $25 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications would scotch the deal unless the private equity buyers agreed to rewrite the credit terms, many observers — including The Deal Professor — suspected the sponsors, too, would be secretly delighted to see the deal die.

headline: Silver Lake Hires Ex-Adobe Executive for Middle-Market Branch
abstract: Silver Lake, the technology-focused private equity firm, said Thursday that it has hired John Brennan, a former Adobe Systems executive, as a managing director at its middle-market arm.

headline: Studios Start Dumping Contract Writers
abstract: “Force majeure” terminations are now in full effect at Hollywood production companies.

headline: Visa I.P.O. Is Oversubscribed, Analyst Says
abstract: Visa‘s blockbuster initial public offering is currently oversubscribed for its expected trading start on March 20, Scott Sweet of the research firm IPO Boutique told MarketWatch.

headline: Clinton Booked On Letterman
abstract: “Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton will yuk it up on CBS’s ‘Late Show with David Letterman’ on Monday, a day before the Feb. 5 Super Tuesday contests,” the Associated Press notes.

headline: SAG Awards: The Winners
abstract: The television winners at the Screen Actors Guild Awards:

headline: Icahn Pushes for Merger of Railcar Makers
abstract: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn apparently thinks that Greenbrier, the biggest railroad-flatcar maker in the United States, and his American Railcar Industries would be good for each other.

headline: Tom Perkins Puts His Yacht on the Block
abstract: Tom Perkins, the prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist, is apparently looking to cash in one of his investments — but in this case, the investment is not a Web start-up but a high-tech superyacht. Mr. Perkins has put The Maltese Falcon up for sale, just two years after he first set sail on it.

headline: Ranking the Top V.C.’s in the World
abstract: Putting money into a start-up company can be exciting, but at the end of the day, it’s the money you take out that matters most to a venture fund’s investors.

headline: Chiefs’ Pay Under Fire at Capitol
abstract: In pointed exchanges with Congressional lawmakers Friday, three prominent financial executives defended the multimillion-dollar pay packages they received even as their companies were brought to their knees by the spreading credit crisis.

headline: Linkin Park Sings for Apple, but Doesn’t Pitch Products
abstract: As it hinted to fans, Linkin Park, the rock band, played a concert for Apple in New York. But it was simply a performance at an Apple store, not part of a product announcement event.

headline: Canadian Pension Fund Says BCE Buyout on Track
abstract: While turmoil in the financial sector has caused worries about the health of pending merger and acquisition deals, the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan says there has been no change in process regarding its 34.8 billion Canadian dollar ($35 billion) takeover of the Canadian telecom BCE.

headline: Private Equity-Owned Somerfield Said to Be for Sale
abstract: The owners of Somerfield Stores, a British grocery chain, have put the company up for sale and brought in Citigroup to conduct an auction, The Deal reported.

headline: Countrywide Denies Rumors of Bankruptcy
abstract: Shares of Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, plunged 28.4 percent Tuesday after it denied rumors that it was planning to file for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Hollywood Hopes For Strike Settlement Soon
abstract: From the picket lines to ballrooms filled with stars, Hollywood on Monday hoped for a deal to end a 3-month-old clash between striking writers and studios amid reports they could reach an agreement this week.

headline: U.S. Wonders if Stock Deal Is Tax Abuse
abstract: A strategy that corporate executives routinely use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Video Games and Valuations
abstract: Earlier this week, we covered Yahoo‘s brief, polite rejection of Microsoft‘s bear-hug letter. In making the determination that Microsoft’s bid “substantially undervalues” its assets, Yahoo had the benefit of advice from three investment banks.

headline: Readers Weigh In on Year-End Career Exercise
abstract: Post about year-end goal setting stimulates rich discussion among readers.

headline: A Showtime Experiment: Giving Away Content
abstract: Showtime is trying a variation on the old marketing adage “give away the razor to sell the blades.”

headline: South Korean Concern Bids for Korea Express
abstract: The Kumho-Asiana Group, owner of South Korea’s largest builder and second-biggest airline, bid more than 4 trillion won ($4.3 billion) for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services.

headline: What Happened at Carlyle Capital?
abstract: What was the Carlyle Group thinking?

headline: Google’s DoubleClick Deal Said to Receive E.U. Approval
abstract: European regulators plan to approve Google‘s proposed $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick without conditions, rejecting complaints by Microsoft that the deal would hurt competition, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Another City Where C.D.O. Spelled Trouble
abstract: Although it began in the United States, the subprime mortgage crisis has left few corners of the globe untouched.

headline: Jumbo Lender’s Shares Rise 36% on Private Placement
abstract: Shares of Thornburg Mortgage, a provider of jumbo mortgages that is trying to stave off a bankruptcy filing, rose 36 percent on Tuesday after the company disclosed plans to raise $1.35 billion.

headline: Oscar Ratings Are Way Down
abstract: Early ratings for the 80th annual Academy Awards suggest the program may have attracted a significantly smaller audience than in previous years.

headline: Sumitomo Heavy Goes Hostile on Axcelis
abstract: An increasingly bitter battle for control of Axcelis Technologies, a maker of equipment used in manufacturing microchips, erupted publicly Monday when Sumitomo Heavy Industries of Japan launched a $544 million hostile bid for company.

headline: What to Do With Bear’s C.E.O.?
abstract: JPMorgan Chase is obviously acquiring a lot in its $236 million purchase of Bear Stearns. For pennies on the dollar, the banking giant is buying extensive prime brokerage and clearing operations, as well as a $1.2 billion office building.

headline: Do Recessions Save Lives?
abstract: Now here’s good news. Recessions save lives.

headline: Julius Baer’s U.S. Unit to Go Public
abstract: With stocks so volatile these days, it might seem like a bad time to kick off a big stock offering. Then again, Julius Baer Americas, whose flagship mutual fund has a five-star rating from Morningstar, would seem to know a thing or two about market timing.

headline: Bond Insurer in Turmoil Turns to Familiar Leader
abstract: Joseph W. Brown Jr. got an inkling three weeks ago that retirement would have to wait. Former colleagues began calling to lament the tough times facing MBIA, the bond insurance company he used to run.

headline: Ratings: Kids (Well, Young Adults) Love Politics, Giving CNN A Super Tuesday Win
abstract: CNN was the most popular cable news source for Super Tuesday coverage, averaging 3.16 million viewers between 8 p.m. Tuesday and 2 a.m. Wednesday. Fox News Channel averaged 2.54 million viewers and MSNBC averaged 1.75 million.

headline: CBS Takes a Tighter Hold of CSTV
abstract: CBS Sports took a firmer grip on CSTV by announcing Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of it.

headline: Lehman Suspends Two Equity Traders in London
abstract: Lehman Brothers suspended two London-based equity traders after some of their trades were picked up by the bank’s internal control system, a spokeswoman said.

headline: Sallie Mae: Hoping to Earn a Diploma
abstract: Sallie Mae is flunking on Wall Street.

headline: The Big MAC
abstract: We are now a good nine months into the market turmoil that began early last summer. The crisis has left a host of dead deals and tarnished companies in its wake — not to mention scores of scarred merger arbitrageurs who were repeatedly blindsided by cratered transactions.

headline: How To Be Positive In a Bear Market
abstract: I get criticized sometimes for being too negative — “talking us into a recession” is one phrase I have heard — and perhaps I should take that to heart. There’s a bright side to almost anything.

headline: The Loneliness of AOL
abstract: Time Warner hopes that separating the Internet access business will make it easier to sell, spin out, or form partnerships with the rest of AOL. But since the Microsoft-Yahoo combination eliminates two possible partners, and AOL’s business is stagnant, it may have to go it alone.

headline: A Harsh Winter for Hedge Funds
abstract: Hedge funds around the world had the worst month in at least eight years in January as equities worldwide tumbled amid concerns that the U.S. economy was headed for a recession, according to Eurekahedge.

headline: CBS Will Beam…Uh, That is, Stream ‘Star Trek’ And Other Classics
abstract: Do you miss the original “Star Trek,” “Melrose Place” or, god help us, “MacGyver?”

headline: Candover Said to Offer $2.6 Billion for Expro
abstract: Candover, the private equity firm, has made an approach to acquire Expro International, an oilfield services company, in a deal that could value Expro at 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion), The Financial Times reported.

headline: IDS Group Seeks to Raise $86 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: IDS Group, which provides software for financial institutions and equipment manufacturers, is planning an initial public stock offering that could raise $86.25 million.

headline: Hedge Fund Urges Times Co. to Sell More Assets
abstract: One of two hedge funds seeking to name directors at The New York Times Company sought on Sunday to clarify its intentions for the newspaper publisher, saying it wanted the company to sell some assets and focus on digital publishing.

headline: Porsche Closer to a Takeover of Volkswagen
abstract: Porsche and Volkswagen demonstrated on Monday that empire building is alive and well in the European auto industry, as Porsche crept closer to taking over Volkswagen, even as VW bought control of a rival truck manufacturer.

headline: ‘Daily Show’ And ‘Colbert Report’ Seek Agreement With Guild
abstract: “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “The Colbert Report” with Stephen Colbert “have been seeking to make their own deal with the Writers Guild for an agreement similar to the one Worldwide Pants was able to reach,” Bill Carter reports in Saturday’s Times.

headline: 8 Banks in Talks to Rescue Ambac
abstract: Eight major banks are in talks to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, as part of an industrywide rescue being orchestrated by state regulators, people briefed on the negotiations said Friday.

headline: Mascoma Bulks Up With $50 Million Round
abstract: Mascoma, an East Coast biofuel startup with a multi-pronged approach to commercializing cellulosic ethanol, has just become one of the most heavily funded companies of its kind with a $50 million funding round first reported by peHUB.

headline: U.S. and China Still Sparring, But Smiling
abstract: After the geopolitics session saw a Chinese panelist offering lessons in democracy and an American speaker underscoring modesty, Chinese and American experts clashed — if good-naturedly, for the most part — during an economics-laden discussion Wednesday on whether the rest of the world still catches a cold if the United States sneezes.

headline: For ABC, ‘Oprah’ Gives Big on Sunday Night
abstract: On a night of low ratings across network television, ABC earned Sunday’s most viewers thanks to new installments of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Oprah’s Big Give.”

headline: Legg Mason Secures Financing to Prop Up Money Funds
abstract: Legg Mason, the asset management company, threw its short-term money funds a new lifeline on Friday by securing a $150 million letter of credit to prop up portfolios exposed to troubled structured investment vehicles.

headline: Lone Star Chairman to Testify in South Korean Suit
abstract: The chairman of Lone Star Funds plans to testify next week at the trial of the buyout group’s South Korean chief for alleged stock price manipulation, a spokesman told The Associated Press.

headline: Hostility by the Numbers
abstract: As analysts and investors try to handicap Microsoft’s chances of clinching Yahoo, we thought it was a good time to consider the track record for large, hostile bids.

headline: Hong Kong May Limit ‘Cornerstone’ Investors
abstract: In Hong Kong, preferential access to initial public offerings is a lucrative privilege. But as Forbes.com reports, “that cash machine may get shut off” now that Hong Kong regulators are considering a ban on the practice of doling out pre-I.P.O. shares to so-called cornerstone investors.

headline: Under Apple’s Watchful Eye, Games and Business Applications
abstract: Apple has created tools for programmers to build interesting applications to run on the iPhone. But all programs must be distributed through Apple, which will take 30 percent of the sale price.

headline: This Season, Bulked-Up Banks Came Clean
abstract: This earnings season on Wall Street was like the Mitchell Report for baseball, David Weidner of MarketWatch wrote: We found out who was on the juice.

headline: The Appetite for Securities Turns Less Hearty
abstract: To some on Wall Street, the last half of 2007 may have had the feel of a buyers’ strike. Financial products that had experienced rapidly growing demand suddenly became all but unsalable.

headline: NBC Schedules a Chat About Prime Time
abstract: NBC, which made a big point last month about moving to a year-round schedule of program introductions and changing the way it introduces its shows to advertisers, has announced a “prime time press presentation” to be held on April 2, six weeks before the traditional week of network upfronts.

headline: Kerviel Released as SocGen Shuffles Top Ranks
abstract: A French appeals court ruled Tuesday that Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader that Société Générale has blamed for nearly $7.7 billion in losses, should be released from jail while the investigation into his alleged fraud continued.

headline: A Quest for Glory and a Bonus Ends in Disgrace
abstract: When Daniel Bouton, the chief executive of Société Générale, announced that the venerable bank had lost more than $7 billion in unwinding the positions of a rogue trader, he called the culprit “a terrorist.”

headline: Quotes of the Day at Davos
abstract: “I’m glad that this time we did not cause it.”

headline: Of Sovereign Funds and Shooting Rabbits
abstract: After being the talk of the World Economic Forum in Switzerland last month, the subject of sovereign wealth funds was the buzz of Capitol Hill on Thursday. A bipartisan commission heard testimony from four Democratic lawmakers who warned, some more intensely than others, about the potential risks of government-run funds in China and other foreign countries making big investments in American businesses.

headline: Motorola Picks Up Chinese Set-Top Assets
abstract: Motorola said Monday it had acquired the assets related to the digital cable set-top products of Zhejiang Dahua Digital Technology and Hangzhou Image Silicon.

headline: True Lies
abstract: Yesterday’s Times had an article on Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the C.I.A. official who authorized destroying the tapes of C.I.A. agents questioning terrorism suspects.

headline: UBS Names Head of Investment Banking
abstract: UBS on Wednesday named Jerker Johansson as head of its investment bank, ending a protracted search that followed the write-downs of billions of dollars from the subprime crisis.

headline: Borrow and Spend
abstract: Yesterday’s Times included an op-ed piece by W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, arguing “You Are What You Spend.” They compare 1975 statistics to 2006 figures and conclude the bottom 20 percent of Americans in terms of income are doing better than you might expect in terms of consumption.

headline: Visa’s Shine Unlikely to Rub Off on Other I.P.O. Hopefuls
abstract: The blockbuster initial public offering of Visa — the largest ever in the United States — will do little to revive the slowing I.P.O. market, which has been dampened by investors spooked by the credit crisis.

headline: V.C.’s Hot on Pythagoras Solar
abstract: Solar energy startup Pythagoras Solar has completed a $10 million first round of funding led by Israel Cleantech Ventures, according to a report by Clean Edge.

headline: 3i in Deal to Take Civica Private
abstract: 3i Group, the London-based buyout firm, agreed Friday to acquire software company Civica for about 220 million pounds ($440 million) including debt.

headline: As Good as Cash, Until It’s Not
abstract: Investors across the nation are finding themselves in Wall Street’s version of the Hotel California, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson writes in her Sunday column: they have checked into an investment they can never leave.

headline: Carlyle Adds Telecom and Media Adviser
abstract: The Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity firm, said Thursday that Stephen C. Gray had become a senior adviser to the firm’s global telecommunications and media group. Mr. Gray is a telecom entrepreneur and former executive at McLeodUSA and MCI.

headline: See You Tomorrow!
abstract: David will be the host of an event at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport.

headline: Recession Fears Send Bank Shares Down
abstract: Shares of Citigroup and other financial companies suffered broad declines for a second day on Tuesday, as evidence mounted that borrowers are falling behind on more payments, the nation’s economy might be in recession, and losses on complex debt securities might worsen.

headline: Placing Bets on the Diller-Malone Showdown
abstract: As the media industry eagerly awaits the judge’s ruling in Barry Diller and John C. Malone’s acrimonious court battle for control of IAC/InterActiveCorp, one industry observer has placed his bets on the outcome.

headline: The Passion of Steve Jobs
abstract: Apple’s chief executive talks up his company’s latest products and offers some frank thoughts about his competitors.

headline: Political TV: Edwards Scheduled on ‘Letterman’
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards will appear on “The Late Show with David Letterman” next Tuesday, CBS announced today.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Bidders Said to Resubmit 3Com Offer
abstract: Bain Capital and the Huawei Company of China plan to resubmit an application seeking United States approval for a planned $2.2 billion buyout of 3Com within the next several weeks, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: CNBC Video: Bear’s New C.E.O. Speaks
An Antidote to Spitzer’s Style
abstract: A career expert reveals details of her personal life as part of her branding strategy.

headline: Entrepreneurship Takes Off in Ireland
abstract: Ireland is now alive with enthusiasm for entrepreneurs, who seemingly rank just below rock stars in popularity.

headline: ‘American Gladiators:’ A Breakout Hit?
abstract: Is “American Gladiators” the unexpected hit of the 2007-08 television season?

headline: CFO’s Grow Glummer
abstract: That a recession is under way has become conventional wisdom, even if many economists still do not have one in their forecasts.

headline: Eyeing the Future at C.E.S., Part 1
abstract: A video eyewear company offers immersive video goggles, while threatening to turn customers into fashion outcasts.

headline: Video Q&A: Answers From Iraqis, Part 2
abstract: Video

headline: The Biggest Airline Deals to Take Flight
abstract: As the boards of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines gather Tuesday to discuss a potential merger — one that could shake up an industry that has clamored for consolidation — it’s worth putting any deal that is reached in perspective. Dealogic helped DealBook out by listing some of the biggest airline transactions to get off the ground.

headline: Dead Man Blogging
abstract: The reality of the Consumer Electronics Show:

headline: Motorola Snaps Up Soundbuzz
abstract: Motorola said Monday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Soundbuzz, a Singapore-based digital music provider, adding that the deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2008.

headline: The (Unlisted) Hot Tickets at Davos
abstract: Davos may seem like it is all about the big theatrically produced panels and presentations, like Bill Gates’ planned speech this year schedule titled “A New Approach to Capitalism in the 21st Century.” But the hottest tickets — and the hardest to come by — aren’t on the schedule at all.

headline: How to Read a Private Equity Deal Agreement
abstract: Reading merger agreements is like putting together a jigsaw puzzle. For those who like their puzzle a bit more complex, private equity merger agreements are the ones with more pieces. And since it is Friday and we’re all looking for a distraction, what follows is a how to guide for reading private equity agreements for closing risk.

headline: Canopy Nabs $15 Million in First Round
abstract: Canopy Financial announced a $15 million first institutional round of capital from Granite Global Ventures on Thursday.

headline: Lawsuit Seeks Ritchie Capital’s Secrets
abstract: Ritchie Capital Management “may be forced to deliver a lot more than an apology, if investors have their way,” HedgeCo.Net wrote in an article about how the hedge-fund firm is fighting an involuntary bankruptcy petition filed by investors who “not only are trying to reclaim their cash, but expose some secrets in the process.”

headline: Debate Breaks Record For MSNBC
abstract: Tuesday’s duel between Democratic candidates Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama earned MSNBC the highest ratings in its 11-year history.

headline: Guild Board Member Predicts ‘Detonation Day’
abstract: Some decidedly mixed signals have been coming from union leaders to striking Writers Guild of America, West members for the last day.

headline: Fox May Be In Best Strike Position
abstract: The broadcast networks “have more than a hundred episodes of scripted series ready to roll out over the next few months,” the Associated Press reports. But few are fan favorites.

headline: Fading Prospects for a White Knight for Yahoo
abstract: If Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, is expecting a white knight to help him keep the company from being frog-marched down the aisle with Microsoft, he shouldn’t put his hopes on the private equity quarter, according to industry observers.

headline: Ex-Lehman Executive Plans Fund for Mortgage Trading
abstract: To many people, mortgage-backed bonds and securities are radioactive waste. But it appears that for some traders, they’re a potential gold mine.

headline: Ratings: CBS’s ‘Brother’ and ‘Jericho’ Tumble
abstract: One week after earning relatively mediocre ratings in their debuts, CBS’s “Big Brother” and the second season of “Jericho” saw their audiences shrink more than a million additional viewers on Tuesday.

headline: If Everyone’s Finger-Pointing, Who’s to Blame?
abstract: Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.

headline: Fidelity to Cough Up $8 Million to End Case Over Gifts
abstract: Days at Wimbledon. Nights at U2 concerts. Flights aboard the Concorde. And a dwarf to toss.

headline: Ze-gen Raises $2.5 Million from Pinnacle
abstract: Ze-gen, a company that has a process for converting municipal waste into electricity, has raised $2.5 million to fund construction of its first full-scale plant.

headline: A $299 Sony Blu-ray Player, but No Cheap Chinese Models
abstract: Sony expects prices to drop for its Blu-ray disc players from $399 to $299 by the end of the year and perhaps to $199 by the end of next year. To keep prices from crashing, the Blu-ray format is not being licensed to any manufacturers in China yet.

headline: Toll Daughter Won’t Pay
abstract: Robert Toll, the chief executive of Toll Brothers, the home builder, has complained that newspapers — he singled out The Times — are to blame for persuading customers to walk away from contracts to purchase homes.

headline: An Activist Tries a Soft Touch with Times Co.
abstract: “A spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down.”

headline: Bond Insurers Claim Conflict in Buffett’s Moody’s Link, Report Says
abstract: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett has apparently found himself on the receiving end of claims of conflict of interest in his latest foray into the troubled bond insurance industry.

headline: Meet Me in Ohio
abstract: Politicians and foreign manufacturers aren’t the only ones besieging Ohio these days. On Sunday, Connecticut’s United Technologies sent a “bear hug” letter to Ohio-based Diebold Industries. The letter proposed an acquisition of Diebold at a price of $40 a share and described a failed two-year courtship between the two companies.

headline: Entrepreneur Unveils Tourist Spacecraft
abstract: Burt Rutan took the cloak off of his new spacecraft on Wednesday.

headline: CNN’s Advantage in Español
abstract: In Texas, Hispanic voters may be the deciding factor in the contest between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. In its coverage of the voting patterns, CNN had a distinct advantage: a Spanish-language network named CNN en Español.

headline: Activists Gain 2 Seats on Times Board
abstract: An agreement struck by The New York Times Company with a pair of hedge funds that want to shake up the company marks the first time since the Times Company went public in 1967 that it has accepted directors nominated by outsiders.

headline: The Cost of Bear’s Crisis to Its Employees
abstract: Update: Bear Stearns has agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share. The firm’s shares closed at $30 on Friday, giving it a market value of $4.1 billion. For DealBook’s full coverage of the Bear Stearns crisis, go here.

headline: Constellation Uncorks Sales of 2 Brands
abstract: Constellation Brands, the world’s biggest wine company, is selling its Almaden and Inglenook wine brands and the Paul Masson winery in Madera, Calif., to the Wine Group for $134 million.

headline: Frontline, Silicon Valley’s Wireless Start-Up, Folds
abstract: Frontline Communications, which hoped to build a nationwide wireless data network with the backing of top Silicon Valley venture capitalists, has gone out of business. A payment of $128 million to proceed with its bidding in government spectrum auctions was due last week.

headline: Massachusetts Accuses Merrill of Fraud
abstract: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments, casting light on how Wall Street banks sold complex mortgage securities that are now plummeting in value as the housing slump deepens.

headline: Blackstone’s Mini-Buyout of Blackstone
abstract: The Blackstone Group is fond of investing in companies that it thinks aren’t getting a fair shake from the public markets. On Thursday, it seemed to find one: the Blackstone Group.

headline: Carlyle Unveils Wave of Promotions
abstract: The Carlyle Group has promoted 30 executives to senior positions in the company, eight to managing director – the most senior role below those of senior adviser, founder and chairman – and 22 to director.

headline: CIT Seeks to Raise Cash from Foreign Bank, Report Says
abstract: CIT Group is in talks with an overseas bank to raise funds for its lending business, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Showtime Plays Well on iTunes
abstract: NBC Universal’s spat with Apple’s iTunes over pricing issues has been well documented. But Showtime, a subsidiary of CBS Corporation, has found iTunes to be a good outlet for selling its shows. Last week Showtime shows accounted for six of the top ten television offerings on iTunes, measured by the number of purchases.

headline: Lehman Appoints New Head of Fixed Income
abstract: Lehman Brothers announced Tuesday that Andrew J. Morton will take over as its global head of fixed income, becoming the executive in charge of the investment bank’s biggest revenue generator.

headline: How Microsoft Could Go Hostile
abstract: Bear hug letters are an art form. They are designed to put an unwilling takeover target on notice that they are no longer safe, but to fall short of being blatantly hostile.

headline: Omeros Files for $115 Milion I.P.O.
abstract: A Biopharmaceutical company, Omeros, has filed to go public in a maximum $115 million offering.

headline: Drake Suspends Withdrawals From $3 Billion Fund
abstract: Drake Management suspended most redemptions from its largest hedge fund after losing 23.7 percent through November, Bloomberg News reported, citing a letter sent to investors of the New York-based firm.

headline: Fund Run by Ex-SAC Trader Said to Suffer 12% Loss
abstract: Sailfish Capital Partners, a credit hedge fund run by a former SAC Capital Management bond trader, Mark Fishman, recorded a loss of more than 12 percent for the first 51 weeks of last year and is understood to be suffering significant client redemptions, Financial News reported.

headline: Quadrangle to Manage Bloomberg’s Wealth
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg disclosed Tuesday that he has chosen the firm headed by his long-time friend, Steven Rattner, a financier who moves among New York’s power elite, to manage the investments of his billion dollar fortune.

headline: Northern Rock Investors Reject Hedge Fund Proposals
abstract: Shareholders in Northern Rock, the ailing British mortgage lender, voted at a special meeting Tuesday against proposals by two hedge funds that would have forced managers to seek shareholder approval for even small asset sales.

headline: Live from Germany: Super Return 2008
abstract: What a difference a year makes.

headline: Are Deals Getting More Pushback?
abstract: There are lots of reasons for the recent lull in merger activity. One of the less-obvious ones might be increased skepticism from boards, hedge funds and proxy advisory firms about the benefits of such deals, Compliance Week suggests.

headline: Want Want China’s $1 Billion I.P.O. Prices at Bottom of Range
abstract: Want Want China Holdings, China’s largest maker of rice cakes and flavored milk, priced its $1.05 billion Hong Kong share sale at the bottom of a proposed range, according to a sale document.

headline: When the Resistance Was Fading
abstract: I arrived in the Times’ Baghdad bureau on Sunday, Jan. 25, 2004, with a duffel bag, flak jacket and 12-cup muffin tin that someone had asked me to bring. Back then the bureau was a noisy frat-house like place with correspondents from across the planet living on top of each other and sharing bath soap. I was nervous, lonely, excited and overwhelmed, thrilled by the intensity of all the guns on the street and tanks rolling by and a bit unsettled by it — and the fact that I had now entered the world’s biggest story.

headline: Lessons in Democracy and Modesty
abstract: The world must be changing when on a World Economic Forum panel on geopolitics you have three Asians, two Europeans and just one American (even though that American was called Power — the Harvard professor Samantha Power).

headline: What Does It Cost to Get Into Davos?
abstract: Getting an invitation to the annual meeting at the World Economic Forum is considered an honor for most — but it sure doesn’t come cheap.

headline: In Second Installment, Hollywood Producer Wins the Lightning
abstract: In what amounts to a rerun of sorts, Hollywood producer Oren Koules is again on the verge of purchasing pro hockey’s Tampa Bay Lightning four months after the original deal he was a part of fell through.

headline: Gawker Media Gets Strung Out on Sci-Fi
abstract: Gawker Media adds a new science fiction blog to its staple of online media properties.

headline: Endwave Buys Out Wood River Stake
abstract: On Christmas Eve, Wood River Capital Management finally liquidated its 4.1 million shares of Endwave, a San Jose maker of radio frequency modules used in telelcommunication networks, bringing to a close one of the more bizarre episodes of hedge fund investment in Silicon Valley history.

headline: Classic Game Shows Have Viewers Playing ‘What’s My Vintage?’
abstract: A popular block of programs, in glorious black and white, has returned to the GSN cable network.

headline: Locking in Viewers to Watch the Commercials
abstract: Bill Carter reports in Monday’s Times:

headline: A Reshuffling in Merrill’s Wealth Management Ranks
abstract: From Jenny Anderson, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Among TV Judges, ‘Judy’ Is Renewed but ‘Hatchett’ Is Axed
abstract: “Judge Judy,” the longest-running and highest-rated courtroom show in syndication, earned a two-year renewal this week, which will extend its run through 2012.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.
