abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Worldwide PC Sales Could Still Grow by Double-Digits
abstract: While a further downturn could slow growth of PC sales to single digits, the industry is showing considerable strength across all segments from laptops to desktop replacements says a report from Gartner.

headline: Breaking the Rules and Admitting It
abstract: It is not often that a major international bank admits it is violating well-established accounting rules, but that is what Société Générale has done in accounting for the fraud that caused the bank to lose 6.4 billion euros – now worth about $9.7 billion – in January.

headline: Entertainment One Expected to Announce ThinkFilm Acquisition
abstract: Entertainment One is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying the Canadian assets of Toronto-based rival ThinkFilm, The Globe and Mail reported. The move would put the fast-rising company into the upper echelons of the film industry from bit player in less than a year.

headline: A Start-Up Says It Can Predict Others’ Fate
abstract: Is your start-up worthy of investment? Ask the venture investor in a box.

headline: 3i Pulls Away from Early-Stage Investments
abstract: 3i, the publicly listed British venture capital and buyouts shop, is moving away from investing in early-stage companies as part of a reorganization that will merge its venture business with its growth capital unit, says PE Hub’s Tom Allchorne.

headline: Bioheart Falls in First-Day Trading
abstract: Shares of Bioheart stumbled in their first day of trading Tuesday after the biotechnology company’s initial public offering priced below the expected range.

headline: Attaching An Asterisk To The TV Season
abstract: Advertisers would welcome the adoption of a year-round television season rather than the September-to-May schedule now followed by the broadcasters.

headline: U.S. Joins Countries Investigating Tax Evasion in Lichtenstein
abstract: Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

headline: Fortis Shares Surge After Assuaging Investor Concerns
abstract: Fortis, Belgium’s biggest financial-services company, rose the most in almost 5 years in Brussels trading after the bank eased concerns about possible writedowns on subprime mortgage assets and raising new capital.

headline: My Technology Training Program
abstract: Some tips for improving technology skills, for those who learn best by coaching.

headline: Writers Are ‘Really, Really, Really, Really Happy’ To Be Back
abstract: Returning to work on Wednesday, chatter among writers centered on how relieved everyone was that the strike was finally finished.

headline: Putting a ‘Buy’ on Blodget
abstract: Few tech-bubble analysts have received as much attention — and derision — as Henry Blodget, the one-time Merrill Lynch star analyst who, after being barred from the securities industry, refashioned himself as an industry commentator.

headline: Showdown Expected at UBS Shareholders Meeting
abstract: Switzerland’s troubled flagship bank, UBS, was expected to face a disturbed bunch of shareholders at its annual meeting on Wednesday.

headline: I.P.O. Cancellations Hit $21.4 Billion
abstract: Companies have shelved initial public offerings totaling $21.4 billion so far this year, almost double the value of new equity issuance, Thomson Financial data showed.

headline: A Wave of Information
abstract: The next twist in TVs might be the ability to navigate through on-screen menus with a wave of your hand. Look for them in hotel lobbies.

headline: A.D.S.: The Way Out
abstract: Is there still a way for Alliance Data Systems to be acquired by Blackstone Group?

headline: EADS Targets U.S. Acquisitions
abstract: EADS, currently battling opposition in Congress to a United States Air Force deal, wants to identify up to two acquisitions in the United States this year, according to Reuters, which cited an internal memo.

headline: A Treasure Chest of Good Jokes
abstract: Indeed, laughter is the best medicine and the dose is online.

headline: Carl Icahn, Blogger. Seriously.
abstract: For two decades, Carl C. Icahn has been among the most visible of rabble-rousing investors, garnering attention from the press for nearly every investment he makes. From TWA to Time Warner, he has been unafraid to step into the spotlight and attack companies, and sometimes take them over, in an attempt to shake them up.

headline: Grammys Reach Deal With Writers
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: NBC Will Show ‘Dateline’ Before ‘Globes’
abstract: NBC has confirmed that a two-hour edition of “Dateline NBC” will be shown before the Golden Globes press conference on Sunday.

headline: Bear’s Chairman Buys $26 Million Condo
abstract: Bear Stearns‘s stock may be hitting new 52-week lows, but the firm’s chairman just put the finishing touches on a high-flying real-estate deal.

headline: Are Today’s ‘Rogues’ Yesterday’s ‘Superstars’?
abstract: What’s with the flurry of rogue trading? In the last six months, there have been at least three big losses tied to unauthorized trades, with the latest coming from a wheat trader at MF Gloabl.

headline: Ambac Raises $1.5 Billion
abstract: The Ambac Financial Group, the bond insurer, said on Friday it had sold $1.5 billion of shares and convertibles, protecting the company from ratings cuts but not satisfying some analysts who had wanted the company to raise more.

headline: Is Marketing to Blame for Failed Vale-Xstrata Deal?
abstract: Following the breakdown of its efforts to buy Xsastra, Brazil’s Vale is blaming the scuttled $90 billion deal on marketing.

headline: Chief of eBay Is Expected to Retire
abstract: An era at eBay is about to end.

headline: Hedge Funds Still Pose Risk to Financial System, Report Says
abstract: Despite closer monitoring by regulators, hedge funds still pose significant risks to the financial system, a government report said Monday.

headline: Moderator and a Panelist Ousted at ‘Fox News Watch’
abstract: “Fox News Watch,” one of two weekly television shows that assess the conduct of the national news media, has fired its longtime moderator and let go one of its more liberal panelists.

headline: Hedge Funds Hit by Northern Rock Decision
abstract: RAB Capital and SRM Global, two of Europe’s best known hedge funds, are likely to be the biggest losers following the British government’s decision to nationalize the troubled lender Northern Rock.

headline: Sears May Still Have Restoration in Its Sights
abstract: Sears Holdings is apparently not giving up on Restoration Hardware, even though the home furnishings retailer rejected a revised offer from Sears on the last day of Restoration’s go-shop period.

headline: Delta’s Anderson to Waive Compensation in Merger
abstract: Delta Air Lines‘ chief executive, Richard Anderson, has told the airline’s board he will waive compensation in the event of a merger.

headline: More Good News: ‘Krod Mandoon’ Will Start Shooting Soon
abstract: MRC, one of the studios that reached an interim agreement with the Writers Guild of America before the broader strike was settled, has just announced its first slate of television projects with broadcast and cable companies.

headline: Ratings: On Fox, ‘Idol’ Wins And Gives A Long Echo To ‘Lyrics’
abstract: The results edition of “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday while giving a considerable boost to the network’s other singing competition, “Don’t Forget the Lyrics.”

headline: Tips on Post Vacation Re-entry
abstract: Six tips for easing re-entry after a vacation.

headline: A Parting Shot at the S.E.C.
abstract: Kayla Gillan, a founding member of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, had to leave the board because her term was up. Now she has sent out a blast at the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the way it handled the efforts to make Section 404 of the Sarbanes Oxley Act more friendly to companies.

headline: Coca-Cola Says It Won’t Rely on Deals for Growth
abstract: Coca-Cola said on Friday it would continue to make acquisitions, but they were not necessary for the company to meet its long-term growth objectives, Reuters reported.

headline: Delta Pilots Reject Arbitration in Union Dispute
abstract: Delta Air Lines‘ pilots union rejected Wednesday the idea of submitting to arbitration with its counterpart at Northwest Airlines to break their impasse over integrating seniority lists as part of a possible combination of the carriers.

headline: Another Media Exec Leaves Yahoo
abstract: Vince Broady, a senior vice president in Yahoo’s media group, is the latest executive to leave the company as his duties are scaled back.

headline: Dechert Law Firm to Lay Off 13 Associates
abstract: As investment banks cope with the growing economic slowdown, so too are big law firms. According to the Legal Intelligencer, the latest to pare down its associates roster is Dechert.

headline: Putting ‘The’ Back in ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: The writing staff of “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” and the companion program “The Colbert Report” returned to work on Wednesday morning.

headline: German Bank Gets $7.2 Billion Bailout
abstract: WestLB, a state-owned German bank, said Friday that it would reduce its work force by 25 percent and receive 5 billion euros ($7.2 billion) from its owners to cover losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market.

headline: Goldman Sachs, the Unstoppable Deal Machine
abstract: The landscape for mergers and buyouts shifted drastically last summer, but one theme remained constant in 2007: If there was a big deal, Goldman Sachs was probably involved. As in previous years, the firm was the top adviser on mergers as measured by dollar volume, both globally and for deals with targets in the United States. It also ranked near the top of the heap as a participant, through its private equity arm, in leveraged buyouts.

headline: Spectrum Auctions: Billion Dollar Leapfrog
abstract: Bidding hit $6.1 billion in the federal government’s auction of wireless spectrum. Two bidders appear to be bidding for the most valuable national license. The block of frequencies that is meant to be operated in conjunction with public safety agencies continues to languish with no new bids.

headline: The Rubicon Project Snags $15 Million
abstract: The Rubicon Project, which essentially acts as a middleman between Web sites and ad networks, announced Monday that it raised an additional $15 million in funding, bringing its total financing to $21 million.

headline: Will Yahoo Bid Put AOL in Play?
abstract: With its potential to redraw the battle lines in the struggle for Internet domination, Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo may end up putting other companies in play. High on the list of potential targets is AOL, which is the middle of a turnaround effort by its parent company, Time Warner.

headline: The New Online Stock: Web Site Names
abstract: The notion that names of Web sites can be valuable, cash-generating assets just like stocks, bonds or property – appears to be gaining a broader acceptance that veteran domainers, as they call themselves, are not accustomed to and may not be totally comfortable with.

headline: Verizon Rejects Hollywood’s Call to Aid Piracy Fight
abstract: Unlike AT&T, Verizon won’t monitor its network to block unauthorized copying. That would violate customer privacy, it says, and would be expensive too.

headline: G.M. Voices Confidence in Lending Business
abstract: Despite big losses at the auto and mortgage lender GMAC, General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled financing business.

headline: Bits Debate: Mixing It Up Over Remixes and Fair Use
abstract: How much should people be able to quote from, remix, and reuse copyrighted material? That is the topic for today’s debate between between Rick Cotton, of NBC Universal, and Columbia law professor Tim Wu. Not surprisingly, they disagree.

headline: A Tale of Two Hostiles
abstract: Electronic Arts‘s unsolicited takeover offer for Take-Two Interactive is unfolding fast: Take-Two, which makes the popular Grand Theft Auto video-game series, has responded to Sunday’s public bid by Electronic Arts with the flurry of activity that usually follows these kinds of things: golden parachutes, rapid strategic maneuvers of questionable shareholder value and general hostility.

headline: G.M. Building Offers Said to Top $3 Billion
abstract: The General Motors Building is well on its way to becoming, in the words of The New York Sun, “the priciest property in America.”

headline: Last.FM Has a First With Streaming Music
abstract: Last.FM, the free online radio service owned by CBS, will let users listen to any of 3.5 million songs on demand, paid for with advertising. The key limit: each user can only listen to each song 3 times.

headline: FusionOne Picks Up $6 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: FusionOne, which creates applications and services for mobile devices, has raised $6 million in a Series A-1 preferred stock round for its mobile content backup services.

headline: BlackRock Plans a Listed Fund of Hedge Funds
abstract: BlackRock, the money manager, said on Tuesday it is planning a London-listed closed-end fund of hedge funds that will offer exposure to its $11 billion (5.5 billion pound) Appreciation Strategy.

headline: McLaren breakdown on the way to ball
abstract: Just a quick note on Thursday in Malaysia before we move into overdrive tomorrow. A couple of things got inversed in the move of the F1 circus from Australia to Malaysia within the same week. First, it was Australia that proved to have the Malaysian weather, where Malaysia now has weather we should have encountered in Australia. At practically 38 degrees Celsius everyday in Australia and with no rain and only sun, you’d have thought it was the Kuala Lumpur race. Here in Malaysia today, by contrast, it was maybe only 28 degrees Celsius – a veritable refrigerator by comparison – and there was rain yesterday and today. Rain is in the forecast at the track for every day this race weekend.

headline: No Word from CBS on Captive Journalist
abstract: Amid the coverage of the five-year anniversary coverage of the Iraq war, one story has gone largely overlooked: an anonymous CBS News journalist is still being held captive somewhere in the country.

headline: Critics Have Their Say
abstract: This year’s Super Return conference seemed smaller and more subdued than the one last year in Frankfurt.

headline: Landry’s C.E.O. Bids to Take Chain Private
abstract: Tilman Fertitta, who built Landry’s into a nationwide restaurant chain propelled through nearly two decades of acquisitions, wants to make one more purchase – the company he runs. As chairman, president and chief executive of the restaurant, hotel and casino company, he already owns 39 percent of it.

headline: Writers’ Strike Makes Happy Hunting for Some Start-Ups
abstract: Few online entertainment ventures today make money. Yet, says The Los Angeles Times, that has not deterred striking Hollywood writers, eager to bypass the studio system, from forming start-ups to distribute their work on the Web.

headline: TheStreet Sets Up Shop on MainStreet.com
abstract: After getting a $55 million injection from Technology Crossover Ventures last November, TheStreet.com is using some of that cash to roll out mainstreet.com today in a bid to expand beyond its pure-play financial focus and add celebrity news with a personal finance angle.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Pernod Buys Lillet
abstract: The French wines and spirits group Pernod Ricard said on Thursday it would acquire a small French aperitif maker, Lillet, and reaffirmed its interest in Absolut vodka despite the continuing turbulence in credit markets.

headline: A Big Winner in Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
abstract: Now that Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo has put the Internet company in play, shareholders will reap a windfall. But perhaps none will be more relieved than Bill Miller, the chief investment officer of Legg Mason Capital Management.

headline: Scanning Your Money to the Bank
abstract: New software being offered to banks will allow consumers to to deposit checks by scanning them at home and sending them electronically to your bank. No need to visit a branch or even an ATM.

headline: Tamping Down SocGen Chatter, HSBC Is Expected to Sell 400 Banks
abstract: HSBC, the biggest bank in Europe, plans to put about half of its 800 French consumer branches up for sale as it focuses on expanding in Asia and other emerging markets, according to press reports.

headline: Eurotunnel Begins $1.2 Billion Cash Call
abstract: Eurotunnelhas bucked the credit crunch to secure an initial 800 million euros ($1.2 billion) of fresh funding that will be used to cut financing costs, preserve shareholders’ equity and hasten the payment of a first dividend.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Loss on I.P.O. Costs
abstract: Och-Ziff Capital Management posted a net loss in its first quarterly earnings report as a public company, mostly because of the costs of listing its shares in November. But the hedge-fund group reported higher-than-expected distributable earnings, the number that analysts look at most closely, Reuters said.

headline: Buyouts Create Jobs, Industry Study Says
abstract: A new study funded by the private equity industry says that buyouts have resulted in significant gains in employment over the past several years.

headline: Pondering Microsoft’s Options
abstract: Yahoo‘s announcement Wednesday that it would delay its nominations deadline poses an interesting question for Microsoft. Does Microsoft wait until the announcement of the meeting date and the nominations deadline to start a proxy contest or does it attempt to nudge Yahoo by nominating directors beforehand (i.e., now)?

headline: Morgan’s Mack Under Pressure Over Risk
abstract: John J. Mack stood before his board and shareholders at Morgan Stanley‘s 2007 annual meeting and struck an aggressive tone. Coming off a year of record profits fueled by using the firm’s capital to take some highly lucrative risks – particularly by diving deeply into subprime mortgages, leveraged loans and complex derivatives – Mr. Mack had much to celebrate.

headline: Ailing Fortunoff Attracts a Suitor
abstract: One of the most storied names in New York retailing plans to bail out another.

headline: Cohen Pledges $50 Million to Children’s Hospital
abstract: Despite fears of recession looming, the hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen doesn’t seem to be hurting too much.

headline: Yahoo and the Art of the Rejection
abstract: Microsoft has already shown its skill in crafting a “bear hug” letter. Now Yahoo has tried its hand at the bid-rejection letter, and the result is remarkably, well, nice — especially when compared with the much harsher rejections that some other companies have issued in recent years.

headline: Amazon’s S3 Cloud Has a Dark Lining for Start-Ups
abstract: Amazon’s S3 online storage service was down for several hours, taking startups and other customers out with it.

headline: Approval of DoubleClick Deal May Help Microsoft
abstract: A decision Tuesday by regulators in Europe to approve Google‘s acquisition of DoubleClick could strengthen Microsoft‘s argument that it should be allowed to buy Yahoo, were it to succeed in its battle with that company, analysts said.

headline: Feds Share Coupons to Help TV Transition
abstract: “Millions of $40 government coupons become available Tuesday to help low-tech television owners buy special converter boxes for older TVs that might not work after the Feb. 18, 2009 switch to digital broadcasting,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Spitzer’s Woes Cast Shadow on Troubled Bond Insurers
abstract: Wall Street may have cheered when news hit that New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer, once dubbed the Sheriff of Wall Street for his crusade against their transgressions, was considering resignation after being linked to a prostitution ring.

headline: Judge Allows Unusual Auction for MAXjet Airways
abstract: A bankruptcy judge has authorized MAXjet Airways, the all-business-class airline, to auction itself under conditions that have raised the concerns of the federal official monitoring the case.

headline: Death of the Corporation
abstract: The individual corporation can’t go it alone. If there is a theme of this year’s C.E.S., it is cooperation.

headline: Xerox to Pay $670 Million to Settle Securities Case
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said Thursday it would pay $670 million to settle a securities lawsuit from 2000, without admitting wrongdoing.

headline: Giant Write-Down Is Seen for Merrill
abstract: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate, prompting the firm to raise additional capital from an outside investor.

headline: Legg Mason Sells Notes to K.K.R.
abstract: The asset management firm Legg Mason said on Monday that it had sold $1.25 billion in convertible senior notes to an affiliate of the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Ex-NBC Chair to Join Lee Equity Partners
abstract: Bob Wright is jumping from G.E. to P.E.

headline: Investors Take Ellen Tracy Off Liz Claiborne’s Rack
abstract: A group of investors have agreed to try on Ellen Tracy for size.

headline: Roche Wins Ventana With Sweetened $3.4 Billion Bid
abstract: Roche Holding has overcome Ventana Medical Systems‘ resistance to its takeover bid by raising the price, acquiring the diagnostics maker for $3.4 billion to expand its cancer testing business.

headline: When Elbows Rub, Can Deals Be Far Behind?
abstract: “A merger is like two people falling in love,” Klaus Schwab, the founder of the World Economic Forum, was once quoted as saying in Wired magazine. “Sometimes we are the place where the people first meet. Sometimes we are the place where they do the proposing. And sometimes we just provide the beautiful sunset.”

headline: New Executive Post Heightens I.P.O. Chatter at Citadel
abstract: As chatter that the Citadel Investment Group, the powerful hedge fund run by Kenneth C. Griffin, may be planning an initial public offering grows, the latest inside move has added to the speculation.

headline: Investors Pour $31.5 Million into Intrinsity
abstract: Intrinsity, a semiconductor design start-up, said Monday that it had raised $31.5 million in a fifth round of venture capital, a strong endorsement of the company’s three-year transition into a “chipless” company devoted solely to licensing its intellectual property.

headline: EMC Acquisition Shows It Wants to Be a Cloudmaster
abstract: From our colleague Steve Lohr at Bits:

headline: Private Firms Said to Employ Marketing Blitz
abstract: Private equity funds are responding to harder times by adopting a financial services equivalent of the marketing world’s attack advertisements and peppering investor presentations with comparisons that are meant to differentiate – and elevate – themselves from their competitors, The Financial Times reported.

headline: JPMorgan’s Expanding Footprint
abstract: DealBook maps out JPMorgan’s footprint in the wake of the Bear Stearns deal.

headline: Enterprise Search Deals: More to Come?
abstract: Microsoft‘s recent acquisition of FAST Search & Transfer is one of the latest and largest deals in the enterprise search space.

headline: ABN Amro Posts $2.36 Billion Write-Down
abstract: The Dutch bank ABN Amro said on Thursday it had made a 1.56 billion euro ($2.36 billion) writedown in its global markets business in its last results before being split between three buyers.

headline: ‘I Wrote Something Today’
abstract: Video

headline: China Eastern Shareholders Reject Singapore Bid
abstract: Shareholders in China’s third-largest airline rejected a bid by Singapore Airlines to buy a minority stake Tuesday after a rival Chinese carrier offered more money in an unusual takeover battle involving two state-owned companies.

headline: Now the Tunes Are Really Electric
abstract: What does getting hit by a Taser feel like? How about a Taser that also plays John Mayer?

headline: Lampert Hits Road Blocks in Search for Sears New C.E.O.
abstract: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge-fund investor mired in turning around Sears Holdings, has been looking for a chief executive to run the retail giant since last fall, a longer time period than publicly acknowledged, according to The Chicago Tribune.

headline: Milberg Case Alters Class Action Landscape
abstract: As the famed class-action lawyer William S. Lerach steps before a federal judge in Los Angeles on Monday to learn his sentence in a wide-ranging fraud and conspiracy probe, his misdeeds and those of his former colleagues might be helping to alter the way securities law is practiced, according to The Los Angeles Times.

headline: YouTube On the Go
abstract: YouTube expands its mobile site to make the experience of watching videos on the go more like it is on the PC.

headline: Alliance Data Drops Lawsuit Against Blackstone
abstract: Alliance Data Systems on Friday dropped its lawsuit against its would-be buyer, the Blackstone Group, leaving open a path to settlement talks. Alliance Data, a credit card services provider, filed a motion to dismiss its case in Delaware’s Court of Chancery.

headline: Lehman Brothers to Cut 200 Jobs, Report Says
abstract: Lehman Brothers is cutting 200 jobs, equivalent to 10 percent of its investment banking staff, CNBC television reported on Thursday.

headline: The Complexities Behind JPMorgan’s $10 Bear Offer
abstract: The decision by James Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, to raise his bank’s bid for Bear Stearns from $2 a share to $10 dollars a share illustrates the deep complexity and political sensitivity of a deal with participants who reached into the highest corners of Washington, from the Treasury to the Federal Reserve System, according to The New York Times.

headline: BBC Said to Mull Private Equity Partnerhsip
abstract: The BBC‘s commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, is looking to go into partnership with private equity firms in a bid to expand its acquisition muscle beyond its 350 million pounds ($681 million) borrowing limit, according to The Guardian.

headline: Loss Narrows at Sirius as It Awaits Ruling on Merger
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio reported a narrower loss on Tuesday as it awaits regulatory action on its plans to combine with a rival, XM Satellite Radio Holdings.

headline: Congressman May Take Hedge Fund Lobbying Post
abstract: The $2 trillion hedge fund industry’s main lobbying group was talking with a United States Representative, Richard Baker, about possibly naming him as its president, a spokeswoman for the lawmaker told Reuters Monday.

headline: Sundance Channel May Be for Sale
abstract: The Sundance Channel, a joint venture of NBC Universal, CBS and Robert Redford, is being put up for sale, a media analyst said Wednesday.

headline: Bain Says It Has Terminated 3Com Deal
abstract: 3Com said Wednesday that it would still hold a meeting Friday for shareholders to vote on a $2.2 billion takeover by Bain Capital, despite the continued inability to strike a revised deal that would be approved by federal regulators.

headline: Microsoft Loses Its In-House Yahoo Executive
abstract: Joanne Bradford, the Microsoft executive in charged of running the company’s MSN portal, has quit to join a Los Angeles advertising company.

headline: Leno Presents Ten Minute Monologue
abstract: On his first night back on “The Tonight Show,” Jay Leno “offered a monologue that included jokes he said he had crafted beforehand. Whether that violated rules of the striking Writers Guild of America — to which Leno belongs — was not immediately clear,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: First Calgary Board Members Resign Amid Activist Campaign
abstract: Three of First Calgary Petroleums‘s board members resigned Sunday amid the Canadian energy company efforts to beat back a dissident shareholder motion to remove its chief executive officer over the development of a natural gas field in Algeria.

headline: Strike: Writers Pull Reality, Animation Off the Table
abstract: The Writers Guild of America has decided to withdraw its proposals relating to reality show and animation writers, removing a major impediment to a potential settlement between the guild and the alliance of major Hollywood studios.

headline: Super Tuesday: Calling California, Monitoring Missouri, Counting Delegates
abstract: “California is a magical place for politicians,” Jeff Greenfield, the chief political correspondent on CBS, said, minutes before the polls closed in the most populous state up for grabs on Super Tuesday.

headline: Despite Strike, Oscar Organizers Are Optimistic
abstract: The Oscar nominations are out, “one of the biggest questions about this year’s Oscar race — how a continuing writers strike will affect the ceremony — went unanswered,” Brooks Barnes notes.

headline: Brazil’s Vale Confirms Talks to Merge With Xstrata
abstract: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the world’s largest producer of iron ore, said on Monday that it was in talks with a rival, Xstrata, about a merger.

headline: SRM Global Said to Be Down 30%
abstract: SRM Global, the British hedge fund headed by a former star trader atUBS, Jon Wood, may have ratcheted up its profile by opposing deals for the troubled British lender Northern Rock and a United States counterpart, Countrywide Financial, but the investments haven’t done its balance sheet any favors.

headline: Trading Retirement for Something Else
abstract: An interview with Marc Freedman, who seeks to define what occurs in the years formerly known as retirement.

headline: Deeya Energy Fires Up $15 Million Round
abstract: Deeya Energy, which makes large flow batteries to provide backup power to industrial plants, raised $15 million in a second round of financing, according to Venture Wire.

headline: Lies, Damn Lies, and Swaps
abstract: It looks like both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Internal Revenue Service should be looking at what might be called the fiction of equity swaps.

headline: CNet to Appeal Delaware Ruling
abstract: CNet Networks said Monday afternoon that it would appeal a Delaware court ruling allowing a hedge fund to nominate seven directors to its board.

headline: GO Capital Halts Fund Redemptions
abstract: GO Capital Asset Management temporarily halted redemptions from its Global Opportunities Fund, in what Bloomberg News said was “at least the seventh hedge fund in the past month forced to take steps to protect itself from market fluctuations.”

headline: Merrill Won’t Sell Bloomberg, BlackRock Stakes
abstract: Even before Merrill Lynch announced the worst quarterly loss in its history on Thursday, the firm had already lined up more than $12 billion in fresh capital from outside investors. Depending on whether the securities firm has cleared out all of its subprime-related detritus and how the markets fare, the firm may have to seek yet more financing.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: A Very Popular ‘Raisin’
abstract: ABC’s Monday night broadcast of “A Raisin In the Sun,” starring Sean Combs and Phylicia Rashad, lifted the network to No. 1 in the night’s ratings.

headline: Apax Said to Cool on Reed Unit
abstract: Apax, the British buyout shop, has cooled its interest in the 1.25 billion pounds auction for Reed Business Information, the publisher, The Independent reported.

headline: Visa Offering Could Set U.S. Record
abstract: Behold the power of plastic: Visa said Monday that its highly anticipated stock sale could raise nearly $18.8 billion, which would make it the largest initial public offering in United States history. In an updated regulatory filing, the credit-card giant said it would sell as many as 446.6 million shares for an expected $37 to $42 per share.

headline: Yahoo’s Purchase of Maven Adds Complexity
abstract: Yahoo’s purchase of Maven Networks may help it expand in the video advertising business. But the deal adds complexity to a company at the same time that it is trying to simplify.

headline: The Web? The Weather Channel Decides To Do Something About It
abstract: For most television companies, digital revenue is still a small sliver of overall revenue. But the forecast is different for The Weather Channel. Its Web site represented 33 percent of its advertising revenue in 2006, 40 percent in 2007, and will edge close to 50 percent this year, executives say.

headline: Seeing Signs of ‘Systemic Failure’
abstract: “This is not a normal crisis,” George Soros, the hedge fund pioneer turned philosopher, said today to a group of reporters he had invited to lunch at the World Economic Forum. “It is the end of an era.”

headline: Do Resets No Longer Matter?
abstract: Has the Fed solved the mortgage reset problem?

headline: A High Price for Countrywide Deal’s Failure
abstract: The mortgage lender Countrywide Financial may have to pay Bank of America a fee of $160 million if a deal to buy it falls through, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

headline: CNet and the Future of Poison Pills
abstract: Late Friday evening, CNet announced that its board of directors had adopted a shareholder rights plan, commonly known as a poison pill.

headline: In Debate Ratings, Democrats Trump Republicans
abstract: The first broadcast network debates of the presidential election cycle were also the most popular to date, as ABC’s back-to-back debates drew an average of 8.36 million viewers between 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. Saturday.

headline: Fujifilm to Bid for Toyama Chemical
abstract: Fujifilm Holdings, the digital camera and medical equipment maker, said it would take control of Toyama Chemical for up to 155 billion yen ($1.45 billion) to gain a foothold in the pharmaceuticals market.

headline: Could Egypt’s Citadel Make a Tasty Target?
abstract: The announcement Wednesday that a Cairo-based private equity firm, Citadel Capital, is preparing to go public had Breakingviews wondering if an even-bigger private equity shop looking for a regional presence might swoop in and pre-empt an I.P.O.

headline: What Created This Monster?
abstract: Bill Gross of Pimco is no stranger to market crises. But this new meltdown is different from the others, the famed bond manager tells The New York Times as part of a long examination of how we arrived at this point.

headline: Valero to Sell Refineries
abstract: The refining company Valero Energy of Texas said on Tuesday it is considering selling nearly a third of its North American refineries amid an economic slowdown in the United States that is crimping fuel demand.

headline: Disney to Offer Some Vintage Shows Online
abstract: Bloomberg reports:

headline: A Farewell to Specific Performance
abstract: Private equity is changing – but not in the way market observers would have predicted.

headline: AOL Brings Out the Penguins to Explain Ad Targeting
abstract: AOL wants to explain online ad targeting to consumers–with a penguin.

headline: Bank Moves to Withdraw Its Suit Against Wikileaks Site
abstract: A Swiss bank asked a federal judge to dismiss a lawsuit it had filed against a Web site that it claimed had displayed stolen documents with confidential information about the accounts of its clients.

headline: Once Plentiful, Activists Are a Rare Breed at Davos
abstract: There was a time in the 1990s that Davos had little time for what was then called – it seems so quaint a label now – the anti-globalization movement. Protests prompted a security lockdown, and at times managed to shut down parts of the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum.

headline: Ratings: Huckabee, Obama and…Trump?
abstract: With the Iowa caucus returns on cable and Orange Bowl college football coverage on Fox, NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” still managed to earn Thursday night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49.

headline: It’s Official: Yahoo Rejects Microsoft Bid
abstract: Over to you, Microsoft.

headline: ’60 Minutes’ Lands Musharraf Interview
abstract: After a week of prodding and persuading, Lara Logan, the chief foreign correspondent for CBS News, has secured an exclusive interview with Pervez Musharraf, the embattled Pakistani president who has come under intense criticism since Benazir Butto died during a suicide attack on Dec. 27.

headline: Och-Ziff Fund Bounces Back (But Not Its Stock)
abstract: Choppy markets, plus some other problems, are wreaking havoc with hedge funds — and denting their reputations as the heavyweights of high finance. Banks have reportedly seized the assets of Peloton Partners, a London-based firm whose bets on mortgage-backed securities went bad. Sailfish Capital Partners, also stung by the credit markets, decided last month to shut down. Accounting problems recently forced D.B. Zwirn to close two of its largest funds.

headline: HBO’s Patch of “Bad Road”
abstract: When you are the power couple of Harry Thomason and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason — known for “Designing Women,” political connections to the Clintons, and so very much more — you do not necessarily take the cancellation of your new series by HBO lying down.

headline: HBO’s Strategy: Sample ‘In Treatment’ Online, Then Watch It On TV
abstract: HBO executives knew the risks they were taking when they scheduled the new series “In Treatment” to run five nights a week for nine consecutive weeks.

headline: Spanish Energy Upstart Plans $1 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Eolia Renovables de Inversiones, an independent wind and solar power company that is taking on Spain’s national utility giants, is scheduled to go public on the Madrid exchange this year with a $1 billion valuation.

headline: 2008: The Year of the Big Airline Merger?
abstract: It is one of the oldest stories on Wall Street: the idea that big mergers will sweep across the United States airline industry, reshaping a business that is notoriously prone to sharp downturns. And so far, it has largely been a piece of fiction.

headline: China’s CNOOC in Talks for Independent Refineries
abstract: China National Offshore Oil Corporation, the parent of CNOOC, said it is in talks to acquire several independent refineries in eastern China’s Shandong province.

headline: Accounting for Emeril’s $20 Million Kicker
abstract: There’s a meaty accounting lesson in the details of Martha Stewart’s recent deal with Emeril Lagasse, the celebrity chef.

headline: Fraud Trial Focuses on Insurance Giants
abstract: The reputations of two business titans – Warren E. Buffett and Maurice R. Greenberg – came under attack on Monday as the latest corporate corruption trial got under way in federal district court here.

headline: Warburg Takes Lifecore Private in $239 Million Deal
abstract: Warburg Pincus has signed a deal to take Lifecore Biomedical, a medical device maker, private in a $239 million buyout.

headline: I.B.M. Acquires Israeli Data Storage Company
abstract: I.B.M. bought an Israeli data-storage provider, XIV, to meet growing demand for digital archiving. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Bally Fitness Settles S.E.C. Fraud Charges
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil lawsuit against Bally Total Fitness Holding, alleging the Chicago health-club chain violated securities law — and misled investors — by issuing financial reports that fraudulently misrepresented Bally’s financial condition during the years from 1997 to 2003.

headline: Possible Proxy Fight Puts Yahoo Board in Focus
abstract: Ronald W. Burkle may want to watch his back.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Gains a Wider Audience
abstract: An edited version of the show “Dexter,” about a serial killer, earned 8.1 million viewers on CBS Sunday night — many more than had ever seen the series in its original home, the pay-TV channel Showtime.

headline: CBS Radio Plays Tortoise to AOL Music’s Hare
abstract: CBS, after a decade, is deciding to get serious about Internet radio. It is investing in technology, new programs, and a distribution deal with AOL.

headline: Time Warner: Download Too Much and You Might Pay $30 a Movie
abstract: Time Warner Cable plans to test a new price plan that would limit how much customers can download. Those who go over the limits might end up paying $4 to $30 to watch a high-definition movie.

headline: Professor Muller’s Ingenious iPhone Feature Workaround
abstract: A reader’s tip on how to make your iPhone vibrate and then ring.

headline: Study Says Private Equity Isn’t Big Job Killer
abstract: Among the world’s private equity kings and policy makers, the issue of whether buyouts create jobs or result in more layoffs has always been the $100 billion question.

headline: Spielberg Gets Spooky With Social Networking Site, Report Says
abstract: Steven Spielberg is preparing to introduce a new social network for people interested in sharing paranormal and extraterrestrial experiences, TechCrunch reported.

headline: HD DVD Owners, Some Stores Want to Make Amends
abstract: To assuage the feelings of the 200,000 customers who purchased HD DVD players from a Best Buy store, the company will announce Wednesday that it is giving each buyer a $50 gift card.

headline: A Break for Freddie and Fannie
abstract: With the blessing of the Bush administration, the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, eased a major restriction on the companies on Wednesday in an effort to unfreeze credit markets and stabilize housing prices.

headline: Kodak Knows a Little About Dying Business Models
abstract: “Microzoning” — printing several versions of a newspaper in the same city, each with ads aimed at a specific neighborhood promises to yield increased sales of Kodak’s high-speed production printers — particularly of the 1,600 page-per-minute printer Kodak is about to introduce.

headline: What Would it Be Like to …?
abstract: Ever wonder what it would be like to do something else for a living?

headline: Carlyle Capital on the Verge of Collapse
abstract: Carlyle Capital, an affiliate of the Carlyle Group, the private equity investor, said on Thursday it was in default on margin calls of more than $400 million and said its lenders would likely take possession of its remaining assets.

headline: The Unseen Merger Boom: SPACs
abstract: The rampant predictions of a 2008 decline in mergers and acquisitions are missing one coming takeover boom: acquisitions by special purpose acquisition companies or SPACs. SPACS are companies organized to purchase one or more operating businesses. The equity funds to acquire these businesses come from their initial public offering. Think private equity for the masses.

headline: Sears to Replace C.E.O.
abstract: As billionaire Edward S. Lampert struggles to turn around the Sears Holdings Corporation, the company announced Monday that said its chief executive, Aylwin Lewis, will leave the company on Saturday.

headline: Etsy Brings Out Accel’s Crafty Side
abstract: Etsy, a site for buying and selling hand-made crafts, has raised $27 million in a round led by Accel Partners, with Accel’s Jim Breyer joining the company’s board of directors.

headline: Rent Anything … From the Family Down the Street
abstract: Several companies are trying to revive the idea of an online rental marketplace, where you can rent anything from cars to pool cleaning equipment, perhaps from the family down the street.

headline: Tracking the World’s Appetite for Innovation
abstract: In its quest for what it calls “new metrics for the knowledge economy,” a nonprofit research group has come up with an index of global innovation confidence.

headline: What Now for Societe Generale?
abstract: In a country where the hurly-burly of market capitalism has long been viewed with suspicion, Société Générale was a rare Gallic success story – the Chanel or Château Margaux of French banking.

headline: Podcast: Election Veto Exposes a Shiite Rift
abstract: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: Quad-C Said to Buy Sportswear Firm
abstract: Quad-C Management is buying the Augusta Sportswear Group from Linsalata Capital Partners in a secondary buyout valued at $405 million to $450 million, The Deal reported.

headline: Where Will the Children Work?
abstract: Will our children all become Davos Men (or Women)?

headline: Exchange Official Is Charged With Insider Trading
abstract: The vice chairman of the International Securities Exchange, an options and stock exchange in New York, was charged with insider trading on Thursday, accused of leaking confidential information about the $2.8 billion takeover of the market last year.

headline: The Technological Divide Between Parents and Their Children
abstract: Children use the cellphone differently than adults. But sometimes the adults have the acronyms that the children don’t have.

headline: F1 and the French municipal elections
abstract: Le Figaro, the French national daily newspaper, today had a page two story about the role of Formula One in the municipal election campaign in Versailles. With the headline, “Formula 1 in pole position in the campaign,” the article outlines how the battle to stage the French Grand Prix in Versailles is being used by politicians to promote their candidacy.

headline: UBS Takes a $14 Billion Hit
abstract: UBS, the largest Swiss bank, said Wednesday that it would write off $14 billion in exposure to the troubled U.S. housing market and post a net loss for 2007.

headline: Ex-Georgeson Proxy Solicitors Start New Firm
abstract: Two former senior managing directors from Georgeson, a major proxy-solicitation firm, have launched their own firm, Okapi Partners. The two executives, Bruce Goldfarb and Patrick McHugh, told Reuters that demand for proxy services is strong, especially as corporate transactions become more complex.

headline: No Remorse From John Snow
abstract: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Sallie Mae Settles Suit Over Failed Buyout
abstract: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement on Sunday over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting that had cast a cloud over the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Bloomberg Moves to a New Channel in NYC
abstract: Bloomberg TV is moving to a new and more desirable channel position in the nation’s financial capital, where it will be closer to its two chief rivals.

headline: The Choice Facing Comcast’s Roberts
abstract: It has been four years since Comcast, the cable company, abandoned its hostile bid for Walt Disney. So when is Brian L. Roberts, Comcast’s chief executive, going to start striking deals again?

headline: A Sweeping New Lineup at TNT
abstract: TNT wants to be known for more than “Law & Order” repeats.

headline: L.A. Times Editor Fires Parting Shot at Tribune
abstract: It’s been only a month since Samuel Zell took control of Tribune and already he’s facing the fallout from rebellion in the ranks.

headline: Judge Sides With Kucinich In MSNBC Debate Flap
abstract: A Nevada judge has ordered MSNBC to include Representative Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic presidential candidate, in Tuesday night’s debate in Nevada, the Associated Press reports. MSNBC plans to appeal.

headline: Detroit Misery
abstract: A tidbit from the producer price index report today:The 2007 change in producer prices for motor vehicles and equipment was zero. Detroit could not get any increase in what it charges to dealers.But it could be worse. Since the end of 1995 — 12 years — the producer price index for motor vehicles is down 1.6 percent.It’s no wonder that the auto industry is suffering, or that Detroit home prices are so weak.

headline: False Resume Gets Chef Cut From Food Network
abstract: After rising to culinary stardom preparing impossible meals on his Food Network series, Robert Irvine has met an obstacle his kitchen prowess couldn’t overcome — an embellished resume.

headline: Sorting the Mortgage Victims From Those Who Volunteered
abstract: Over the last two decades, few industries have lobbied more ferociously or effectively than banks to get the government out of its business and to obtain freer rein for “financial innovation.”

headline: Apax Pulls Tommy Hilfiger I.P.O.
abstract: Stock market turbulence claimed its most fashion-conscious victim on Thursday as Tommy Hilfiger‘s private equity owners decided to postpone a planned $2 billion initial public offering of the designer clothing brand indefinitely.

headline: F1 Season Preview
abstract: The IHT F1 season preview is now up on the site, as is the first installment of the IHT Global Sports Forum – F1 edition! Bookmark the special F1 page where the preview is located, as that will be the location of my stories in the coming F1 Special Reports throughout the season, and it has a link to this blog.

headline: As Cablevision Weighs a Deal, Analyst Fears a Flop
abstract: Does Cablevision Systems want to be a rock star? An analyst from Pali Research suspects it does — and he thinks it would go over about as well as a Vanilla Ice comeback.

headline: Outlook for New York City Economy Turns Grimmer
abstract: The outlook for New York City’s economy and its main engine, the financial services industry, had already taken a bleak turn before the sudden failure of Bear Stearns, the fifth-largest firm on Wall Street.

headline: SocGen’s Rogue Trader Is in Custody
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel, a former trader at Société Générale, surrendered to the police on Saturday as investigators looked into what had caused the bank, one of Europe’s largest, to lose more than $7 billion.

headline: UBS Shortens Directors’ Terms
abstract: UBS said Thursday that board members will have to stand for election every year, an indication that the bank is giving in to investor anger over recent subprime troubles.

headline: Bear Stearns to Sell Itself to JPMorgan for $2 a Share
abstract: Updated 7:25 p.m. Bear Stearns, facing collapse because of the mortgage crisis, agreed Sunday evening to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, the two companies announced.

headline: New Questions for a New Year
abstract: A list of tech-industry questions that might get answers this year.

headline: Breeden Capital Goes Back for More of Zale
abstract: Activist investor Breeden Capital Management has once again increased its stake in jewelry store operator Zale, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission Monday.

headline: Home Price Plunge Accelerates
abstract: The S.&P./Case-Shiller indexes for December, out this morning, show the following price changes for the fourth quarter of 2007, annualized:

headline: UBS Shuffles Financial Institutions Group
abstract: As Olivier Sarkozy prepares to move to the Carlyle Group from UBS, the Swiss bank is wasting little time in shifting personnel inside its financial institutions group to fill that gap.

headline: Credit Rating Cut for Sallie Mae
abstract: The SLM Corporation, the educational lender known as Sallie Mae, had its long-term credit ratings cut by Moody’s Investors Service to two levels above junk Tuesday on concern that a change in the company’s strategy will erode profitability.

headline: Your Questions for Iraqis
abstract: What would you like to know about Iraqis’ thoughts on the war, the United States and life in Iraq today? We’ll take a video camera and a translator out on the streets of Baghdad to ask people your questions. This isn’t an opinion poll — the answer you get may only reflect one person’s views. Still, that may offer a little insight into how the Iraqi people see things. Submit your questions this week using the comment box below or suggest a topic for future Q&As. The first set of responses will appear on Monday, March 17.

headline: Is JPMorgan’s Buying Spree Only Beginning?
abstract: James Dimon may have solidified his reputation for deal-making savvy with JPMorgan Chase‘s stunning deal for Bear Stearns But his firm may not be putting its checkbook away yet.

headline: Pandit’s Price Tag, All Told: $216 Million
abstract: Call him Citigroup‘s quarter-billion-dollar man.

headline: Tom Perkins: ‘I Love Bubbles’
abstract: When Tom Perkins isn’t blowing the whistle at Hewlett-Packard, sailing in his retro yacht or writing a memoir, he is known as one of Silicon Valley’s leading venture capitalists. In that latter capacity, he recently spoke with Spencer Ante, a BusinessWeek editor who also runs the Creative Capital blog, about the current state of venture capital.

headline: The Curious Incident of the Kellwood Tender Offers
abstract: The Kellwood deal took a slight turn this weekend. On Friday, Sun Capital amended its tender offer to include a new condition “that, upon the closing of the tender offer, Sun Capital representatives on the Kellwood Board of Directors will constitute a majority of the directors and be proportionate in number to Sun Capital’s percentage shareholding in the Company.”

headline: Is Google’s Enterprise Software Too Cheap?
abstract: Enterprise customers want their hands held. And if Google cuts prices too low, there simply isn’t enough money for it or a reseller to provide much service.

headline: Ringleader Recharges With $6 Million
abstract: Ringleader Digital on Monday became the latest in a string of companies in the embryonic mobile advertising market to announce that it has attracted venture capital funding.

headline: Delta Says It Also Has a Strong Stand-Alone Plan
abstract: Delta Air Lines‘ executives are painting a picture of the airline as a suitor that can afford to be picky.

headline: Liz Claiborne Said to Be Near a Sale of Ellen Tracy
abstract: Liz Claiborne, the women’s clothing giant, is in the process of selling some of its brands and may make an announcement as soon as Friday, Fortune’s Suzanne Kapner reported.

headline: Altria Plans to Spin Off Overseas Division in March
abstract: The Altria Group said Wednesday that it would spin off its international tobacco business on March 28, freeing it to pursue cigarette sales more aggressively outside the United States.

headline: Turn Reels In $15 Million in New Round
abstract: An online ad network, Turn, has raised a $15 million second round funding, Paid Content reported.

headline: Celebrity Chef Cooks Up Deal With Martha Stewart
abstract: Is there room in the well-appointed house of Martha for another larger-than-life name brand?

headline: Outside the Box: Hasbro’s Cranium Deal
abstract: Is Hasbro changing its game plan?

headline: The Power of Scent, Explained
abstract: Few people stop to smell the roses during this frenetic week. But for a small group that did Thursday afternoon — the blooms being sniffed were white — they learned that a rose contains 300 different scent molecules.

headline: The iPod Economy and C.E.S.
abstract: This year, sales will be greater for speaker systems and clock radios designed to hook up to Apple iPods than standalone desktop stereos and home theater-in-a-box systems.

headline: Bear Hires New Asia Markets Executive
abstract: Bear Stearns has hired Darius Yuen from the French bank BNP Paribas to head its equity capital markets group in Asia, a spokeswoman told Reuters on Friday.

headline: Is RiskMetrics’ I.P.O. a Bellwether for 2008?
abstract: A share sale this week for RiskMetrics Group, the owner of Institutional Shareholder Services, the proxy advisory service, could go a long way toward determining whether the new-issues market will have a smooth or bumpy ride in the early part of the year, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Upstart Exchange Said to Eye Archipelago Founder for Top Post
abstract: Building up its arsenal before facing off against the CME Group, an upstart and still unnamed electronic futures exchange backed by a dozen financial players is considering Archipelago founder Jerry Putnam for its chief executive, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: It’s Almost Time To Write The Academy Awards
abstract: One program especially eager to get its writers back is the Oscar telecast slated for February 24.

headline: Merrill Gets In on Another Big Mining Deal
abstract: Merrill Lynch, dropped as an adviser and financier to the Brazilian mining company Vale, has re-emerged in the mining sector as a lender to BHP Billiton, which raised its bid for a rival, Rio Tinto.

headline: As State Street Faces Suit Over Losses, Will Others Follow?
abstract: Have the floodgates on a new wave of securities fraud lawsuits been opened?

headline: Hedge Funds With Northern Rock Stakes Fight Takeover
abstract: Hedge funds SRM Global and RAB Capital on Monday detailed their case for blocking takeover offers for Northern Rock, the troubled British bank that precipitated Britain’s worst banking crisis in more than a century.

headline: WNET President Seeks a Heightened Urgency
abstract: On Monday Neal Shapiro’s one-year apprenticeship as the president of WNET, Channel 13 in New York, “will end when he takes on the top job, as president and chief executive of the station’s parent, the Educational Broadcasting Corporation,” Elizabeth Jensen reports in today’s New York Times.

headline: Times Company Joins $29.5 Million Round for WordPress Owner
abstract: Automattic, the commercial arm of the popular WordPress publishing platform for blogs, has received $29.5 million in financing from four companies, including a small portion from The New York Times Company.

headline: Enel Plans $22 Billion in Asset Sale
abstract: The Italian utility Enel on Thursday disclosed plans to sell assets worth up to 15 billion euros ($22 billion) to help offset the costs of acting as a white knight for Spain’s Endesa last year, as well as a recent expansion in Russia.

headline: Whitney Sharply Cuts Citi Earnings Estimates
abstract: One of Citigroup‘s most persistent critics hasn’t changed her negative view on the stumbling financial giant.

headline: Executive Pay on the Hill: The C.E.O.’s Respond
abstract: “The reality is that I received no severance package.”

headline: Analysts See More Pain for Citi
abstract: Analysts at Goldman Sachs said they expect additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major United States brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup forecast to record the highest write-down of about $12 billion.

headline: Are Tech Deals Getting More Hostile?
abstract: Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion unsolicited bid for Yahoo on Friday may be proof that hostile takeovers are coming of age in high tech, The San Jose Mercury News says.

headline: Buffett’s State of the World: There’s Folly in Wonderland
abstract: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett disclosed Friday that he had earned profits for shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway by speculating in the Brazilian currency, the real, and by buying a large stake in a French pharmaceutical company, Sanofi-Aventis.

headline: Friday’s Links: Business Cards for Slash-Filled Lives
abstract: Some commentary on the surge in business card offerings.

headline: Onex Sees Challenges Ahead
abstract: The Canadian private-equity group Onex said Thursday its pace of investment will slow this year as the “upheaval” in credit markets makes financing large deals more difficult.

headline: Antitrust Concerns Hover Over UnitedHealth Deal
abstract: Investors’ concerns about the $2.4 billion merger of Sierra Health Services and the UnitedHealth Group appear to be growing, judging from the widening spread in the companies’ share prices. The reason? Continued political opposition in Nevada and the “risk that a further delay in the federal antitrust review could trigger new proceedings at the state level,” The Deal reports.

headline: Goldman to Invest in China Buyout Fund, Report Says
abstract: Two senior Goldman Sachs bankers are teaming up to run a new $2 billion private-equity fund aimed at landing big deals in China, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: D.E. Shaw’s (Very) Good Timing
abstract: When Alliance Data Systems announced Friday that it was dropping its lawsuit against the Blackstone Group, many shareholders surely leaped for joy as the company’s stock jumped 6.9 percent. But perhaps chief among the beneficiaries of the news was D.E. Shaw, which made an extremely timely investment, PE Hub’s Dan Primack points out.

headline: Carlsberg and Heineken to Swallow British Brewer
abstract: Heineken is set to assume the mantle of Britain’s biggest brewer after Scottish & Newcastle on Friday accepted a $15.2 billion (7.8 billion pound) joint takeover offer made by the Dutch brewer and its Nordic counterpart, Carlsberg.

headline: Bears Said to Eye Stake in China Asset Management
abstract: Bear Stearns is in talks to buy around 10 percent of China’s biggest fund house, China Asset Management, to tap the country’s red-hot mutual fund market, Reuters reported.

headline: Fox Leads CBS in Household Viewers
abstract: First 18- to 49-year-olds, then total viewers, now households: the recognition of Fox as the most-watched television network in America continued last week as it displaced CBS among households in prime time.

headline: King & Spalding Poaches Silicon Valley Lawyers
abstract: In the latest example of the rush on Silicon Valley to grab talent and clients in the U.S. technology company center, Atlanta-based law firm King & Spalding is venturing into California, poaching at least eight attorneys from Perkins Coie‘s Silicon Valley office.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Genesco Adds Charge Against UBS in Fight With Finish Line
abstract: The legal battle over the $700 million merger of the shoe retailers Genesco and Finish Line is coming to a head.

headline: I.B.M.’s Follow-Through on Cognos
abstract: I.B.M. spent $5 billion last November to acquire Cognos to expand its so-called information-on-demand strategy. The 451 Group, an analyst firm, looks at what has happened since the transaction closed in late January.

headline: Cadbury Sets Terms of Spinoff
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, has set the terms of its soda unit’s planned spinoff.

headline: Who Are More Human: PC Users or Couch Potatoes?
abstract: Matters turned philosophical here at the Consumer Electronics Show in a discussion with Toshihiro Sakamoto, president and senior managing director of Panasonic AVC Networks. Mr. Sakamoto is charming, twinkle-eyed and at least a grade classier than the sell-at-all-costs, run-of-the mill American chief executive. (And, as my friend Alex Pham of The Los Angeles Times put it, he sure is handsome.)

headline: For Blackstone, a Question of ‘Best Efforts’
abstract: Alliance Data Systems announced Monday that the Blackstone Group had dropped the bombshell the market had been fearing. Blackstone informed Alliance Data that it does not anticipate the condition to closing the merger relating to obtaining approvals from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency will be satisfied.

headline: A System Overdue for Reform
abstract: A week ago Thursday, just days after the big Bear Stearns crisis, Representative Barney Frank gave a speech to the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce. Most people know Mr. Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, as one of the most liberal members of Congress.

headline: How The Strike Affects Your Favorite Shows
abstract: As the writers’ strike enters its tenth week, networks have been forced to scramble.Here’s how your other favorite shows have been affected. Check back frequently for updates.

headline: Pioneer Aims to Tap $136 Million in Blank-Check I.P.O.
abstract: Pioneer Southwest Energy Partners, a limited partnership formed to acquire oil and gas properties, said Tuesday it plans to raise $136 million in an initial public offering of 7.5 million common units, according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Ratings: A Revived ‘Apprentice’ Finale Wins Out
abstract: Piers Morgan, best known for his role as a judge on NBC’s “America’s Got Talent,” became the seventh winner of NBC’s “Apprentice” series on Thursday as the show’s two-hour finale earned the night’s highest ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 12.1 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. for the “Apprentice” conclusion, the largest audience for any episode of the series since the finale of “The Apprentice 4″ in December 2005.

headline: What If Yahoo’s Earnings Disappoint?
abstract: While some Yahoo investors might be waiting for a richer bid from Microsoft, some industry observers have been speculating that the software giant might be waiting for its opportunity to table a lower bid.

headline: New Patentable Idea: A Way to Invalidate Vague Patents
abstract: A federal appeals court has agreed to hear a patent case that may invalidate a controversial class of patents called business method patents, which seek to protect ways of doing business.

headline: The Kids Choice: ‘Hannah Montana’ and ‘Drake and Josh’
abstract: “It was a night when children were given the floor to bestow accolades on Hollywood,” Jacques Steinberg reports. “At the 21st annual Kids’ Choice Awards on Saturday, Miley Cyrus, the star of the Disney Channel series ‘Hannah Montana,’ was chosen favorite television actress and female singer, while ‘Drake and Josh,’ a Nickelodeon series, was honored as favorite television show with one of its stars, Drake Bell, as favorite television actor.”

headline: CNNMoney Takes on Cable Business News
abstract: In an attempt to take on cable business news, CNN Money will start producing 30 video segments a day, with regular financial updates, interviews, and video blogs.

headline: Can the Touch Revive Apple’s iPod Sales?
abstract: Despite a 10 percent drop in Apple’s shares, the company did very well in the fourth quarter, putting $3 billion in the bank. It plans to address its main weakness–slow growth in iPod sales–by emphasizing the Internet capability of the iPod Touch.

headline: Clear Channel Warns Buyout May Collapse
abstract: Radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications said on Friday its pending $20 billion buyout may collapse, as the banks had failed to provide funding for the deal under previously agreed terms.

headline: A Guide to Yahoo’s Unlikely Alternatives to Microsoft
abstract: Yahoo is searching for any alternative to being swallowed by Microsoft. It has been talking to News Corporation, Time Warner and Google, among others. None of these talks appear likely to be able to fend off a deal with Microsoft.

headline: Alder Gets $40 Million Injection from V.C.s
abstract: Alder Biopharmaceuticals raised $40 million in a third round of venture capital to fund clinical trials of its first novel antibody product for treating rheumatoid arthritis and cancer.

headline: Pentagon Capital to Close Its Doors
abstract: Pentagon Capital Management, a 1 billion pound ($2 billion) hedge fund run by the investor Lewis Chester, said Thursday that it would close its funds and return investors’ money because of a mutual fund trading investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Diving Into Davos 2008
abstract: Another year, another high-powered gathering in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: G.M. Becomes Delphi’s Lender of Last Resort
abstract: Almost a decade after spinning off the auto parts maker Delphi and more than two years after Delphi filed for bankruptcy, General Motors still finds itself shelling out cash to its former subsidiary.

headline: Supreme Court To Review ‘Fleeting Expletive’ Case
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: Permira Hires Ex-North Fork C.F.O. as Adviser
abstract: A British private equity firm, Permira, said on Monday that it had hired North Fork‘s former chief financial officer, Daniel M. Healy, as a senior adviser for potential deals primarily in the financial services sector.

headline: Rescue Me: A Fed Bailout Crosses a Line

The study concluded that Spanish women were not the very skinny tall types that designers idealize, but rather fell into three main body types: hourglass, pear shape and cylinder. It also found that 4 of 10 women had trouble finding clothes to fit, mainly because sizes varied from store to store and because what was on the racks was too small.
