headline: Belgium: Copyright Violation Is Claimed
abstract: Belgian newspapers, emboldened by a court victory against Google last year, have started a preliminary copyright action against the European Commission over links on agency Web sites. Two Web sites owned by the commission, the Brussels-based executive for the 27 European Union nations, infringe copyright laws by linking to Belgian newspaper articles free, according to Copiepresse, a copyright group for French- and German-language newspapers. A Brussels court, asked by the group to look at its claim, appointed an expert to study how information is gathered for the E.U. sites. “Once the expert has submitted his report, we may decide to file a lawsuit,” said Margaret Boribon, the group’s secretary general. A Brussels court in February ruled Google had violated Belgian copyright laws by publishing links to the newspapers without permission and ordered the company to remove the links or pay a daily fine of 25,000 euros ($37,000).

headline: Despite Weak Economy, Business Travel Demand Was Up in 2008
abstract: BUSINESS TRAVEL DEMAND UP IN 2008 Any weakening in the economy apparently has not yet affected most business travelers’ plans this year. According to Access America, an insurance and travelers’ assistance company, 26 percent of business travelers surveyed said they expected to be on the road more this year than last, and 61 percent said they expected to travel about the same amount. Among other findings in the survey of 1,000 travelers: Nearly 78 percent cited high gasoline prices as one frustration of travel, 55 percent named poor airline service, and 41 percent cited airport security and passport and border procedures. By far the least frustrating part of travel was booking the trip. Only 16 percent said they found making travel arrangements frustrating.

abstract: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes a regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

abstract: The victims, nine Afghan police officers and a civilian, were mistaken for Taliban and shot by American forces.

headline: Yahoo’s Directors Discuss How to Face Microsoft Bid
abstract: Presentations from Yahoo’s management and its bankers argued that the company was worth more than what Microsoft has offered.

abstract: New data provided fresh evidence of the housing market’s slump even as the broader economy is squeezed by higher prices.

abstract: A mob of 300 Serbs wielding clubs and tools gathered near a small ethnic-Albanian village, prompting NATO to send armored vehicles and tanks to head them off.

headline: Monk Protests in Tibet Draw Chinese Security
abstract: Chinese security forces were reportedly surrounding three monasteries after what are believed to be the largest protests in two decades.

abstract: Mr. Copeland made a fortune with the fried-chicken restaurant chain he started, Popeyes.

abstract: The United States arm of ING is launching a “Your Number” campaign, which refers to the amount of money that you will need to retire comfortably.

abstract: Nearby hotels cater to those seeking to offset frustrations, offering a spa treatment or a workstation for the delayed traveler.

headline: Macquarie Chief to Retire; Successor Is Named

The firm also forecast a 23 percent gain in full-year profit to 1.8 billion Australian dollars ($1.62 billion) on higher trading volumes. Mr. Moore, 49, who runs the division that generates more than 50 percent of profit, takes the top job May 24, the company said in a statement.

headline: Oracle, Sweetening Terms, Buys BEA
abstract: Just three months after BEA handily rejected its original unsolicited bid, Oracle said it would acquire BEA Systems for $8.5 billion.

The standoff increases the possibility the position will go vacant once Toshihiko Fukui’s term expires on Wednesday. The government must propose a new candidate or resubmit the same one after the conflicting votes. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

The company, based in Camden, N.J., began selling imported broths in Russia in October.

abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Expanding Into Wind Energy
abstract: Scottish and Southern Energy, a British utility, agreed to buy the Irish wind farm operator Airtricity for 1.83 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash to add to its production of renewable energy. In the deal, Scottish and Southern said it would also take over 375 million euros of debt. The European Union has called for 20 percent of all energy, including transport fuels and heating, to come from renewable sources by 2020. Airtricity, Ireland’s largest wind farm operator, has been expanding operations in Britain and last year won approval to install turbines off the coast of England. Scottish and Southern, based in Perth, Scotland, said the deal would probably be completed in the first quarter.

abstract: The reduction of the benchmark interest rate to 2.25 percent was less than investors had been hoping for, though it was one of the deepest in Fed history.

headline: Annan Has Sharp Words for Kenyans as Talks Stall
abstract: Kofi Annan, the former U.N. secretary general who is trying to broker a political peace treaty in Kenya, expressed rare public frustration, blasting Kenya’s leaders for failing to compromise.

abstract: Carlyle Capital said that it had asked lenders to halt further liquidation of collateral worth as much as $16 billion while the two sides discuss ways to repay debt.

headline: Canada: Buyout Challenged Over Racial Bias
abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada’s proposed $1.6 billion acquisition of Alabama National BanCorp was challenged by a group that claimed the Canadian bank engages in discriminatory lending. A financial advocacy group for poor consumers, Fair Finance Watch, said it asked the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., in a letter for hearings and all documents relating to the proposed buyout. The Royal Bank agreed on Sept. 6 to buy Alabama National for cash and stock. Fair Finance Watch claimed that in 2006 Royal Bank’s RBC Centura unit denied mortgage refinance applications in Charlotte, N.C., to blacks 4.4 times more frequently than whites. The group said in the Atlanta area, RBC Centura denied home improvement mortgage applications of blacks 4.2 times more frequently than whites. A bank spokeswoman, Judi Levita, said “the lending practices of RBC Centura satisfactorily comply with all applicable requirements.”.

headline: Canada: Quarterly Turnaround at Airline
abstract: Air Canada reported fourth-quarter profit of 35 million Canadian dollars ($34.8 million), reversing a year-earlier loss, helped by a stronger Canadian dollar and higher domestic demand. Net income was 35 cents a share, the airline said. A year earlier, Air Canada had a net loss of 144 million Canadian dollars. Revenue increased 3.7 percent, to 2.51 billion Canadian dollars ($2.5 billion). Air Canada, which generates a fifth of its revenue from flights to the United States, had been shifting capacity to domestic routes to avoid a slowdown in the United States. Air Canada’s stock rose 18 percent after the results were released.

abstract: When it is first broadcast later this month, “Ippadikku Rose” (“Yours, Rose”) is expected to cause a sensation, introducing India’s first transgender celebrity to television.

headline: In This Shiite Battle, a Marked Shift From the Past
abstract: Among the differences between the ongoing Shiite battle in Iraq and the wave of Shiite attacks of 2004, one is that the Shiite rebels are fighting Iraqi soldiers, not Americans.

abstract: Prosecutors accused Klaus Zumwinkel, chief executive of Deutsche Post, with tax evasion after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Bearer of Bad News Decides to Advertise It
abstract: After more than 70 years, Consumer Reports has decided that a review isn’t enough for a bad product — it deserves a provocative ad campaign, too.

headline: Suit Says Spinal Disk Maker Falsely Won F.D.A. Approval
abstract: The suit now says the original maker of the device and the investment firm that financed its development misled patients and federal regulators about the disk’s safety.

headline: Olmert Is Cautious as Talks With Palestinians Begin
abstract: As the talks started, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel sought to lower expectations of reaching a final peace agreement within a year.

headline: New Orders for Goods Fall Sharply
abstract: Manufacturers, wary of making large investments during the economic slowdown, sent new orders for durable manufactured goods down 1.7 percent in February.

headline: A Monstrous PC Gaming Rig Comes With a Nonthreatening Price Tag
abstract: Gaming beasts like the Dell XPS 630 are paving the way for new machines with impressive performance and impressively low prices.

headline: Would-Be Peacemaker Killed in Kenya
abstract: A freshman lawmaker who could have been one of the keys to unlocking Kenya’s crisis was shot dead.

headline: With Wires Out of Sight, the Bunny Slippers Under the Bed Will Be Visible
abstract: The Idapt is a flat charger with one power cable and three slots to hold various charging tips for iPods, cellphones and other gadgets.

headline: Getty Images Up for Sale, Could Fetch $1.5 Billion
abstract: Getty Images, the world’s biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block.

headline: Brown Defends Takeover of Ailing British Lender
abstract: British Prime Minister Gordon Brown defended his decision to nationalize the struggling lender Northern Rock but some shareholders are threatening legal action.

headline: Newly Elected South Korean Leader Faces Inquiry
abstract: An independent prosecutor will investigate whether President-elect Lee Myung-bak engaged in financial misdeeds.

abstract: The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday argued that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news is damaging the newspaper industry.

headline: Mad Magazine Uses Pulitzer Winners to Tweak Bush
abstract: Mad magazine enlists the talents of 10 Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonists for its two-page exposé, “Why George W. Bush Is in Favor of Global Warming.”

headline: Bid for China Eastern Airline Stake Rebuffed
abstract: The snub opens the way for the parent of the nation’s largest carrier, Air China, to make an offer of its own.

abstract: A day after an interest rate cut fueled the best stock session in five years, the Dow slid back nearly 300 points and commodity prices plummeted.

abstract: Witnesses say that for almost 24 hours after Lhasa erupted, police officers were often nowhere to be found.

headline: Study Says Private Equity Isn’t Big Job Killer
abstract: The World Economic Forum plans to announce on Friday the results of a study that found that companies owned by private equity shed on average about 1 percent more jobs than their peers.

abstract: Dr. David B. Allison resigned as president of the Obesity Society, a research group, after being criticized for an affidavit he wrote as a paid consultant on behalf of the restaurant industry.

abstract: Some nonresidential construction sectors, whose share of construction had risen to a 15-year high, appear increasingly hesitant to spend and overall construction spending has begun to fall.

headline: In Argentina, No Assistance From Region on Gas Needs
abstract: Argentina and Brazil are facing the possibility of short-term energy crises from a lack of natural gas needed to fuel industries and generate electricity for residents.

headline: Europe’s Central Banker Engineers His Economics
abstract: Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the European Central Bank, is standing resolute about inflation, but he is watching the American economy closely.

headline: A Lebanese Diva, Performing in Syria, Creates Drama in More Ways Than One
abstract: Fayrouz, the great Lebanese diva, returned to Damascus for the first time in three decades, a performance some considered a betrayal.

headline: Second Leg of Apple’s Plans Includes Jumping Back Into Movie Rentals
abstract: Steven P. Jobs is rebooting Apple’s digital movie effort and putting the company squarely in the middle of an intensifying industry battle.

headline: New York Times Plans to Cut 100 Newsroom Jobs
abstract: The newspaper will bow to growing financial strain and cut 100 newsroom jobs this year, primarily through attrition and buyouts, but layoffs are a possibility, the executive editor said.

headline: Is the Ad a Success? The Brain Waves Tell All
abstract: Agencies and advertisers are growing more interested in neuroscience in their never-ending efforts to improve effectiveness.

headline: Frank Piasecki, a Pioneer in Helicopters, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Mr. Piasecki was the first to develop a tandem-rotor helicopter — the so-called Flying Banana — capable of carrying large cargo loads or troops into combat.

headline: Britain: More Chaos at Heathrow
abstract: For the second successive day, British Airways canceled dozens of flights at Heathrow Airport’s glittery new Terminal 5 as its staff struggled with state-of-the-art technology supposed to hasten check-in and baggage-handling procedures. The hitches since the terminal opened on Thursday were “definitely not British Airways’ finest hour,” the airline’s chief executive, Willie Walsh, told reporters. Some passengers slept overnight inside the steel-and-glass terminal, reviving precisely those images of delay and decline in British aviation that British Airways said Terminal 5 would banish.

headline: Trade Case Takes Aim at China on Financial Data
abstract: The Bush administration joined with the European Union in filing suit with the World Trade Organization to protest China’s rules governing foreign financial news services.

headline: A Lawmaker Whose Nation Dislikes Her Friends
abstract: Few politicians generate as much emotion or controversy as Piedad Córdoba, the Colombian senator at the center of negotiations with Colombia’s largest rebel group.

headline: A Virtual Travel Agent With All the Answers
abstract: Alaska Airlines introduces a surprisingly pleasant virtual assistant on its Web site.

headline: 19 Burned to Death in Violence in Kenya
abstract: Ethnically driven violence intensified in Kenya on Sunday, and police officials said at least 19 people, including 11 children, were burned to death in a house by a mob.

headline: A Middling Week, but a Good One for 2008
abstract: The broad market declined modestly, but the Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily laden with technology stocks, managed a slight gain.

headline: This Year, Commodities Are on a Rockier Road
abstract: Rising demand, a falling dollar and rosy economic predictions have stoked the price of commodities in the last few years. But times are changing.

abstract: The Queensland Gas Company, an Australian producer of natural gas from coal seams, and the BG Group of Britain plan to invest about 8 billion Australian dollars ($7.2 billion) in an export project in northeastern Australia to tap rising demand for the fuel.

abstract: Singapore’s government has put the entire country on alert after a man believed to be the leader of a terrorist group escaped from prison.

headline: Israeli Army Operation in Nablus Is Suspended

abstract: The BBC World Service, which began its shortwave transmissions 75 years ago, ended its English-language shortwave services in Europe on Monday.

abstract: After 10 months of political turmoil, President Pervez Musharraf is so unpopular that his own party is distancing itself from the president, candidates and party officials admit.

headline: U.S. Cities Put on the Charm for Foreign Tourists
abstract: As the weak dollar woos international visitors, individual cities and states are stepping up their global promotional efforts.

headline: As Suharto Clings to Life, Mystics See Spirits’ Power
abstract: The diagnosis among some believers in Solo, the heart of Javanese culture, is that powerful occult forces in former President Suharto’s body will not let him go.

headline: Pope’s Rewrite of Latin Prayer Draws Criticism From 2 Sides
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI on Tuesday issued a replacement for a contentious Good Friday prayer, removing language that many Jewish groups found offensive but still calling for their conversion.

headline: Chile: 11 Die as Plane Crashes Into Ball Field
abstract: A small police plane crashed into a soccer field in Santiago, the capital, killing the six occupants of the plane and five people on the field.

headline: Amid Warnings, Europe’s Economy Is Holding Up
abstract: New data suggested Europe was fairing better than many analysts had expected, but officials warned that a slowdown was probably inevitable.

headline: A Light Show in a Bulb
abstract: Adding mood lighting to a space-age bachelor pad is easy with this five-watt L.E.D. bulb from ThinkGeek that comes with its own remote control.

abstract: Lt. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno mid-February completed a 15-month tour as the day to day American commander in Iraq.

headline: Ford Is Pushing Buyouts to Workers
abstract: The buyout packages are among the richest ever offered to factory workers, including one-time cash payments of $140,000.

headline: The Builder Who Pushes Tokyo Into the Clouds
abstract: Minoru Mori, Japan’s most prolific developer, will finish one of the world’s tallest buildings in May, and plans to build or help build 10 more huge complexes in downtown Tokyo.

headline: Sale Price Reflects the Depth of Bear’s Problems
abstract: JPMorgan Chase will pay just $2 a share for Bear Stearns — less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.

abstract: America’s image in the Middle East is as low as it has ever been. Yet generally speaking, Iranians like Americans — a sentiment that has become much more pronounced.

headline: Clashes With Israeli Troops Kill 4 Militants in Gaza
abstract: An Israeli soldier was also seriously wounded in an exchange of fire with Palestinian militants in southern Gaza.

headline: Britain: Inflation Exceeds Bank’s Target
abstract: Inflation in Britain was above the Bank of England’s 2 percent target for a third month in December, adding to the case for fewer interest rate cuts this year. Consumer prices rose 2.1 percent from a year earlier, the same as in November, the Office for National Statistics said.

abstract: A gunman opened fire inside a a famous Jewish seminary in the heart of Jerusalem, killing at least eight students and wounding at least nine others, Israeli police said.

abstract: In a massive city of steel at the edge of the Red Sea, Saudi Arabia is trying to move beyond oil to become an industrial power.

abstract: Thaksin Shinawatra returned to Thailand 17 months after he was ousted in a coup, and will face corruption charges.

abstract: Iraqi forces, which have no air support of their own, have so far failed to subdue Shiite militias in Basra and have asked the Americans and British for help.

abstract: Police said they arrested nearly 200 rioters involved in Thursday’s protest in which demonstrators, outraged at American support for an independent Kosovo, stormed the U.S. Embassy in Belgrade.

abstract: Greek officials handed over the Olympic flame to organizers of the Beijing Summer Games on Sunday, but demonstrators sought to disrupt the ceremony.

abstract: As part of a campaign to upgrade its image by changing the way it does business, Wal-Mart has pledged to cut the energy used by many of its products by 25 percent.

abstract: Economists viewed a surge in unemployment as the most powerful sign to date of a possible recessionary downturn.

abstract: The commission is considering taking steps to discourage cable and telephone companies from delaying the downloads and uploads of heavy Internet users.

abstract: The Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts chain has signed a celebrity spokesman whose specialty is near and dear to the guests’ hearts: golf.

abstract: Because there are so many of them, baby boomers are the most competitive generation we’ve ever seen, but as they retire, many will experience a kind of forced leisure.

abstract: Old rhetoric dies hard for Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive at Ford Motor Company, who spent most of his career at jet maker Boeing.

abstract: Israeli forces also blew up militant commanders’ houses as Palestinians fired a rocket more than 10 miles into Israel.

abstract: Hints of stagflation and continuing worries about slumping growth weighed on investors as the major stock indexes ended an erratic week of ups and downs.

abstract: Sales of pickup trucks, long a steady supplier of hefty profits to automakers, were slowed in 2007 by gas prices and housing ills.

abstract: In the deeply troubled Rift Valley, furious mobs rule the streets, brutalizing ethnic rivals with complete impunity.

abstract: Macedonia’s bid to join the military alliance could be blocked if it fails to resolve a long-standing name dispute with Greece, a longtime NATO member.

abstract: One of the most prominent human rights advocates in China stood trial on Tuesday on subversion charges.

abstract: The Ambac Financial Group, a bond insurer, said Wednesday that its chief risk officer had resigned.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 17 at Ceremony Near Capital
abstract: In the wake of a suicide bombing near Falluja, Iraq, in Anbar Province, local tribesmen burned the house of the young bomber’s family and prevented them from collecting his head for burial.

abstract: As the dollar weakens, holders of dollars, especially those overseas, are aiming for better returns by diversifying their portfolios.

abstract: Verizon Communications announced earnings of $1.07 billion in the fourth quarter, but said its traditional telephone business remained a drag on the bottom line.

abstract: India has long tried to strike a delicate balance between maintaining good relations with China and allowing the Dalai Lama and his followers, who are based in the country, to keep their cause alive.

abstract: The suspect, and now fugitive, Mas Selamat Kastari, was a senior operative with Jemaah Islamiyah, the Indonesia-based Islamic movement associated with Al Qaeda.

abstract: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills.

abstract: A group of high school students who scaled a brick wall to ask the U.N. to help the Tibetan cause were instead served a lunch of steamed dumplings.

headline: Yahoo Makes a New Play for Ads on Mobile Phones
abstract: Yahoo plans to announce it has opened up some of its key mobile software and services to outside publishers and programmers.

abstract: Thousands of Serbs took to the streets of the divided city of Mitrovica, waving Serbian flags and chanting “Kosovo is Serbia!”

abstract: The company named Katharine Weymouth, passing the title to the fourth generation of the family that has controlled the paper for 75 years.

abstract: The nationalization of Northern Rock is a huge blow for the government of Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 40 at Iraq Highway Rest Stop
abstract: Shiite Muslims making a pilgrimage to the Shrine of Imam Hussein in Karbala were targeted by a suicide bomber.

abstract: The real estate on the back of an HDTV is crowded with ports for connectors of the past. Out of that mess comes yet another cable, but it is supposed to make everything simple: the HDMI.

headline: Iran Reformists Question Conservative Gains
abstract: Conservatives controlled about three-quarters of the more than 200 races decided so far in the 290-seat Parliament, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Deal Reached to Buy Some Verizon Lines
abstract: FairPoint Communications reached an agreement with the Vermont Public Service Department that would allow it to buy Verizon phone lines in the state.

abstract: A New York state appeals court has ruled that Maurice R. Greenberg can review internal documents detailing questionable transactions, a victory in his fight against the company he had long helmed.

abstract: A long-running federal investigation into the orthopedic device industry’s suspected kickback payments to hip and knee surgeons now has the doctors in the spotlight.

abstract: In what may become an A-list booking-war blitz, David Letterman has landed comedian Robin Williams as the first guest when “The Late Show” returns to CBS.

abstract: The authorities in Berlin closed a gallery whose exhibition included satirical works by Danish artists that caricatured the Kaaba shrine in Mecca after Muslims protested.

abstract: The rocker Bob Geldof, who has made ending poverty in Africa a personal cause, is convinced that President Bush has undergone some sort of epiphany about Africa.

abstract: Dmitri A. Medvedev, chosen by President Vladimir V. Putin to be Russia’s next leader, is crafting his own image.

abstract: An environmental group says a Coca-Cola bottling plant in the drought-stricken state of Rajasthan is depleting scarce water supplies.

abstract: Seeking stability, Chrysler turns to James E. Press, a 37-year veteran of rival automaker Toyota.

headline: They're Working on Their Own, Just Side by Side
abstract: Equipped with cellphones and Wi-Fi, young people who work independently are banding together in shared spaces.

abstract: Sun Microsystems has received a $44 million contract from the Pentagon to explore the high-risk idea of replacing wires between computer chips with laser beams.

headline: Canada: Agency Puts Conditions on Phone Buyout
abstract: Canadian communications regulators approved the 51.7 billion Canadian dollar ($50.9 billion) buyout of BCE, the country’s biggest phone provider, and set conditions that require the carrier to remain Canadian controlled. One of the six criteria requires Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan to appoint six directors, instead of the five proposed. The pension plan and its United States partners agreed to modify the original deal to appease the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, which had expressed concerns that BCE might end up being controlled by United States investors. That proposal did not go far enough, the agency said in its decision. Deborah Allan, a spokeswoman for the pension plan, said the pension fund was reviewing the conditions and had no further comment.

headline: Dispute Deepens for Russia and Britain
abstract: A British cultural organization was forced to close its offices and its staff was questioned by Russian authorities, the latest twist in a downward spiral in relations since the death of a former Russian spy in London in 2006.

headline: Start-Up Airline’s Campaign Takes Cheeky Approach
abstract: Not so long ago, airline advertising was, well, high-flying, using majestic or serene themes like “The wings of man,” for Eastern Air Lines; “Something special in the air,” for American Airlines; and “Pan Am makes the going great,” for Pan American World Airways.

abstract: A Pakistani official in charge of the country’s nuclear arsenal ruled out any possibility that Islamic extremists, could gain control of nuclear weapons.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe: Finland: Nokia Siemens Makes Acquisition

Apertio’s products are used by wireless and fixed phone operators. Apertio, based in Bristol, England, has operations in Continental Europe, Asia and the United States.

headline: Brazil: Bank’s Lending and Profit Rise
abstract: Banco Bradesco, the Brazilian bank, reported a 29 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income on higher lending and one-time gains. Net income climbed to 2.19 billion reais ($1.23 billion) from 1.7 billion reais a year earlier, Bradesco said. Recurring profit, similar to profit from continuing operations, advanced 14 percent to 1.85 billion reais from a year ago, it said. Bank lending in Brazil has increased every month since February 2004 as interest rates fell to record lows and employment rose. The total loan portfolio, including receivables from credit cards, grew 39 percent to 161.4 billion reais, from 116.2 billion in December 2006. Net income was helped by a one-time 227-million-reais gain from the sale of a stake in Bolsa de Mercadorias & Futuros, Latin America’s largest derivatives market, and 178 million reais of profit from the sale of shares in Bovespa Holding, owner of São Paulo’s stock exchange.

headline: A Simple Fix for Abraded Keys
abstract: Is there any remedy for worn-off keyboard letters? I’ve had this keyboard for less than a year, and already I’ve eroded several letters.

headline: Need Money for a Business? Start at the Bank.
abstract: For small business owners, forging a good working relationship with your banker is crucial, and it can result in more credit, lower fees and streamlined paperwork.

headline: If You Don’t Have Anything Nice to Post ...
abstract: Some critics say a Facebook application called Honesty Box has become another weapon in the cyberbully’s arsenal.

headline: An Exchange Official Is Charged
abstract: The vice chairman of the International Securities Exchange was accused of leaking confidential information about the $2.8 billion takeover of the market last year.

headline: As Seen on TV
abstract: In college I took a door-to-door sales job. I knew it would be challenging, but I saw it as a way to overcome my shyness.

headline: Taking the Bears to Task
abstract: Prominent bloggers are trading barbs over whether their fellow pundits have been far too optimistic or pessimistic about the economy.

headline: Iran: Russia Says New Rocket Raises Nuclear ‘Suspicions’
abstract: Iran fired the rocket Monday from its new space center in the deserts of Semnan Province and said it wanted to launch domestically built satellites for research and telecommunications.

headline: Putting Price on Flights of Fantasy
abstract: My husband and I struggle to stay in sync financially, but we get stuck in a rut whenever we look toward the 5-, 10- or even 20-year horizon.

headline: Hong Kong-Macao Hydrofoils Collide in Fog
abstract: Two high-speed hydrofoils ferrying passengers between the Chinese territories of Hong Kong and Macao collided in heavy fog off Macao, seriously injuring 19 people, the Macao government said.

headline: Hedging Their Way to Billions
abstract: Through the first nine months of 2007, three hedge fund managers had made more than $1 billion.

headline: The Netherlands: Not Reaching New Heights
abstract: The Dutch, thought to be the world’s tallest people, appear to have stopped growing, the Central Bureau for Statistics reported. It said growth rates for men and women had increased scarcely or not at all since 2001. The average Dutch man is 5 feet 11 inches tall. The average woman is 5-foot-6.

headline: A Google Friend Is Now Facebook’s
abstract: Google’s status as the coolest place to work may be waning. The company has lost another high-ranking employee to the social networking site Facebook.

headline: Rethinking Real Estate
abstract: In more than 300 cities and counties across the United States, residential developers are asked — or forced — to include a certain amount of affordable housing in their projects.

headline: The Thin Skin of Apple Fans
abstract: Introducing even a hint of negativity into a review or article will bring down the wrath of Apple’s most fanatical fans.

headline: Let Finances Be a Chore, Not a Phobia
abstract: While some research suggests a shift is occurring, the aversion many women have to money tasks is still surprisingly common.

headline: Glamour Is Chastened After Caddish Remarks by Dating Blogger Incite a Revolt
abstract: In the beginning, Glamour magazine’s s online community responded well to the postings of Mike Cherico, a Los Angeles high school teacher writing a blog about dating.

headline: Massachusetts Subpoenas 3 Banks
abstract: UBS, Merrill Lynch and the Bank of America were subpoenaed as the state looks into whether investors were properly informed of the risks of auction-rate securities.

headline: A Sign of Hope for Stocks
abstract: The behavior of the markets at their October peak raises hope that the recent decline may not turn out to be severe — and that it may have already run its course.

headline: 2 Ex-Marsh Officials Convicted on Antitrust Charge
abstract: Two former executives of Marsh Inc., the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.

headline: Leap Year Day Is Special, and Marketers Know It
abstract: Businesses and nonprofit organizations are using this year’s leap year day — Feb. 29 — as the occasion to make special proposals and pitches of their own.

headline: Tough Quarter for J.C. Penney, and More Expected
abstract: Fourth-quarter profit declined 10 percent as customers struggled with a weakening economy, the company said Thursday.

headline: The Air Shuttles to Boston and Washington Endure Industry’s Changes
abstract: Security lines, delays and the removal of the guaranteed-seat policy have undermined the shuttles’ basic quick-turnaround formula.

headline: Aloof From Recession
abstract: There are plenty of industries that have historically done well in recessions — particularly those that serve basic needs like food, energy and health care.

headline: Un-Naming Rights
abstract: IF the University of Wisconsin business school ever writes a case study about itself, the lesson may be that some things are more valuable unsold.

headline: Ahmadinejad, in Iraq, Chides Bush on Iran Criticism
abstract: The visit, the first by an Iranian leader since the brutal Iran-Iraq war of the 1980s, set off protests in Sunni Arab areas.

headline: China: Rails and Main Road Reopen
abstract: China’s main north-south highway, the Zhuhai-Beijing Expressway, reopened and was expected to ease the logjams that have stranded millions of bus and rail passengers after a series of exceptional snowstorms. Rail service was slowly returning to normal. About 80 trains left southern Guangzhou on Sunday with 210,000 passengers aboard, said the state-run newspaper The Southern Metropolis Daily. But a river of new travelers trying to get home for the Lunar New Year holiday this week flowed into the city on Monday, and the area around the main train station was still packed with people.

headline: Kenya: South African Bows Out of Mediation
abstract: Cyril Ramaphosa, a South African businessman who led the African National Congress’s negotiations to end apartheid in his country in the 1990s, withdrew as a mediator in crisis talks in Kenya after the government of President Mwai Kibaki said he would not be impartial because he had had business dealings with the top opposition leader, Raila Odinga. Mr. Ramaphosa denied that. He arrived in Nairobi on Friday to help Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, broker talks between Kenya’s opposing politicians. Talks continued without him. The sides pledged to help people return to their homes and to provide food and shelter for those displaced by the ethnic violence that broke out after with the Dec. 27 presidential election. The government also lifted a monthlong ban on live television broadcasts.

headline: Germany: Truck Maker’s Profit Rises 33%
abstract: The German truck maker MAN said its profit increased by 33 percent in the fourth quarter, powered by strong demand for its commercial vehicles, and forecast that earnings would continue to rise this year. MAN, which is based in Munich, said it earned 331 million euros ($490 million) in the October-December quarter, up from 248 million euros a year earlier. Total group sales rose 35 percent, to 5.23 billion euros ($7.7 billion) from 3.88 billion euros a year earlier. Sales of commercial vehicles rose 42 percent, to 3.6 billion euros ($5.3 billion). MAN said its fourth-quarter operating profit was up 78 percent, to 631 million euros ($935 million) from 354 million euros a year earlier.

headline: Airline Ordered to Pay French First Couple Over Ad
abstract: A French court ordered Ryanair to pay damages to President Nicolas Sarkozy and his new wife for using a photograph of them in an advertisement.

headline: France: Romantic, Glamorous, Litigious
abstract: President Nicolas Sarkozy and his wife, Carla Bruni, won a lawsuit against Ryanair, the European low-cost airline, for the unauthorized use of their photograph in an ad. A judge in Paris ordered the airline to pay Mr. Sarkozy one euro in damages, the sum he had asked for. Ms. Bruni, a former model, was awarded 60,000 euros, about $88,000. She had sought 500,000 euros, or $732,000, what she said she would expect to earn for appearing in an ad. The couple filed the suit against the airline after the ad appeared in the newspaper Le Parisien last week, just days before they married on Saturday. A cartoon bubble above Ms. Bruni read: “With Ryanair, my whole family can come to my wedding.”.

headline: Super Bowl and Olympics: This Marketer’s Dream Year
abstract: Herbert Hainer, the chief executive of Adidas, says his company is using major athletic events like the Super Bowl and the Summer Olympics in its battle to catch up with and surpass Nike.

headline: Proxy Fight Looms for Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft will wage a proxy fight to oust Yahoo’s directors, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Bank Outlines How Trader Hid His Activities
abstract: The French bank Société Générale, facing persistent questions over how a lone, junior trader could have instigated more than $7 billion in losses, acknowledged on Sunday that his activities prompted questions from risk managers several times last year, but that the bank never began an investigation because his explanations defused any suspicions.

headline: PubMatic Nabs $7 Million
abstract: PubMatic, an advertising optimization software company, said Tuesday it had received $7 million in venture financing.

headline: In a Photographer’s Memory, Images of the Dead
abstract: Five years have passed since I stood on the border of Iraq and Kuwait, watching the predawn sky for the first salvos in the Iraq war. I am reading political analyses and historical accounts of years that are past. I am thinking of all of the things that had not yet happened as I stood in the desert sand that day.

headline: Investors May Be Betting Against Clear Channel Deal
abstract: Speculation is apparently mounting that the $19.5 billion leveraged buyout of Clear Channel Communications, the U.S. radio and outdoor advertising group, could be the next victim of the storm in the deal world.

headline: Television Without the TV Set
abstract: Watching television episodes on a computer screen is now a common activity for millions of consumers.

headline: Behind SocGen’s Decision to Stand By Its Man
abstract: The board of Société Générale, gathering Wednesday in a conference room on the 35th floor of the bank’s headquarters outside Paris, tacitly agreed to grant the bank’s chairman and chief executive, Daniel Bouton, a reprieve.

headline: When the Going Gets Tough, the Tough Revive ‘90210’
abstract: The CW, the fifth-place broadcast network, needs one thing above all else: hit shows.

headline: Spectrum Auction: Bidders Spurn Frequencies Linked to Public Safety
abstract: After four rounds of of the government auction, only a single bid has emerged for the block of frequencies meant to combine national wireless voice and data service with communications for public safety agencies.

headline: Where Is Apple’s Rental Service for Music?
abstract: The latest iPods have built-in clocks that could support music subscription services as well as movie rentals. The music industry still believes that their best option is to charge people a flat monthly rate for all they want to listen to. Apple, so far, disagrees.

headline: Do Do That Hulu That You Do So Well
abstract: A roster of blue-chip advertisers is joining two media giants to do the Hulu.

headline: Canada: The Country That Couldn’t Say ‘No’
abstract: Canada’s takeover-friendly securities laws have helped make the country the easiest in the world for foreign acquirers, according to a new study that shows Canadians are the world’s biggest net sellers of corporate assets in terms of the nation’s market size.

headline: SocGen Rights Issue May Not Deter Bidders
abstract: A deeply discounted $8 billion rights issue from Société Générale, seen in part as a bid by the scandal-hit French bank to remain independent, has not convinced analysts that it will deter predators.

headline: CBS Likes ‘Price’ in Prime Time
abstract: CBS, which started showing “The Price Is Right” on Friday nights last month, has ordered four more after-dark episodes of the venerable daytime game show.

headline: At Writers’ Meeting, Cautious Optimism
abstract: Writers leaving the two-hour-plus New York meeting characterized the reaction as generally positive and said there was cautious optimism that the end of the strike — the guild’s first in 20 years — could be near.

headline: ACA Capital Receives Extension to Unwind Subprime Exposure
abstract: ACA Capital Holdings, the troubled bond insurer, has received an additional month to unwind an estimated $69 billion of credit exposure stemming from the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Thornburg Mortgage Says Survival in Doubt
abstract: Thornburg Mortgage, the second-largest independent mortgage lender in the United States, said Friday that its survival was at stake because it was unable to meet $610 million of margin calls.

headline: Buyout Firms’ True Struggle: Finding the Exit?
abstract: The collapse of the $1.8 billion buyout of PHH, a mortgage and vehicle leasing company, by the Blackstone Group and General Electric, had industry observers Wednesday lamenting the failed deal as an ominous start to the new year and yet another example of the drastic changes that have torn through the debt markets since the summer of 2007.

headline: Regulator Fines Brokerages Over Mutual Fund Sales
abstract: Brokerages, including units of Merrill Lynch and UBS, have agreed to pay $2.4 million in fines and reimburse more than $20 million to customers to settle investigations of improper mutual fund sales and transfers, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Thursday.

headline: Earnings Rise at Two Chinese Banks
abstract: The Bank of China and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China posted higher fourth-quarter profits Tuesday, buoyed by the country’s surging economy but dragged down by holdings in American subprime-related securities.

headline: Zagat Publisher Seeks Buyer
abstract: A “clever and sharp” restaurant guide company with “telling” rankings and “a penchant for quote marks” from its thousands of “in-the-know” reviewers is apparently “on the block.”

headline: New Threat to Clear Channel Unit Sale
abstract: Another buyout is in danger of collapsing – but this time because one of the banks involved is suing its own client, the private equity firm trying to do the deal.

headline: Thoma Cressy Takes Macrovision’s Software Unit
abstract: As Macrovision seeks to shore up support for its $2.8 billion Gemstar-TV Guide acquisition, the company announced on Thursday that it is selling its software business to a unit of private equity firm Thoma Cressey Bravo.

headline: JPMorgan to Funnel $750 Million into Asia Private Equity Fund
abstract: JPMorgan Chase announced a major push on Monday into private-equity investing in Asia, saying it had earmarked at least $750 million of its own capital to take minority stakes in businesses in a region where buyouts are notoriously difficult.

headline: Fortissimo Snaps Up Magic Software Unit
abstract: Magic Software Enterprises, a maker of tools for business software development and integration, said it sold its Advanced Answers on Demand subsidiary to a private equity firm, Fortissimo Capital, for $17 million. The agreement calls for payment in two installments with the last coming by the end of January.

headline: From Davos, an Early Take on Rate Cuts
abstract: As world leaders such as Gordon Brown and business bigshots such as Lloyd Blankfein stream into Davos this week for the World Economic Forum, the stock markets are giving them plenty to talk about. Floyd Norris, the chief financial correspondent for The New York Times, is already in Davos for the event. The latest post on Mr. Norris’s blog offers his initial thoughts on Tuesday morning’s potentially market-moving development: the United States Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cut:

headline: Sundance Channel Said to Be on the Block
abstract: The Sundance Channel, the cable network spawned from Robert Redford’s eponymous annual film festival, is up for sale, The New York Post reported.

headline: Mixed Reviews for Oprah the Merciful
abstract: “Oprah’s Big Give,” which will debut Sunday night on ABC, represents Oprah Winfrey’s first foray into prime time network television.

headline: Schwarzman’s School Ties
abstract: It isn’t often that Stephen A. Schwarzman admits to being less than the best. As the chairman and chief executive of the Blackstone Group, Mr. Schwarzman has constructed his career on his competitive streak, building his firm into one of the pre-eminent investment companies on Wall Street.

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Names New London Co-Heads
abstract: Sullivan & Cromwell has appointed new London management, with partners Vanessa Blackmore and Robert Schlein stepping up to lead the elite Manhattan firm’s London base.

headline: Oats, Peas, Beans and Emeril
abstract: Two months after severing some ties with the Food Network and one week after selling his franchise to Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Emeril Lagasse has a new television act: “Emeril Green,” an original series for the forthcoming Planet Green channel.

headline: HD DVD is Dealt a Blow
abstract: A single format for high definition DVDs will be a good thing for just about everybody on earth except the companies who aligned themselves with the losing format.

headline: Lithium Battery Ban? Check Again
abstract: The FAA ban on some batteries on planes — starting Jan. 1 — shouldn’t affect many travelers.

headline: The Browser Choices We Make
abstract: Firefox hit a milestone of 500 million downloads and it claims 17 percent of the Web browser market. And yet some people use some pretty old or obscure browsers. Why?

headline: How Bad Is It? AIG Can’t Tell
abstract: If someone wants to buy insurance against a risk, perhaps the insurance company should assume the risk is real.

headline: Small and Midsize Banks Start Struggling in Credit Crisis
abstract: The credit crisis is tightening the screws on thousands of small to midsize banks across the United States, squeezing local builders and businesses that depend on those lenders for financing.

headline: Credit Suisse Expected to Dodge Subprime Woes
abstract: The Credit Suisse Group is earning more than UBS for the first time in almost a decade after it avoided the write-downs that forced UBS to report the biggest-ever quarterly loss by a bank, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Liz Claiborne Close to Selling Ellen Tracy, Reports Says
abstract: Liz Claiborne, the fashion apparel company, is close to selling its Ellen Tracy brand to a private investment consortium for $50 million, The New York Post reported Wednesday.

headline: MSNBC Cancels Tucker Carlson Show
abstract: MSNBC is canceling ‘Tucker’ and replacing it with a new, politically oriented program featuring David Gregory.

headline: Commodities: Latest Boom, Plentiful Risk
abstract: The booming commodities market has become increasingly attractive to investors, with hard assets like oil and gold perhaps offering a safe hedge against inflation, as well as the double-digit gains that have fast been disappearing from the markets for stocks, bonds and real estate.

headline: Cameras Permitted–Maybe
abstract: You’ve been warned. The signs of the future may not say “NO PHOTOGRAPHY.” One day soon, they may say, “NO PHOTOGRAPHY WITH NICE CAMERAS.”

headline: Today’s Tech-Support Nightmare
abstract: An online customer-service chat leaves one wondering how we communicate at all.

headline: Lehman Snags Robeco Unit
abstract: Robeco Investment Management, an asset management company, has agreed to sell its municipal fixed-income business in the United States to Lehman Brothers as it nears the completion of its plans to exit the fixed income market in the United States.

headline: M&A in Ethnic Food Industry Heats Up
abstract: Acquisition activity in the so-called ethnic foods market has been cooking, as the Hispanic and Asian populations continue to increase in the United States and mainstream America gets a bigger appetite for an ever-widening range of cuisines, The Deal.com reports.

headline: An ‘Idol’ Creator Predicts More Growth in Reality
abstract: LAS VEGAS — How much reality is too much reality?

headline: MBIA to Call on Congress to Rein in Ackman
abstract: MBIA, the world’s biggest bond insurer, is planning to hit back at the hedge fund heavy William A. Ackman, who has long been betting against the insurers’ shares.

headline: Citigroup Sells Japan Headquarters to Morgan Stanley
abstract: Citigroup, which has been raising funds since taking a huge hit from the United States subprime mortgage meltdown, has sold its Japan headquarters to a rival, Morgan Stanley, in a deal reportedly worth $445 million.

headline: Checking Into 15 C.P.W. for $16 Million
abstract: Another Goldman Sachs employee has joined Lloyd Blankfein as a resident of one of New York’s hottest – and priciest – new buildings.

headline: SEIU Urges Action Against Countrywide Deal
abstract: Bank of America‘s deal to acquire Countrywide Financial has garnered both praise and brickbats from the financial community and the press. But it is also drawing fire from an unusual quarter: a major labor union.

headline: Canadian Hedge Funds Start Incubator Fund
abstract: A pair of Canadian firms have started a hedge fund incubator fund, calling it the “first of its kind” in the country.

headline: Intel Said to Invest in WiMax Venture
abstract: Sprint Nextel and Clearwire are close to announcing the formation of a WiMax joint venture with funds provided in part by a $2 billion injection from Intel, TheStreet.com reported.

headline: Merrill Shuts Unit Making Home Loans
abstract: Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that it would stop making subprime mortgages through its First Franklin Financial unit and would eliminate 650 jobs.

headline: More Margin-Call Woes at Carlyle Capital
abstract: Carlyle Capital, the investment fund affiliated with the private equity firm the Carlyle Group, said on Friday that it was exploring all its options after receiving another wave of margin calls from lenders.

headline: Ratings: How Many New Ways Can We Say It? Just Sing, Dammit. Sing!
abstract: Like a knife-wielding psycho that can’t be stopped, “American Idol” destroyed Thursday’s ratings for the third and final time this week, boosting the young Fox drama “New Amsterdam” and giving Fox an easy win for the evening.

headline: Listening for a Peep From Sunnyvale
abstract: Now that Microsoft has said it won’t raise its bid for Yahoo and is moving to take the matter to shareholders, it is time for Yahoo to say what it plans to do next.

headline: Danger: Curves Ahead
abstract: What is a private equity professional to do when all the talk about credit crunches and distressed debt becomes too much? Shake it off with a spin in a virtual race car.

headline: ConAgra to Sell Trading Unit to Ospraie Fund
abstract: ConAgra Foods, the packaged foods giant, said Thursday that it would sell its commodities trading unit to a fund run by Ospraie Management, a commodity-focused hedge fund, for about $2.1 billion in cash and debt.

headline: Buying Movies on Flash Drives: Nice Idea That Doesn’t Work
abstract: Instead of Blu-ray discs, some wonder if movies could be sold on flash memory cards. Flash, it turns out, is still too expensive and too slow to make this cost-effective.

headline: Willis Group Said to Eye Deal for Marsh & McLennan
abstract: An insurance broker, Willis Group Holdings, has approached its bigger rival, Marsh & McLennan about a possible takeover of Marsh & McLennan, CNBC reported.

headline: Friday’s Link: Even Secret Service Agents Want Work/Life Balance
abstract: Even Israeli secret service agents want work/life balance.

headline: Charming Shoppes Sues 2 Activist Funds
abstract: The owner of women’s plus-size apparel retailer Lane Bryant is suing a pair of activist hedge funds, accusing them of misleading the chain’s investors as they mount a proxy campaign to shake up the company’s board.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.
