abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: F1 in Schools video from Malaysia
abstract: When I was in Malaysia for the race I attended the F1 in Schools world championship races and did a story on it in the IHT’s new special F1 page. I also did a short video about the event, and have now put it up on the site and linked it to the story I wrote about the F1 in Schools event. And as you can see, I’ve also placed it below:

headline: Hedge Funds in Distressed Debt Rush
abstract: More than 70 hedge funds — including those run by Blackstone Group and Goldman Sachs — are rushing into the melee to snap up distressed mortgages and securities from banks battered by the subprime meltdown, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Co-Lead Defendant in Insider Trading Case is Sentenced
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs trader who helped lead a $6.7 million insider-trading conspiracy — and then cooperated with the government — was sentenced to time served by a federal district court judge on Friday.

headline: A Chance To Flee
abstract: Just how the Fed’s latest move should help to bail out Thornburg Mortgage is not clear to me. But a lot of money is being bet that it will.

headline: Marsh to Reorganize Amid Deal Speculation
abstract: Shares of Marsh & McLennan rose Thursday, extending the previous day’s gains, following a report that a key executive at its insurance brokerage unit had resigned and that a reorganization of the group was imminent.

headline: McCain Warns Against Hasty Mortgage Bailout
abstract: Drawing a sharp distinction between himself and the two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona warned Tuesday against vigorous government action to solve the deepening mortgage crisis and the market turmoil it has caused, saying that “it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers.”

headline: Comparing $100 million fines
abstract: It will no doubt continue to take a long time to digest the magnitude of the $100 million fine that the FIA asked McLaren Mercedes to pay in last summer’s Formula One spy scandal. But my wife, Nathalie, last night pointed out an interesting measuring stick: We were talking about the $285 million fine that Total SA, the oil company, along with three other defendants, were asked to pay by a Paris court for the ecological disaster that occurred after the sinking of the Erika tanker in 1999 spread oil along the French coast of Brittany.

headline: Ratings: Sinking Like ‘Eli Stone’
abstract: Fox’s less-than-a-year-old series “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” earned its highest ratings on record Thursday, outperforming its time slot competitor and one-time ratings phenomenon, ABC’s “Lost.”

headline: Liechtenstein Issues Warrant for Tax Informant
abstract: Liechtenstein has issued an international arrest warrant for a man suspected of selling stolen banking data to German authorities that formed the basis of a vast tax evasion scandal.

headline: Slide Slides Into Some Cash
abstract: Slide, the maker of applications for social networks, has raised another round of financing – $50 million from the private equity funds at Fidelity and T-Rowe Price.

headline: Lionsgate Poised to Make Deal With Writers
abstract: Lionsgate, the movie and television company, is soon expected to join the growing ranks of production houses that have signed independent deals with the Writers Guild of America.

headline: Private Equity Firm Said to Rev Up Deal for Ducati
abstract: A major shareholder in the Italian motorcycle maker Ducati plans to bid for the entire company and delist it, Italy’s financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported, according to Reuters.

headline: Diller to Keep His Hand In After IAC Split
abstract: Barry Diller, the media mogul who runs the Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp, told investors Tuesday that after the company spins off four divisions, he will stay involved in the management of the restructured IAC, Expedia and Ticketmaster.

headline: Counting Wall Street’s Casualties
abstract: Citigroup: 6,200. Lehman Brothers: 4,990.

headline: Viewers Find ‘Lost’
abstract: The premiere of the fourth season of “Lost” delivered 16.1 million viewers on Thursday, Nielsen estimated, lifting ABC to a No. 1 finish on the night, though the audience was down from the 18.8 million who watched last season’s debut. The premiere followed an 8 p.m. show summarizing the series’s complicated back story (13.1 million).

headline: National Security SPAC Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Big names of finance have gotten into blank-check companies in a big way in recent years. So why not a former United States ambassador to the United Nations and a former governor?

headline: The Birds, the Bees and Hardcore Business
abstract: The co-chairman of Vivid Video, the pornography film studio, plans on Saturday to take Google and Yahoo to task for being purveyors of smut to minors. But it isn’t because he finds free pornography to be a competitive threat, is it?

headline: Electronics Makers Look for the Next Display
abstract: Liquid crystal displays continue to dominate the television market. That hasn’t stopped Panasonic and Sony from trying to develop other display technologies.

headline: Strike: Who Needs Writers II, Primetime Edition
abstract: Here’s an eye-catching headline: “Primetime Ratings Will Increase Thanks to the Strike.”

headline: How Green Is Your Printer?
abstract: Xerox is introducing a Sustainability Calculator, a tool that representatives of its Office Services unit will use to help companies gauge the environmental impact of their printers and copiers. The point is s not to use them less, but to replace them with new printers.

headline: Singapore’s China Easter Bid Hits Turbulence
abstract: A Singapore Airlines bid to buy a 24 percent stake in China Eastern Airlines appeared to be in trouble Wednesday after a major shareholder criticized the deal as unfair.

headline: Rubbermaid Taps Technical Concepts in $445 Million Deal
abstract: The consumer products maker Newell Rubbermaid said Wednesday it had agreed to buy an Illinois maker of touch-free washroom dispensers and other devices for $445 million, its second acquisition announced this week.

headline: Merrill Lynch Co-President Will Leave
abstract: Merrill Lynch said on Monday that a president, Ahmass L. Fakahany, would leave as the company builds a new management team after an implosion in the credit market that caused $12 billion in net losses in the second half of 2007.

headline: Overseas Funds Resist Calls for a Code of Conduct
abstract: Last year, as governments in Asia and the Middle East started to buy stakes in financial institutions in the West, the Bush administration called for an international code of conduct by sovereign wealth funds. The purpose was to get the funds to disclose more of their activities and not play politics with their investments.

headline: Macklowe’s Pain Could Be Good News for Blackstone
abstract: Things aren’t looking so good for Harry B. Macklowe, the property developer who raced from lender to lender to round up a record-breaking $1.4 billion to buy the General Motors Building.

headline: Russia’s Binbank Sold
abstract: Mikhail Shishkhanov, a nephew of a Russian billionaire, Mikhail Gutseriyev, has agreed to sell a Russian lender, Binbank, to a businessman and senator, Vadim Moshkovich, the bank said on Friday.

headline: A Return Engagement in a Different Role
abstract: Almost exactly one year ago, in this space, we observed that Tony Blair, then British prime minister, had celebrated a “valedictory moment” at Davos – “his final appearance at the World Economic Forum as Britain’s prime minister after almost 10 years in office.” In parentheses we added: “but probably not his last time at the conference.”

headline: Is JPMorgan Getting Too Clever?
abstract: In scrambling to patch the mistakes in their previous deal with Bear Stearns, JPMorgan and its attorneys at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz may have put themselves in a newly precarious position.

headline: Offshore Outsourcing’s Next Wave: How High?
abstract: Just how much back-office work can be sent abroad, and how quickly, is a matter of some debate. Many think it will grow explosively.

headline: The Purpose of ‘Project Canoe’
abstract: Tim Arango reports:

headline: ‘Is PBS Still Necessary?’
abstract: In Sunday’s New York Times, Charles McGrath asks: Is PBS still necessary?

headline: Santander Said to Have Held Talks for British Lender
abstract: Grupo Santander, the owner of Abbey National, was recently in talks to buy another mortgage lender in Britain but negotiations stumbled on price and came to nothing, according to The Financial Times.

headline: On Fox, a ‘Moment’ of Cashing In
abstract: Fox televised the first truly uncomfortable episode of the lie-detector test show “The Moment of Truth” on Monday, and the contestant who admitted to adultery now says she only did it for the prize money.

headline: Sayonara, ‘Girlfriends’
abstract: The long-running sitcom “Girlfriends” is ending its run after eight seasons on UPN and the CW.

headline: Is Nasdaq Starting a Race to the Bottom for SPACs?
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market announced Thursday that it would propose new rules permitting special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, to list on its market.

headline: Jana Wins in Delaware Court
abstract: Jana won its case against CNet on Thursday in the Delaware Chancery Court. Referring to Lewis Carroll and the “Bloody Shirt of Blaisus,” Chancellor William B. Chandler held that the CNet bylaws were unambiguous in favor of Jana.

headline: Internet to the TV? Me Too!
abstract: Microsoft reached some new agreements to allow delivery of new movie and television content over the Xbox Live service and MSN online. It must mean the connected home – the holy matrimony between hardware and downloadable content – finally is at the altar.

headline: Courts Weigh in on Valuation Debate
abstract: That was fast.

headline: S.E.C. Sets New Office to Distribute Penalties to Investors
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday it has created a new office in the agency to quickly distribute financial penalties to wronged investors.

headline: ‘Deal’ And ‘Gladiators’ Top ‘Terminator’
abstract: Despite a lot of competition during prime time on Monday, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” and “American Gladiators” managed to rank No. 1 and No. 2 in the ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Deal or No Deal” delivered the largest audience overall, 15 million viewers at 9 p.m., while “American Gladiators” at 8 p.m. drew 10.7 million viewers.

headline: Yahoo Joins Social Network Group, as Google Gives Up Control
abstract: Yahoo joins the OpenSocial alliance, and Google transfers control over the group it created to a non-profit foundation.

headline: ‘House’ Enjoys The Post-Bowl Time Slot
abstract: The minutes immediately following the Super Bowl are some of the most valuable on television. With nearly 100 million viewers watching, broadcast networks have used the time slot has been used to debut new shows and prop up existing franchises.

headline: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid
abstract: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title “Only the Paranoid Survive.”

headline: The Men Behind the Bear Stearns Deal
abstract: DealBook offers a list of the major deal makers who helped sell Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share.

headline: Target in Talks to Sell $4 Billion in Credit Card Loans
abstract: The discount retailer Target said on Wednesday that it was in talks with an investment partner to sell an undivided interest in about half of its credit card receivables for about $4 billion.

headline: Swiss Venture Capital Firm Eyes I.P.O.
abstract: HBM BioVentures, the Swiss biotech and medical-device investor with about $1 billion in net assets, soon expects to go public in a rare move for a venture capital firm.

headline: Merrill Lynch to Close Subprime Lending Unit, Report Says
abstract: Merrill Lynch plans to wind down most of its First Franklin subprime mortgage lending unit, responding to continued deterioration in United States mortgage markets, CNBC reported.

headline: Monster to Acquire Affinity Labs for $61 Million
abstract: After roughly nine months on the job, Sal Iannuzzi, the chief executive of Monster Worldwide, the online employment company, is continuing his efforts to revive the company.

headline: A Last-Minute Musical Change for ‘SNL’
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Treasury Set to Announce Regulatory Overhaul
abstract: The Bush administration is proposing the broadest overhaul of Wall Street regulation since the Great Depression, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system. The plan is to be unveiled on Monday morning, although key elements were provided to the media in advance. In a news analysis over the weekend, The New York Times said the overhaul has its genesis in a yearlong effort to limit Washington’s role in the market.

headline: Wall Street on Spitzer: ‘There Is a God’
abstract: As news that New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer has been linked to a prostitution ring swept Wall Street Monday afternoon, the reaction can be described in one word: schadenfreude.

headline: Fox’s Reality Squirmfests Continue to Deliver
abstract: The return of “Lost” — albeit a two-hour repeat of the last season finale — buoyed ABC’s ratings on a night otherwise dominated by Fox’s “American Idol” and “Moment of Truth.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two Fox programs delivered the night’s largest audiences by far, 25.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. for “American Idol” followed by 17.9 million for “The Moment of Truth” at 9 p.m.

headline: Transmeta Hires Piper Jaffray to Advise on Buyout
abstract: A chip designer, Transmeta said Thursday it had lined up Piper Jaffray to help it weigh an unsolicited buyout offer from an investor, Riley Investment Management.

headline: For Ex-Goldman Trader, a Good Sinking Feeling
abstract: After four years of trading subprime mortgages, Jason Rew jettisoned his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs and founded an off-shore business.

headline: A U.K. Restaurant Happy to Take Bankers’ Bonuses
abstract: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague in London:

headline: Japan’s Takefuji Faces $290 Million Loss on Investment
abstract: The Japanese consumer lender Takefuji said it might lose as much as 30 billion yen ($290 million) on a structured finance deal arranged by Merrill Lynch, making it the first money lender in the country to be hit by the global credit crisis.

headline: Without Writers, Leno Still Wins
abstract: One month after returning without writers, Jay Leno is winning the late-night talk-show race “even though his main competitor, David Letterman, was widely thought to have an advantage.”

headline: Citi’s New Mantra: Risk Management
abstract: Ben Bernanke, meet Gary Crittenden. While you’re easing credit, he is tightening it.

headline: Wachovia’s Big-City Splash Has a Sobering Aftermath
abstract: In yet another concrete sign of trouble in the commercial real estate market, Wachovia, the nation’s fourth-largest bank, announced on Tuesday that it would be taking write-downs of more than $1 billion for commercial loans for the second half of last year. That sum includes $488 million in previously disclosed write-downs for the third quarter.

headline: J.P. Morgan Says Profit Fell in 4th Quarter
abstract: Though it has held up better than many of its Wall Street peers in recent months,  J.P. Morgan Chase is feeling the subprime pinch. The bank on Wednesday posted a 21 percent decline in net income from continuing operations for the fourth quarter, driven in part by a $1.3 billion write-down on assets tied to mortgage loans.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Forum Oilfield Pulls I.P.O.
abstract: Forum Oilfield Technologies withdrew its initial public offering last week, saying it was no longer going forward with it because of “market conditions.”

headline: Lessons in Brevity
abstract: An abbreviated keynote address and seven-word mantras show how effectively a message can be delivered with a minimum of words.

headline: Paul Frère’s death
abstract: He was 91 years old, he lived an incredibly full life. He drove for Ferrari, raced in 11 Grand Prixs in the 1950s. He won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1960. He was cultivated, wrote much (in English and French) and continued testing cars and writing until he was in his 80s – in fact, he was still wickedly fast at 87, setting respectably fast laptimes in an Audi that would later win Le Mans.

headline: A Chilly Candidate for Deal Deathwatch
abstract: Not that long ago, Wall Street’s favorite parlor game was speculating about the next leveraged buyout target. These days, the guessing has turned to which buyout deal will be the next to die.

headline: Sell More NAND, Watch Margins Drop
abstract: NAND flash chips account for only a fraction of Intel’s business, but the segment’s impact on Intel’s bottom line is more dramatic because lower price points mean the company sells even greater quantities, bringing down gross margins.

headline: Colony Capital Hires Ex-Amgen C.F.O. as Principal
abstract: Colony Capital, a private equity firm focused on real estate, said on Monday that it had hired Richard D. Nanula as a principal with a senior role in the firm.

headline: U.S. Bancorp Earnings Dropped 21% in 4th Quarter
abstract: U.S. Bancorp said Tuesday that fourth-quarter earnings fell 21 percent, but the Minneapolis-based bank largely avoided the subprime woes that have hurt other major financial institutions.

headline: Google Goes After Another Microsoft Cash Cow
abstract: Google broadens its assault on Microsoft’s business software franchise with a program that allows groups of workers to jointly create Web documents.

headline: Tesla Fires Executives Amid Shake-Up
abstract: Tesla Motors has yet to bring a product to market, but the electric-car maker certainly knows how to give off sparks. The closely watched Silicon Valley start-up, which recently became estranged from one of its co-founders, has apparently just sent a large number of its employees packing.

headline: Peering Inside GlassHouse Technologies
abstract: GlassHouse Technologies is one of several data-storage companies to seek an initial public offering of late. But GlassHouse is different, according to The 451 Group, because it provides consulting and information technology services rather than storage products. Will the markets buy into the services model?

headline: Sprint Returns a Shot in the Battle of the Bundle
abstract: To combat its huge write downs and losses in customers, Sprint caught up with its rivals with a new $99 unlimited wireless voice and data plan. It offers a little more than those rivals’ plans. Can a price war be far away?

headline: If Sony BMG Drops D.R.M. for Music, D.R.M. Is Gone
abstract: The concept of digital right management software limiting consumers’ use of downloaded music may be coming to an end.

headline: More Blood Expected on The Street
abstract: Forget the big bonus, access to the corporate jet and oceans of pricey champagne at dinner. For many bond and equity traders, The New York Post suggests, the new status symbol on Wall Street may a steady job.

headline: Protesters Infiltrate Bear Stearns Lobby
abstract: Wearing yellow T-shirts with the Neighborhood Assistance Corporation of America logo, some 200 protesters took to the Bear Stearns lobby to demonstrate their belief that the government is bailing out Wall Street while abandoning Main Street.

headline: In Europe, Questions Over Continuing Write-Downs
abstract: When UBS disclosed in October that it had written down $3.6 billion in mortgage-backed securities, it was praised for biting the bullet.

headline: Coughlin Stoia Seeks $688 Million for Enron Work
abstract: The California law firm that led the effort to gain the largest civil securities settlement in history in massive Enron shareholder litigation wants $688 million for its work.

headline: Quebecor to Get Rescue Package
abstract: Quebecor and Brookfield Asset Management have thrown a controversial lifeline to the struggling printing giant Quebecor World in the form of a proposed 400 million Canadian dollar ($393.6 million) financing package, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Maybank to Pay $1.1 Billion for Temasek Stake in BII
abstract: Temasek, the Singapore investment company, has sold its holding in Bank Internasional Indonesia for $1.1 billion to Maybank, Malaysia’s biggest financial services group, Finance Asia reported.

headline: L’Affaire Kerviel Distracts from SocGen’s Subprime Woes
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel’s 4.8 billion euro trading loss ($7.1 billion) had a positive effect for Société Générale, at least temporarily.

headline: Diller Says Weak IAC Results Justify His Spinoff Proposal
abstract: It’s not every day that an embattled chief executive uses lackluster results as a defense against a disgruntled shareholder.

headline: Coal for Some Goldman Employees?
abstract: With all the hype recently about Goldman Sachs being the only major investment bank to avoid being stung in last year’s subprime mortgage fiasco and the record profits it rung up last year, bonus time was expected to be a time of good cheer for Goldman employees.

headline: A Guide to Hunting Bear Stearns
abstract: With Bear Stearns‘s prompting new takeover rumors, how well can the investment bank resist?

headline: Deal for Mortgage Lender PHH Collapses
abstract: In another sign that troubles within the mortgage industry will continue into 2008, one of the largest originators of residential home loans announced Tuesday that it is scrapping a planned $1.8 billion sale, because banks had failed to agree to finance the transaction.

headline: The World According to Strine
abstract: There was a hearing Tuesday on the complaint that Alliance Data Systems filed against Blackstone Group related to their faltering buyout agreement. Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. set a tentative trial date for March 24, though it was a very slippery date.

headline: Visa I.P.O. Could Be Boon for Lawyers, Too
abstract: Visa has two big challenges ahead. The first is its plan for what is expected to be an $18 billion initial public offering, which would be the biggest ever in the United States.

headline: Chatter of an HSBC Bid for SocGen Resurfaces
abstract: Speculation that HSBC, the British bank, might bid for Société Générale of France resurfaced on Wednesday as an impending $8 billion capital increase by Société Générale loomed in the background.

headline: G.E. Chairman Rejects Talk of NBC Sale
abstract: Now hear this: NBC Universal is not for sale. No how, no way.

headline: Qatar Petroleum Plans I.P.O. for Gulf Unit
abstract: Qatar Petroleum,a state-owned oil company, said on Sunday it would sell a 65.8 percent stake in a new holding firm in an initial public offering starting on Feb. 28.

headline: Podcast: Examining Sadr’s Cease-Fire
abstract: Rich Oppel examines the decision by the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr to extend his militia’s cease-fire for six more months.

headline: More at Stake in Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
abstract: Microsoft has been justifying its $44 billion bid for Yahoo as a way to build sufficient scale in the search and advertising business to counter the Google juggernaut.

headline: Inquiry Assails Accounting Firm in Lender’s Fall
abstract: A sweeping five-month investigation into the collapse of one of the nation’s largest subprime lenders points a finger at a possible new culprit in the mortgage mess: the accountants.

headline: Leno, O’Brien Will Face Pickets
abstract: When Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien of NBC return to their late-night television homes tonight, their guests and audience members will face picket lines of striking writers.

headline: Eight Years, And Back To The Start
abstract: If you fled Wall Street eight years ago — remember Y2K? — and came back today, you might conclude that nothing much happened while you were gone.

headline: Temasek: The Rise of ‘Singapore Inc.’
abstract: Temasek Holdings, a decades-old Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, has its roots as a financial backer of domestic companies. In recent years, however, Temasek has moved aggressively, first within Southeast Asia, then Asia as a whole and finally to the West. It has acquired stakes in critical industries such as telecommunications and in companies that are household names, most recently Merrill Lynch.

headline: NBC Pulls the Plug on ‘Quarterlife’
abstract: NBC pulled “Quarterlife,” the made-for-Internet series, on Thursday, after broadcasting only one low-rated episode.

headline: G.E. Swaps Units and Also Makes a Sale
abstract: General Electric used two deals on Thursday to shuffle its lineup.

headline: French Bank’s Chief to Stay, For Now
abstract: Societe Generale ‘s top executive has offered to resign for a second time since the French bank disclosed a $7 billion trading scandal. But the bank’s directors on Wednesday asked him to stay in his post — at least for the moment.

headline: Carlyle Capital to Liquidate
abstract: It’s official: Carlyle Capital has gone bust.

headline: Seatwave Pulls in $25 Million
abstract: Seatwave, a startup that creates a secondary market for theater, sports and music event tickets in Britain and Europe, is expected to announce on Monday that it has raised $25 million in a series C round of fundraising.

headline: Parliament Approves Legislation to Nationalize British Bank
abstract: The British Parliament passed legislation on Thursday allowing the government to nationalize the struggling lender Northern Rock, five months after the bank became a high-profile casualty of the global credit squeeze.

headline: Microsoft to Authorize Proxy Fight at Yahoo
abstract: In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Unless Yahoo quickly reverses course and enters into talks, Microsoft would then seek to nominate a slate of directors to Yahoo’s board by March 13, the final deadline for nominations, and pursue a lengthy campaign to oust the board.

headline: CNN’s Primary Night Victory Lap
abstract: CNN’s political fixation is paying off.

headline: Toll Grades Again
abstract: Robert Toll, the chief executive of Toll Brothers, which bills itself as “the nation’s leading builder of luxury homes,” is out again with his grades on the markets in which the company is trying to sell homes.

headline: Private Equity Said to Balk at Zagat’s Price-Tag
abstract: Several private equity firms have dropped out of the bidding for Zagat Survey, the restaurant guide publiser, because of its high price demands, according to The Deal.com.

headline: High-Paid Chiefs on the Hot Seat
abstract: The chief of Countrywide Financial and the former chiefs of Citigroup and Merrill Lynch were set to testify before Congress on Friday about the abundant pay packages they got even as their shareholders lost billions — and if a memorandum released ahead of the hearing is any guide, they can expect quite a grilling.

headline: Ambac Posts $3.3 Billion Loss
abstract: The Ambac Financial Groupm the bond insurance company, reported a quarterly loss of $3.3 billion on Tuesday after recording massive credit derivative write-downs and setting aside more money for credit losses.

headline: Suit Over Clear Channel TV Deal Is Settled
abstract: Updated:The private equity firm Providence Equity Partners reached a settlement Friday with Wachovia, one of the banks financing its purchase of Clear Channel Communication‘s television unit, helping clear the way for the radio broadcaster’s larger sale to two other buyout firms.

headline: At Davos, L’Affaire Kerviel Is the Topic du Jour
abstract: The figure that arrived on BlackBerries in Davos and made by far the most headlines on Thursday was this: 4.9 billion euros, or $7.2 billion. This massive trading fraud, announced by Société Générale earlier in the day and allegedly executed by a single rogue trader, put Barings‘ Nick Leeson to shame and sent shudders down the spines of all those working in the financial world and pressing the flesh this week at the World Economic Forum.

headline: Prosecutors Say Ex-A.I.G. Executives Created a Fraud
abstract: Prosecutors in the trial of five former insurance executives insisted Monday in closing arguments that the defendants had deliberately mounted a fraud to allow the American International Group to manipulate its financial statements.

headline: It’s A ‘Jungle’ Out There For NBC
abstract: Video

headline: Will Icahn Make Another Run at Motorola?
abstract: Is Carl C. Icahn going to once again take up the tomahawk at Motorola?

headline: When Risk Management Isn’t Just a Department
abstract: Managing risk within a bank is not just a matter of relying on internal processes but also requires making the right decisions at the top of the company, Citigroup‘s chairman, Winfried Bischoff, said on Tuesday.

headline: Live From Davos: Day 3
abstract: Three letters are echoing through this mountain town: S.W.F.

headline: ‘George’ Returns To Cartoon Jungle
abstract: The “George of the Jungle” cartoon returns to television for the first time in 41 years today, with the debut of a Cartoon Network version at 7:30 p.m. Stuart Elliott reports:

headline: Logging On and Tuning In at 40,000 Feet
abstract: A telecommunications provider to airlines is set to try Internet-access-in-the-sky yet again.

headline: Picketers Will Greet Colbert and Stewart
abstract: Comedy Central’s pair of news satires will resume production today after a two-month strike-induced hiatus. Small picket lines of Writers Guild of America members will be stationed outside the studios of both “The Daily Show” and “The Colbert Report” as Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert return to their respective broadcasts.

headline: Morgan Stanley, Starwood Sell Tokyo Westin to Singapore Fund
abstract: The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation bought the Westin Tokyo hotel from Morgan Stanley and the Starwood Capital Group as Morgan Stanley shuffles its Japan portfolio.

headline: JPMorgan to Acquire ClimateCare
abstract: JPMorgan Chase agreed the acquisition of carbon offset provider ClimateCare for an undisclosed sum, the two businesses said in a joint statement.

headline: Top BofA Executives Get Scaled-Back Bonuses
abstract: Bank of America‘s compensation committee took an ax to the bonuses of its top executives, according to a proxy statement the company filed Wednesday with regulators. Still, Kenneth Lewis and his colleagues received millions of dollars in payouts during an extremely tough year for the bank, which could make things interesting as shareholders consider a so-called “say on pay” provision, which is up for vote at Bank of America’s annual meeting next month.

headline: In Enron Case, Lawyer Says Evidence Withheld
abstract: A lawyer for one of three Merrill Lynch executives convicted in 2004 on charges of participating in a sham asset sale with Enron alleges that prosecutors withheld evidence from the defense to manufacture a case without a crime.

headline: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
abstract: The virtual worlds created by Vivaty represent the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
abstract: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billiton‘s attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

headline: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
abstract: France’s Société Générale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

headline: Former Bear Executive Joins Merrill Lynch
abstract: After 22 years with Bear Stearns in Dallas, Sheldon Stein joined Merrill Lynch this week as a Dallas-based managing director and vice chairman of investment banking.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Is Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of masterminding one of the most unusual insider-trading conspiracies in recent memory, one that reaped about $6.7 million, was sentenced Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
abstract: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
abstract: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolina’s Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

headline: Fremont’s Future Threatened by Default Notice
abstract: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

headline: Sunday Belongs To ‘Knight Rider’ (At Least Among Younger Viewers)
abstract: On Sunday, NBC’s highly promoted two-hour movie “Knight Rider” (12.7 million) earned the highest ratings in the 18-to-49 age group for a made-for-television movie on any network in almost three years.

headline: Blank Check Raises $879 Million in Europe
abstract: Liberty International Acquisition, the latest blank-check company formed by investor Nicolas Berggruen, raised 600 million euro ($879 million), somewhat less than the expected $1 billion, when its initial public offering priced late Tuesday in Europe. But the deal did succeed in pricing, a feat in itself given Tuesday’s swan dive in global stock markets.

headline: A Tale of Two Camcorders
abstract: Look at the difference between the quality of a $3,200 camcorder and a $150 Flip camcorder. Is it $3,050 worth of difference?

headline: The “Save XP” Petition
abstract: Some people dislike Microsoft Vista so much they are starting a petition to save its predecessor, Windows XP.

headline: Companies Are Piling Up Cash
abstract: At least someone knows how to fill a piggy bank.

headline: Optimistic Analysts, Part 1
abstract: Arnie Berman, the chief technology analyst at Cowen, surveyed the consensus expectations on profits at 388 tech companies.

headline: Ex-Amaranth Executive Reappears At Hudson Bay
abstract: Hudson Bay Capital Management, the hedge fund founded by ex-proprietary trader Sander Gerber, hired Amaranth Advisors‘ former chief operating officer, Charles Winkler, according to a report in HedgeWorld.

headline: Kenneth Lewis’s Big Countrywide Bet
abstract: Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nation’s largest bank.

headline: The Debt Burden Squeezing Buyout Firms
abstract: With their big paydays and bigger egos, private equity moguls came to symbolize an era of hyper-wealth on Wall Street. Now their fortunes are plummeting.

headline: ‘Housewives,’ ‘Samantha’ Back In April; ABC Holds Three Shows Until Fall
abstract: “ABC said on Wednesday that several series knocked off the air by the Hollywood writers strike, including “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Desperate Housewives,” will return in April but three newer shows will stay sidelined until next season,” Reuters reports.

headline: Reliance Mulls Offering Bonus Shares After Debut Plunge
abstract: India’s Reliance Power, owned by the billionaire Anil Ambani, could issue bonus shares to investors in a move to compensate them for a sharp decline in its stock price, the company said on Monday.

headline: The Five Stages of Yahoo’s Grief
abstract: Denial: The initial stage: “It can’t be happening.”

headline: India’s Wockhardt Hospital Trims I.P.O.
abstract: Wockhardt Hospitals cut the size of its initial public offering, the first Indian company to reduce a sale amid a plunge in equity markets.

headline: TCW Group Slashes Stake in Circuit City
abstract: A major shareholder of Circuit City Stores, the nation’s No. 2 electronics retailer, has sold nearly its entire stake in the company, which reported last week that sales in December had fallen.

headline: Bringing the ‘Lean Forward’ Experience of the Web to TV
abstract: Pick up the remote, turn on the television — and watch YouTube.

headline: Citi, Merrill Said to Pursue More Foreign Capital
abstract: Citigroup and Merrill Lynch are in discussions to receive more capital from investors, primarily foreign governments, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.

headline: Bear Stearns, By the Numbers
abstract: From DealBook’s colleague Floyd Norris on Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Corporate Tech Spending: What’s Next?
abstract: Investments in technology move in big cycles, and the next big upswing could focus on business intelligence software, already an industry that has had a wave of big takeovers.

headline: How Being a Woman Gets You Star Service
abstract: There has probably never been service like it! About 40 women congregated Friday night in the cozy wooden chalet restaurant of the Davos Golf Club and heard Queen Rania of Jordan, Sarah Brown (as in wife of Gordon, Prime Minister of Britain), Indra K. Nooyi, CEO of PepsiCo, Wendi Murdoch, the rock star Annie Lennox and the ”best dressed woman at Davos,” the former Nigerian finance minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, make powerful appeals for concerted action to cut down maternal mortality. Among those listening: Cherie Booth (as in wife of Tony Blair, Gordon’s predecessor), Ann Veneman of UNICEF and leaders of charities like Oxfam and Save the Children.

headline: What Should a Candidate Read?
abstract: CBS asked the presidential candidates to choose the one book they think would be essential to take to the White House, other than the Bible. Only one chose a book related to economics, and that was Senator John McCain, a Republican candidate who has been criticized for lacking economic expertise.

headline: How KKR Could Pull the I.P.O. Plug
abstract: Call a search party: KKR‘s initial public offering is missing in action. KKR — the proposed name for the publicly traded affiliate of Henry Kravis’s private equity firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts — first filed its documents to go public with the Securities and Exchange Commission way back on July 3, 2007. Since that time, it has amended its registration statement twice, the last time on Nov. 13.

headline: Deutsche Bank Avoids Pitfalls of Subprime Collaspse
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, posted a smaller than expected decline in fourth-quarter profit after avoiding the collapse of the subprime mortgage market in the United States that left competitors with record losses.

headline: Doomsayers in Fashion This Year
abstract: The opening panel of the World Economic Forum traditionally gives a macroeconomic weather forecast for the coming 12 months. This year, expect black clouds to gather over Davos when the panel kicks off on Wednesday morning.

headline: Blackstone and Wellspring to Buy Food Distributor
abstract: Performance Food Group, a food-distribution company, said early Friday it had agreed to be acquired by the Blackstone Group and Wellspring Capital Management for $34.50 in cash, or about $1.3 billion.

headline: Hounded by Iraqi Musclemen, a Journalist Awaited His Own Liberation
abstract: At the outset, for me, the approach of American troops to Baghdad was an issue of intense personal concern, as much as professional. The Army and Marine units that arrived at the outskirts of Baghdad in the first days of April 2003 were viewed, then, by an overwhelming majority of Iraqis as liberators from the tyranny of Saddam Hussein. But they were my liberators, too.

headline: Wild Wheat
abstract: There was a time when commodities markets were viewed with deep suspicion by farmers, who saw speculators and gamblers manipulating the prices of crops to benefit themselves and steal from farmers. In 1874, one house of the Illinois legislature approved a bill to make it a crime to trade a futures contract unless the seller actually had possession of the crop. The Chicago Board of Trade managed to water down the law to bar the trading of options, but not futures, and thus stayed in business.

headline: A Savior for Chrysler? Read On
abstract: In a letter to investors about the state of Cerberus Capital Management‘s investments in Chrysler and GMAC, the firm’s founder, Stephen Feinberg, came off sounding at turns cavalier and ruthless, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Super Tuesday: A Comfortable Couric Leads The Conversation On CBS
abstract: Katie Couric, the “CBS Evening News” anchor, hosted two hours of prime time primary coverage on Tuesday.

headline: Rebukes Are Swift for the Chief of Deutsche Post
abstract: The German political elite has wasted no time in dissociating itself from Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post, who is suspected of using a foundation in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

headline: Countrywide Is Sued Again by U.S. Overseer
abstract: The United States Trustee has filed a second lawsuit against the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, accusing the company of abusing the bankruptcy process.
